question_title:
1.
        A 23 year old female caught in a car fire was brought to the emergency room. She was conscious, oriented, pulse rate - 82 bpm and blood pressure - 130/70 mmHg. On further examination, her hard palate revealed blisters and the anterior nasal hair was burned. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
optionA:
A. Secure airway by endotracheal intubation 
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Administer oxygen through bag and mask
explanation:
Explanation

The next best step in the management of this patient is securing the airway by endotracheal intubation.(Option A)

As the given clinical scenario of a female patient with stable vitals and examination findings of hard palate with blisters and anterior nasal hairs burned suggests a potential burned airway injury due to smoke or direct fire inhalation. 

In such cases, if the airway is not secured by a endotracheal tube immediately then complete occlusion of the airway due to laryngeal edema can occur rapidly. This will lead to difficult intubation at this stage and an emergency cricothyroidotomy is indicated. (Option C)

Because of this, early intubation of suspected airway burn is the treatment of choice in such patients and the tube is left in place usually for about 48 hours for the swelling to subside.

The time frame from burns to airway occlusion is usually between 4 and 24 hours. Although antidotes exist to some specific components of smoke(carbon monoxide and cyanide), the treatment of smoke inhalation usually involves endotracheal intubation and ventilatory support (sometimes for several weeks).

According to the latest ATLS guidelines, the order of primary survey in a burns patient is ABCDEF following the principle of ‘what kills first should be managed first’ - 

  • Airway
  • Breathing
  • Circulation with control of haemorrhage
  • Disability(neurological)
  • Exposure with environmental control
  • Fluid resuscitation 

After securing the airway, breathing can be assessed by auscultating for breath sounds and a chest X-ray to look for a pneumothorax or hemothorax. Administering oxygen through a bag and mask is useful during desaturation only if the airway is patent. Therefore, securing the airway is the most important next step for this patient. (Option D) The patient's vital signs are stable, and there is no mention of neurological symptoms or other signs that might immediately suggest CO poisoning, therefore carbogen administration will not be helpful. (Option C)
subject: Surgery

question_title:
3.
        Which of the following signs of pneumoperitoneum is incorrectly paired?
optionA: A. Rigler's sign - Air on both sides of the bowel wall
optionB: B. Football sign - Air outlines the peritoneal cavity
optionC:
C. Cupola sign - Air around the urinary bladder
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Inverted V sign - Air outlines the lateral umbilical ligament
explanation:
Explanation

Cupola sign refers to the presence of air under the central tendon of the diaphragm.

Signs of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs:
    • Double wall sign/ Rigler's sign/ bas-relief sign - Air is seen on both sides of the bowel wall.
    • Telltale triangle sign/ triangle sign - Triangle of gas formed between three loops of bowel or between the abdominal wall and 2 loops of bowel.
  • Peritoneal ligament-related signs:
    • Football sign - Air outlines the confines of the peritoneal cavity
    • Falciform ligament sign -  Air outlines the falciform ligament
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign/ inverted "V" sign - Air outlines the lateral umbilical ligament
    • Urachus sign - Air outlines the urachus
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Cupola sign - Accumulation of air under the central tendon
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign - Air outlines the ligamentum teres
    • Hepatic edge sign -  cigar-shaped free-air pocket in the subhepatic region. It tracks superomedial following the contours of the liver
    • Lucent liver sign - Reduction of hepatic radiodensity due to accumulation of free gas anterior to the liver
    • Morison pouch sign/ Doge cap sign - Triangular/ crescentic gas lucency bound by the 11th rib
    • Periportal free gas sign
subject: Radiology

question_title:
4.
        During the abdominal examination on a 6-month-old infant, you notice the following finding. Which of the following are false regarding this condition?
question_ADD:
1. Incidence of this condition is higher in premature births
  2. Sac decreases in size when the baby cries
  3. Commonly seen in children with congenital hyperthyroidism
  4. Obstruction and strangulation are common below the age of 2 years.
  5. Spontaneous resolution is unlikely if it persists beyond 2 years
explanation:
Explanation

The image shows a mass protruding out of the umbilicus indicative of an umbilical hernia. Sac increases in size when the baby cries. Commonly seen in children with congenital hypothyroidism. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon below the age of 3 years.

An umbilical hernia occurs when a loop of the intestine protrudes through the umbilicus. It is common in newborn children, especially in premature babies. Both sexes are equally affected and the incidence in black infants is up to eight times higher than in white. The hernia is often symptomless, but increases in size on crying and assumes a classic conical shape. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon in umbilical hernias.

Conservative treatment is indicated under the age of 2 years when the hernia is symptomless. The majority of them will resolve spontaneously. If the hernia persists beyond the age of 2 years of age, surgical repair is indicated, as a spontaneous resolution becomes unlikely beyond 2 years of age.

Procedure: A small curved incision is made below the umbilicus and the neck of the sac is opened. The contents are returned to the peritoneal cavity and the redundant sac is excised after closing it. The defect in the linea alba is closed with interrupted sutures.
subject: Surgery

question_title:
5.
        Screening for inborn errors of metabolism in a newborn revealed the presence of severe hyperammonemia with respiratory alkalosis. Plasma levels of orotic acid were normal. Where is the deficient enzyme located in the cell?
explanation:
Explanation

In the above scenario, hyperammonemia and normal orotic acid suggest a carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 enzyme deficiency. It is an enzyme located in the mitochondria of the cell. 

The urea cycle begins in the mitochondria and ends in the cytoplasm. During the metabolism of amino acids through the process of transamination, the amino acids are then cleaved into a carbon skeleton and an amino group that gets removed as ammonia. Ammonia later enters the urea cycle and gets converted into urea which is excreted in the urine.

The urea cycle begins with one molecule of ammonia combined with CO2 in the presence of two molecules of ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate. The reaction is catalyzed by the mitochondrial enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-I (CPS-I).

CPS-I reaction is the rate-limiting step in urea formation which is irreversible and allosterically regulated. 

  CPS-1 CPS-2
Site Mitochondria Cytosol
Pathway Urea Pyrimidine synthesis
Positive effector NAG Nil
Source of NAG Ammonia Glutamine
Inhibitor Nil CTP

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

Enzyme Deficient  Disorder  Features
CPS 1 Hyperammonemia type 1 Rare, characterized by severe hyperammonemia
Ornithine transporter HHH syndrome Hyperornithinemia, Hyperammonemia, and Homocitrullinuria.
Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) Hyperammonemia type 2 X-linked trait characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
Argininosuccinate synthetase   Increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
Argininosuccinate lyase   Argininosuccinic acedemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
Arginase   Hyperargininemia and argininuria

 

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

question_title:
6.
        A patient with pheochromocytoma is posted for surgery. Which of the following anesthetic agents is safe to use in this patient?
explanation:
Explanation

Patients with pheochromocytoma have risk of increased release of catecholamines and their consequences like tachyarrythmias. Muscle relaxants like vecuronium and rocuronium have little to no role in causing such effects hence safe to use in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Drugs that are contraindicated to use in patients with pheochromocytoma : 

DRUGS REASON
Ketamine Sympathomimetic - exacerbation of symptoms
Halothane Sensitizes myocardium to adrenaline (risk of tachyarrythmia)
Atracurium Histamine release -> compensatory catecholamine surge
Pancuronium Vagolytics -> tachycardia & tachyarrythmia
Anticholinergics
subject: Anaesthesia

question_title:
7.
        In a patient with an acute exacerbation of asthma with severely compromised lung function who is not responsive to nebulized beta-2 agonists, which of the following is the steroid of choice for systemic use?
explanation:
Explanation

The steroid of choice for systemic use in this above clinical scenario where there is an acute exacerbation of asthma (especially when the lung function is <30% predicted and there is no improvement with a nebulized β2 agonist) is hydrocortisone. 

Hydrocortisone has the most rapid onset (5–6 hours after administration), compared to 8 hours with prednisolone. It is given at a dose of 4 mg/kg initially, followed by a maintenance dose of 3 mg/kg every 6 hours. Intravenous therapy is usually given until a satisfactory response is obtained, and then it is replaced with oral prednisolone.

Mechanism of action of corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta-2 receptor genes and hence, increased responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors. Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating the enzyme histone deacetylase, which is the target for steroids as well.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
9.
        You are an Intern posted in a rural PHC OPD. The mother of a 2 week old infant brings him to the OPD complaining of a “cursed birthmark” on the baby’s back. Upon examination, you notice the following lesion covered in coarse hair. What is the treatment of choice for the given condition?
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario suggests Giant Congenital Pigmented Nevus (GCPN). Total surgical excision is the treatment of choice.

Giant Congenital Pigmented Nevus (GCPN) is a rare congenital benign skin tumour with a 5% chance of developing malignant melanoma. The risk increases with the nevus’s size, location, and presence of satellite lesions, typically diagnosed around age 7.

Early surgical intervention is recommended, ideally within the first few years of life, especially for large nevi or those on the head or spine. The exact timing may depend on imaging results and the presence of neural melanosis. Total excision aims to remove the entire nevus to reduce melanoma risk, though it may require multiple surgeries and techniques like tissue expansion or grafting. Regular monitoring is crucial. Follow-up should be every 6 months for the first 5 years and then annually. MRI scans may be needed to check for complications like leptomeningeal melanocytosis.

Clinical features of a dysplastic nevus include:

  • 6- to 15-mm size
  • Macular (flat)
  • Pigmentation with variable colour
  • indistinct margins

Other options:

Option A: 5-Fluorouracil cream is used in the treatment of low-risk basal cell carcinoma.

Option B: Interferon alfa-2a & Vincristine are used in the treatment of steroid-resistant hemangiomas.

question_title:
10.
        All of the following groups of drugs should be avoided in a diabetic patient on captopril to avoid hyperkalemia, except _______.
explanation:
Explanation

All of the following groups of drugs should be avoided in a diabetic patient on captopril to avoid hyperkalemia, except calcium channel blockers.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors like captopril may cause hyperkalemia when taken along with K+-sparing diuretics and beta-receptor blockers (option A), especially in diabetics. Calcium channel blockers are not associated with the development of any clinically significant hypo- or hyperkalemia. Hence, they are used as fixed-dose combinations as well.

Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys, leading to hyperkalemia.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include:

  • Hypotension
  • Cough
  • Angioedema
  • Teratogenicity
  • Dysgeusia (alteration in or loss of taste)

Other options

Option C: The most critical adverse effect of renal sodium channel inhibitors, such as amiloride and triamterene, is hyperkalemia. Triamterene may exacerbate megaloblastosis in cirrhotic patients due to its weak folic acid antagonism. It can also reduce glucose tolerance, induce photosensitization, and is linked to interstitial nephritis and renal stones. Common side effects of amiloride include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache, while triamterene is more frequently associated with nausea, vomiting, leg cramps, and dizziness.

Option D: The principal risk of aldosterone antagonists, such as eplerenone and finerenone, is hyperkalemia. They can cause metabolic acidosis in cirrhotic patients. Spironolactone is associated with side effects such as gynecomastia, impotence, and gastrointestinal issues like gastric bleeding, and peptic ulcers.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
11.
        The normal cardiac output curve is depicted in red in the image below. In which of the following conditions will a patients cardiac output curve be at point marked as B?
question_ADD:
1. Administration of spinal anesthesia.
  2. Opening an arteriovenous fistula.
  3. Thyrotoxicosis.
  4. Infusion of intravenous fluids
explanation:
Explanation

The point B depicted in the graph shows the eﬀect of sympathetic inhibition caused by the administration of spinal anesthesia (option A) which leads to decreased cardiac output and decreased venous return. 

Before anesthesia (Point A), systemic filling pressure (Psf) is at a normal level, supporting adequate venous return and cardiac output. After spinal anesthesia is administered, sympathetic activity is reduced, leading to vasodilation and a significant drop in Psf to about 4 mm Hg (Point B). This decrease in Psf results in reduced venous return to the heart, causing the cardiac output to fall to approximately 60% of its normal value. 

Other options:

Option B: Opening an arteriovenous fistula allows blood to flow from the large arteries into the venous system, bypassing resistance elements of the peripheral circulation. This results in increased venous return and cardiac output.

Option C: Thyrotoxicosis is characterized by an overactive thyroid gland leading to excessive production of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) which causes peripheral vasodilation. Vasodilation reduces systemic vascular resistance, which decreases the afterload on the heart. The heart can more efficiently eject blood into the systemic circulation, further increasing cardiac output.

Option D: Infusion of intravenous fluids increases blood volume and leads to compensatory effects such as increased capillary pressure, increased venous distention, and increased peripheral vascular resistance.
subject: Physiology

question_title:
12.
        A 40-year-old male who is a welder by profession came with complaints of dyspnoea, high-grade fever and rigors. He has bluish discolouration of peripheries and profuse sweating. He reports that his symptoms are often resurfacing at the beginning of every week and subsiding later. What could be the probable diagnosis of the patient?
explanation:
Explanation

The patient who is a welder by profession with the above-mentioned flu-like symptoms is likely to be suffering from Metal fume fever. 

Metal fume fever is a self-limited, influenza-like syndrome. It can also mimic malaria. It is most commonly associated with welders due to inhaling tiny metal oxide particles during welding. These particles, primarily zinc oxide but also cadmium and manganese oxides, can inflame the lungs. Symptoms mimic the flu, including fever, tiredness, breathing difficulties, cyanosis, myalgia, salivation and tachycardia.

Symptoms usually begin 6-8 hours after exposure to fumes and resolve within 24 hours of stoppage of exposure. it is usually mildest on Sundays and worst at the start of the workweek. Lab tests and chest X-rays are usually normal, except in severe cases. Teams of experts must recognize this as an occupational hazard and enforce safety measures like proper masks, ventilation, and work duration limits for welders.

Other Options:

Option A: Saturnism is a term given for chronic lead poisoning , symptoms include Anemia with basophilic stippling, Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums), Constipation and colic (abdominal pain), drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy, Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma), Facial pallor (Earliest sign).

 Option B: Hatter's shake is caused due to Hydrargyrism or mercury poisoning.  They are coarse jerky movements causing severe impairment of daily activities involving delicate movements like shaving, writing, and holding a tumbler or spoon.

Option C: Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs characteristic of chronic cocaine abuse. It is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to an itching sensation(formication, tactile hallucinations) with resultant excoriation, leading to irregular scratches and ulcers.

question_title:
13.
        A 14-year-old boy presented with jaundice, fever and mild splenomegaly. The patient is asked to get an Eosin-5’-maleimide (EMA) test which turns out to be positive. In this condition, what property of the red blood cells produces the graph (A) in the osmotic fragility curve?
question_ADD:
SA - Surface area 

V- Volume
optionA: A. Initial increase then decrease in SA/V ratio
optionD: D. Initial decrease then increase in SA/V ratio
explanation:
Explanation

In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of jaundice, fever and mild splenomegaly with a positive Eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test, point towards the diagnosis of Hereditary spherocytosis. This can be confirmed by the right shift seen in the osmotic fragility curve which occurs due to an increased V/SA ratio.

Osmotic fragility is the ability of red blood cells to resist hemolysis when placed in increasing dilutions of saline solution. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that have undergone hemolysis. Normal hemolysis begins at a concentration of 0.5% NaCl and is completed at a concentration of 0.3% NaCl as shown in the graph.

In Hereditary Spherocytosis, the osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased and they lyse more easily in a hypotonic solution than normal discoid RBCs due to the increased volume/surface area ratio. This is seen as a right shift in the osmotic fragility graph. Here hemolysis begins at a higher concentration of the saline solution. 

Decreased osmotic fragility indicates the presence of unusually flattened red cells (leptocytes) in which the RBCs have decreased volume/surface area ratio. Such changes occur in iron deficiency anaemia and thalassaemia in which the red cells with low mean cell haemoglobin (MCH) and mean cell volume (MCV) are unusually resistant to osmotic lysis. This is seen as a left shift in the osmotic fragility graph.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2 and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. Patients usually present with anaemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease.

The life span of affected red cells is decreased on average to 10 to 20 days from the normal 120 days.

The peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes which present as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor that is present in normal red blood cells.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test.  It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein.

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy.

question_title:
14.
        Considering the growing population of India, the government started categorizing various states based on their total fertility rate (TFR). Manipur with a TFR of 2.2 would be kept under ____?
explanation:
Explanation

The state of Manipur with a total fertility rate of 2.2 would be categorised under high focus.

The Government of India has categorized states according to total fertility rate (TFR) level into 3 categories.

  • Very high-focus (more than or equal to 3.0) states, it includes Bihar.
  • High-focus (more than 2.1 and less than 3.0) states, it includes states like Meghalaya, Manipur, and Uttar Pradesh.
  • Non-high focus (less than or equal to 2.1) states
subject: Community Medicine

question_title:
15.
        Match the following:
question_ADD:
Drug Important Adverse Effect
a. Valproate 1. Steven Johnson Syndrome
b. Lamotrigine 2. Visual field contraction
c. Felbamate 3. Fulminant hepatic failure
d. Vigabatrin 4. Pancreatitis
optionB:

question_title:
16.
        A young female patient came with complaints of joint pain, a butterfly-shaped rash on her face, fever, and weight loss. On investigation, ANA, anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive. Which of the following is the immunofluorescence pattern most likely to be associated with her condition?
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and Image A, which shows homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining, is the immunofluorescence pattern associated with it.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia accompanied by early morning stiffness. The other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

ANA, anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. Homogenous or diffuse staining and peripheral staining pattern are most commonly seen in SLE.

The image below shows the homogenous or diffuse immunofluorescence staining pattern seen in SLE:

Other options:

Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients present with dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary gland, respectively.

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are positive in Sjogren's syndrome. ANA and RF (rheumatoid factor) can also be seen. The centromeric pattern and speckled pattern of staining are seen in Sjogren's syndrome.

Image 1 below shows a speckled pattern, and image 2 shows a centromeric pattern of staining.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in fibrosis of the skin, vasculature, and internal organs. It is of two types, namely diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. 

Nucleolar pattern of ANA staining in immunofluorescence is most commonly seen in systemic sclerosis. A centromeric pattern is also seen.

The image below shows nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence seen in systemic sclerosis.

Pearl PM2173: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

question_title:
17.
        A 42-year-old male patient came to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with a vertebral fracture in the dorso lumbar region which was diagnosed by X-ray. Which of the following braces can be used to support the spine after spinal surgery?
explanation:
Explanation

The brace that can be used to support the spine after spinal surgery is Taylor brace.

After a spinal surgery, Taylor brace can be used to support sitting, standing, and walking after spinal surgery. Taylor brace is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

Other options : 

Option A: Milwaukee brace can be used for the management of Scoliosis and kyphosis. Also known as cervico-thoraco-lumbosacral orthosis or CTLSO, it is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. 

A picture depicting the same is shown below.

Option B: SOMI brace (sterno-occipital-mandibular immobilization device) is a rigid cervical brace that positions our neck with alignment to the spine. It can be used in conditions such as severe neck injury or for cervical pain caused by a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed as a recovery aid after Cervical spine surgery.

Option D: Boston brace (image below) is a mold brace and is the most commonly used brace nowadays for the treatment of scoliosis. It is a type of Thoracic - Lumbar - Sacral orthrosis(TLSO).

question_title:
18.
        In a town with a population of 5,00,000, the number of slides examined in one year was 2000. Out of these 250 slides were positive for malaria. The annual parasite incidence (API) is______
explanation:
Explanation

The annual parasite incidence based on the given data is 0.5.

Annual parasite incidence is a measure of malaria morbidity for a given year at any given geographical level. It helps in determining the burden of the disease. It is calculated as

API = Confirmed cases in one year / Population under surveillance × 1000

      = 250 / 500000 × 1000

      = 0.5

Areas with API>= 2 per 1000 population are classified as high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Pearl PM2084: Malarial parameters

Malarial parameters:

Parameter Formula
Annual Parasite Incidence

Confirmed cases in one year

-----------------------------------×1000
Population under surveillance
Annual Blood Examination Rate

Number of slides examined

-----------------------------------×100
      Population
Slide positivity Rate Percentage of slides found positive irrespective of species
Slide Falciparum Rate Percentage of slides positive for P. falciparum

 

Pearl PM1682: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.
subject: Community Medicine

question_title:
19.
        Which of the following uroflow patterns can be observed in a patient with urethral stricture ?
explanation:
Explanation

The second diagram depicts the uroflow pattern in a patient with urethral stricture. 

Uroflow pattern  Pathology
1 Reduced detrusor contractility
3 Normal flow pattern
4 Neurogenic bladder

 In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:

The common causes of urethral stricture are:
Inflammatory Traumatic Iatrogenic
Urethritis Bulbar urethral injury

 Urethral instrumentation including catheterization and transurethral prostatectomy
Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO) Pelvic fracture urethral disruption injury Radical prostatectomy
    Radiotherapy for prostate cancer

Clinical features include hesitancy of micturition, straining to void and a poor urinary stream. Diagnosis is made by uroflowmetry, urethroscopy, urethrography and ultrasound scanning. Retrograde cystourethrography is the investigation of choice.

The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of the stricture. They include:

  • Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigid urethroscope.
  • Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done. A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due to trauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment. 
  • Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure and it can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently.
  • Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergo urethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a daily basis.

In voiding cystourethrogram, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.
subject: Surgery

question_title:
20.
        A 30-year-old male who is a known case of ulcerative colitis presents with exacerbation of symptoms. His stool frequency suddenly increased to 10-12 times in the past 24 hours, with blood in stools. Investigations revealed a CRP of 60 mg/L. Which of the following is used to define the severity of this disease?
explanation:
Explanation

In the given clinical scenario, the patient presented with acute severe ulcerative colitis. Truelove-Witts criteria is used to define acute severe colitis.

Truelove-Witts criteria define acute severe colitis as the presence of:

  1. ≥ 6 bloody stools/24 hrs
  2. Plus, one or more of the following features suggestive of systemic toxicity:
    • Anemia (Hemoglobin <10 g/dL).
    • Mild fever (>100.04°F).
    • Tachycardia (Pulse ≥90 beats/min).
    • High inflammatory markers (ESR > 30 mm/hr or CRP >30 mg/L).

Other options :

Option B: The 2017 revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

Option C: The Montreal classification is used for classifying Crohn's disease.

Option D: The King's College Hospital Criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure (ALF).

question_title:
21.
        Which of the following are membrane bound, pattern recognition receptors (PRRs)?
explanation:
Explanation

The membrane-bound, pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) from the following option are Toll-like receptors(TLR).

TLRs are the membrane-bound Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). When pathogens breach the skin barrier, they encounter macrophages and other phagocytic cells equipped with specialized "microbial sensors." These sensors include TLRs, NOD-like receptors (NLRs), RIG-I-like helicases, and MDA-5. Among these, TLRs are a crucial part of the innate immune response. They are evolutionarily conserved PRRs that detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), which are unique to each pathogen and are essential molecular structures required for the pathogens' survival.

The PRRs are either localized on the cell surface to detect extracellular pathogens or within the endosomes and cellular matrix where they detect intracellular invading viruses. They are involved in activating pro-inflammatory signaling pathways, stimulating phagocytic responses (macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells), or binding to micro-organisms as secreted proteins.

Based on the localization and functional characteristics, PRRs are classified as

    • Membrane-bound PRRs
      • TLR
      • C-type lectin receptors (CLR)
    • Cytoplasmic (intracellular) PRRs
      • Nucleotide oligomerization (NOD) like receptors (NLR) – these include NODs (NOD1 and NOD2).
      • Retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) like receptors (RLR)
    • Secreted PRRs

Peptidoglycan recognition proteins (PGRPs) are a group of proteins that play a crucial role in the innate immune system by recognizing and binding to peptidoglycan, a major component of bacterial cell walls. Their levels often increase in response to bacterial presence, mediating immune responses.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
22.
        A 23-year-old G2P1 lady with a previous history of cesarean section was found to have placenta accreta on ultrasonography. Imperfect development of which layer leads to this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

Imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer, which is marked as 1 in the given image, leads to placenta accreta.

The other structures marked in the image are: 2 and 4 are cytotrophoblast and 3 is inner syncytiotrophoblast. 

Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is directly attached to the myometrium either partially or completely without any intervening decidua. This abnormal attachment to myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.

The definitive placenta consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows: 

Morbidly adherent placenta (MAP) occurs when the placenta fails to detach from the uterine wall and these include: 

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium
  • Placenta increta - villi invade the myometrium
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

The image given below shows different types of morbidly adherent placenta.

Risk factors for MAP include prior cesarean delivery, placenta previa, prior uterine surgeries like hysterotomy, prior curettage, and endometrial ablation.

Ultrasound imaging, color doppler, and MRI have all been helpful in the diagnosis of MAP during pregnancy.

Management:

  • Partial placenta accreta - placental tissue is removed and bleeding areas are oversewed.
  • Total placenta accreta - 
    • Parous women - hysterectomy is done 
    • If the patient desires to have a child - the umbilical cord is cut close to its base so that the placenta left behind gets autolyzed
  • If MAP invades the bladder, hysterectomy and partial cystectomy are required.
subject: Anatomy

question_title:
23.
        Pick out the incorrect statements regarding the 'RHIME' Model.
question_ADD:
1. RHIME model was introduced by the Central Administration and Sample Registration System (SRS) to record maternal deaths utilizing a verbal autopsy.
  2. RHIME stands for Representative, Re-sampled, Routine Household Interview of Mortality with Medical Evaluation. 
  3. It is usually conducted by the ASHA worker in her area.
  4. Information is collected in a form on the symptoms, signs, and key circumstances leading to death.
  5. After the information is collected, the assignment on the cause of death as per ICD-10 guidelines is done by a team of two general physicians together.
explanation:
Explanation

The incorrect statements are 3 and 5. 

The information is usually collected by the trained SRS field worker. This is not included in the roles and responsibilities of an ASHA worker. Also, after the information is collected, the assignment on the cause of death as per ICD-10 guidelines is done by two general physicians independently. If disagreements are noted between the two doctors, then the opinion of a third doctor is obtained. 

RHIME MODEL:

  • RHIME stands for Representative, Re-sampled, Routine Household Interview of Mortality with Medical Evaluation.
  • RHIME model was introduced by the Central Administration and Sample Registration System (SRS) to record maternal deaths utilizing a verbal autopsy.
  • Information is collected in a form on the symptoms, signs, and key circumstances leading to death.
  • The information is usually collected by the trained SRS field worker. 
  • After the information is collected, the assignment on the cause of death as per ICD-10 guidelines is done by two general physicians independently. If disagreements are noted between the two doctors, then the opinion of a third doctor is obtained. 
  • Web-based systems are developed for such studies.

Pearl PM1698: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Pearl PM0156: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months
subject: Community Medicine

question_title:
24.
        A 30-year-old G2P1L1 woman is 18 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labor was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. Which of the following measurements would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm.

Disproportion with respect to the maternal pelvis is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. The disparity in the relation between the head and the pelvis is called cephalopelvic disproportion.

It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis. A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm.
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:

        The following type of wound can be seen in all, except ?
explanation:
Explanation

The above image shows a stellate/ cruciate type of wound, which is seen in a contact shot, not in a close shot.

Close-shot wound features include wounds with the victim within a range of 5 to 8 cm, characterized by circular shapes with inverted edges. Notable signs include blackening and tattooing around the wound area. Additionally, there may be burning of hair, along with abrasion and the presence of a grease collar.

Other options:

Option A: Bursting of the skull is associated with a contact shot wound.  

Option B: Firearm exit wounds can be of various shapes, such as round, cruciate, stellate, elliptical, or crescent-shaped. Exit wounds of the head are usually star-shaped.

Option C: Contact shot features are :

  • An imprint of muzzle around the wound – Recoil abrasion.
  • Back spatter - Sucking of tissue, Cloth fibers, inside the barrel.
  • Pinkish-red discoloration due to CO.
  • Shape - Stellate, Cruciate, Elliptical.
  • Margins - everted.
  • Bursting fractures – In head wounds.
  • Cavitation - abdominal wounds.

question_title:
26.
        Which of the following is likely to be elicited from the history of a patient with the following ocular finding?
optionA: A. History of working with infrared radiation
optionB:
B. History of use of steroids
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD:
D. History of contact lens usage
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

The above lesion is a geographic ulcer, which represents corneal ulceration due to a worsened dendritic ulcer or reactivation of herpes simplex virus, commonly following history of immunosuppression and steroid usage.

Herpetic simplex keratitis, also known as herpetic keratoconjunctivitis and herpes viral keratitis, is a form of keratitis caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea.

The classic herpetic lesion consists of a linear branching corneal ulcer (dendritic ulcer). The ulcer is initially superficial and spreads in all directions as grey striae, which extend and increase in length. Patients with epithelial keratitis complain of foreign-body sensation, light sensitivity, redness, and blurred vision associated with focal or diffuse reduction in corneal sensation. Stromal keratitis manifests as a disc-shaped area of corneal edema. In patients who are immunocompromised due to pre-existing disease or using corticosteroids, the ulcer may become large; in such cases, the lesion is called a geographic ulcer.

Corneal ulcers can be detected with the help of fluorescein sodium dye and a cobalt-blue filter. The epithelial defect of the cornea appears opaque green with a cobalt blue filter. 

Treatment: Topical antivirals such as 1% Trifluorothymidine drops, 3% acyclovir ointment, 3% vidarabine ointment are the first-line treatment. Systemic antivirals in cases of increased severity or recurrence. Topical antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection

Pearl PM0710: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis
subject: Ophthalmology

question_title:
27.
        The instrument shown in the image is used for _______
optionA: A. Measuring the degree of heterophoria
optionC:
C. Refining the power and axis of cylindrical lens
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

The image shows an anomaloscope, which is used for testing colour vision.

An anomaloscope is based on a colour match. On one side, you have a yellow color which can be adjusted in brightness. The other side consists of a red and a green light whereas the proportion of mixture is variable.

Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique); used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens is shown below.

Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

Intraocular pressure is measured by tonometry.

question_title:
28.
        The complications associated with refeeding syndrome are:
question_ADD:
1. Hyperkalemia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypercalcemia
  4. Hypophosphatemia
explanation:
Explanation

Hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia, both occur in refeeding syndrome.

Options 1 and 3 are false as, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia (NOT hyper), are complications of refeeding syndrome.

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to:

  • Starvation
  • Alcoholism
  • Delayed nutritional support
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Massive weight loss in obese patients

With excessive refeeding, there is a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate which stimulates excessive insulin release. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium.

Hence the metabolic abnormalities include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypocalcemia

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

The condition may be prevented by instituting the caloric repletion slowly and gradually increasing it over the first week.

Pearl PM2166: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypoglycemia/hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

optionD:
D. Sign of Leser-Trelat-Carcinoid syndrome
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

Sign of Leser-Trelat is associated with gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma.

It is characterized by the sudden appearance or rapid increase in number and size of seborrheic keratoses, which are benign skin lesions. 

Necrolytic migratory erythema is a red, blistering and eroding skin lesions that form painful and itchy plaques. These are often associated with glucagonoma, a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that secretes excessive amounts of glucagon.

Pityriasis rotunda is commonly associated with hepatocellular carcinoma. It is characterized by discrete, round, scaly, pigmented patches.

Erythema gyratum repens is most frequently associated with lung cancer. It is characterized by figurate erythema commonly with concentric erythematous bands forming a wood-grain appearance.

question_title:
30.
        Assertion: Oral and Intravenous doses of Linezolid are the same.
Reason: Linezolid has 100% bioavailability.
optionA:
A. Both Assertion and Reasons are true and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. Both Assertion and Reasons are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
optionC: C. The assertion is true, but the Reasons is false
optionD: D. The assertion is false, but the Reasons is true
explanation:
Explanation

Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability is 100%. So, intravenous and oral doses for linezolid are the same. So, both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

Linezolid exhibits excellent oral bioavailability (100%) and can be taken with or without food, with no difference in dosing between oral and intravenous forms. Its half-life is approximately 4-6 hours and 30% protein bound, distributing widely to well-perfused tissues. The drug undergoes nonenzymatic oxidation to aminoethoxyacetic acid and hydroxyethyl glycine derivatives. About 80% of the administered dose appears in urine, while 10% is excreted via feces. No dose adjustment is necessary for renal insufficiency, although linezolid and its metabolites are dialyzable, requiring administration post-hemodialysis.

Linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including MRSA. Linezolid is associated with the side effects of myelosuppression( anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia) and serotonin syndrome due to monoamine oxidase(MAO) inhibition. Thrombocytopenia is the most common side effect.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
31.
        An elderly patient was started with metformin therapy for the newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, after 3 months, there was no significant decline in the HbA1c levels. The doctor decides to start injectable exenatide for this patient. This drug is an analogue of a hormone that is released in our gastrointestinal system. Which of the following will not be seen during this therapy?
optionD: D. Increased release of insulin from the pancreas
explanation:
Explanation

Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 analogue known to cause delayed gastric emptying.

 Glucagon-like peptides are derived from proglucagon and are secreted by intestinal L cells. They are released after the meals. Their main actions are

  • Stimulate insulin secretion leading to decreased blood sugar levels
  • Inhibit glucagon release
  • Delay gastric emptying
  • Decrease food intake leading to weight loss

These peptides are inactivated by dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4). 

Clinical correlate—GLP-1 receptor agonists have been used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus. They are exenatide, liraglutide, albiglutide, dulaglutide, lixisenatide, etc. Because they cause weight loss, they can be used in the management of diabetes in obese patients. Since they are peptide hormones, they are metabolised if given orally and must be given through a percutaneous route.

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, such as alogliptin, linagliptin, saxagliptin, sitagliptin, and vildagliptin, have also been used in the management of diabetes mellitus. These inhibitors increase the plasma concentrations of GLP-1 and its analogues.

question_title:
33.
        A 45-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. The patient is apprehensive about history of brain tumors and similar skin pathologies in the family. On examination he had scoliosis and Chest X ray  revealed bifid ribs. Which of the following  gene mutation can be expected in this patient?
explanation:
Explanation

The given family histories brain tumours, with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders suggestive basal cell carcinoma and association of bifid ribs and vertebral anomalies likely points to the diagnosis of Gorlin syndrome. Mutation of PTCH gene is seen in this condition.

Gorlin syndrome also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma  syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in the PTCH gene which codes for PATCHED protiens. In the absence of PATCHED proteins, there is unopposed Hedgehog signaling that increases the expression of a number of pro-growth genes. It is associated with a high risk of basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma.

Other features that can be seen associated are:

  • Highly characteristic facies (with large forehead)
  • Bifid or misshapen ribs
  • Vertebral and other skeletal anomalies (Scoliosis)
  • Pits of the skin of the palms and soles
  • Dysgenesis of the corpus callosum
  • Calcification of the falx cerebri (at an earlier age than is seen in non‐affected individuals)

Other options: 

Option A: Cowden syndrome/ Multiple hamartoma syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in PTEN gene. It is associated with hamartomas of all three embryonal cell layers and dysplastic gangliogliocytoma of the cerebellum. Most common harmartomas include facial trichilemmomas.

Option B: VHL gene  mutation is seen in von Hippel–Lindau syndrome which is associated with cerebellar hemangioblastoma, retinal angioma, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma and cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and inner ear (endolymphatic sac tumors).

Option C: Turcot syndrome is caused by mutations in APC gene or mismatch repair genes and is associated with intestinal polyposis and multiple CNS tumors like Medulloblastoma or glioblastoma.

question_title:
34.
        The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. The diagnostic test for this disease has a specificity of 0.80 and a sensitivity of 0.90. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
explanation:
Explanation

The negative predictive value of the above test is 95%.

For convenience, let us assume that the total population in this scenario is 100.

The prevalence of the disease is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30(TP+FN) and disease-free(FP+TN) is 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 90%.

The total true positives (TP) = 90/100 x (TP+FN) = 90/100 x 30 = 27

False-negative(FN) = 30-27 = 3

Since specificity is 0.80, i.e. TN/(FP+TN) = 80%.

Total true negatives (TN) =(FP+TN) x 80/100 = 70 x 80/100 = 56

False-positive(FP) = 70-56 = 14

The given data is represented below:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

27 (TP)

14 (FP)

41

Test -

3 (FN)

56 (TN)

59

Total

30(TP+FN)

70(FP+TN) 

100

Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%.

An alternate formula(Bayes theorem) that can be used is NPV = (1-P) x Sp /[P x (1-Sn)] +[(1-P) x Sp]

Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- Specificity

Pearl PM0358: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

question_title:
35.
         A patient presents with painless hematuria because of a worm that matures in the vesical venous plexus. Which of the following eggs are most likely to be seen in the urine analysis?
explanation:
Explanation

In the given clinical scenario, the presence of painless hematuria due to a worm maturing in the vesical venous plexus strongly suggests an infection with Schistosoma haematobium. This parasite is known for its distinct ovoid, non-operculated eggs, which have a brownish-yellow transparent shell and a characteristic terminal spine at one pole, as illustrated in Figure A.

Schistosoma haematobium is a parasitic worm and one of the species of trematodes, commonly known as blood flukes, that cause schistosomiasis. It is predominantly found in Africa and the Middle East. 

The transmission of Schistosoma haematobium involves several stages:

  • Cercariae Penetration: The infection begins when cercariae, the larval stage of the parasite, penetrates the skin of humans who are in contact with contaminated freshwater sources.
  • Migration: After skin penetration, the cercariae transform into schistosomula and travel through peripheral venules into the systemic circulation.
  • Maturation: The schistosomula eventually migrate to the vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, where they mature into adult worms and lay eggs.
  • They pass embryonated eggs in urine that hatch in water to release the free-living ciliated miracidia. Miracidia infects the liver of snails and produces first and second-generation sporocysts. Large numbers of cercariae are produced by asexual reproduction within the second-generation sporocysts and are released into the water. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes. 

Clinical Features:

  • Painless Hematuria: One of the hallmark symptoms due to the eggs causing inflammation in the bladder.
  • Urinary Symptoms: Frequent urination, dysuria (painful urination), and sometimes urinary tract infections.
  • Chronic Infection: Long-term infection can lead to bladder fibrosis, increased risk of urinary bladder cancer, and renal impairment.
  • Other Symptoms: Abdominal pain, fever, and occasionally systemic symptoms if the infection is severe.

Praziquantel is the treatment of choice for schistosomiasis, effectively targeting adult worms.

Other options:

Option B: Schistosoma mansoni eggs have a lateral spine near the posterior end. The adult stage of Schistosoma mansoni inhabits the inferior mesenteric veins of the large intestine.

Option C: Schistosoma japonicum eggs are large and rounded. The spine is smaller and less conspicuous. The adult worms live in the inferior and superior mesenteric veins of the small intestine.

Option D: The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained.

Given below are the images for the eggs mentioned above.

Pearl PM1765: Eggs in parasitology
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
36.
        A 70-year-old man who has prostate cancer is being treated with a long-acting GnRH agonist. After prolonged injection of GnRH, which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?
question_ADD:
↓-Low levels, ↑-High levels

Options FSH LH Testosterone
A ↓ ↓ ↑
B ↓ ↓ ↓
C ↑ ↑ ↑
D ↑ ↑ ↓
explanation:
Explanation

Prolonged injection of GnRH(gonadotropin-releasing hormone) will lead to decreased LH, FSH, and testosterone levels.

A constant administration of GnRH produces an initial agonistic action known as "flare", followed by downregulation of GnRH receptors ( decrease in GnRH receptor concentration). This desensitizes the pituitary to the action of GnRH and a hypogonadotropic-hypogonadal state is induced. This is characterized by low LH (luteinizing hormone) and FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) levels, thereby reducing testosterone production (i.e., chemical castration).

The regulation of gonadotropin secretion by the hypothalamus involves the pulsatile release of GnRH. GnRH is secreted in pulses lasting between 5 to 25 minutes at 1 to 2 hours intervals. This intermittent release is crucial for stimulating the anterior pituitary gland to secrete LH and FSH. Continuous infusion of GnRH, in contrast, leads to the downregulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary, resulting in reduced secretion of LH and FSH.

In the treatment of prostate cancer, which is driven by the carcinogenic effects of testosterone, continuous infusion of GnRH agonists is used. This treatment effectively suppresses testosterone levels by downregulating GnRH receptors, thereby reducing the stimulation of LH and FSH. In the case of a 70-year-old man undergoing long-term GnRH agonist therapy for prostate cancer, the expected outcome would be decreased levels of FSH, LH, and testosterone due to the prolonged suppression of GnRH signaling.
subject: Physiology

question_title:
37.
        A patient with a history of schizophrenia presents to the clinic with complaints of new-onset tremors, muscle rigidity, and bradykinesia. He recently had a change in his antipsychotic medication. Which of the following medications can be prescribed to avoid the current complication?
question_ADD:
1. Clozapine
  2. Quetiapine
  3. Chlorpromazine
  4. Loxapine
  5. Aripiprazole
explanation:
Explanation

The complaints of new-onset tremors, muscle rigidity, and bradykinesia suggest extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) from the recent medication change; therefore Clozapine, quetiapine, and aripiprazole are the best alternatives that do not show EPS as a major side effect.

  • Clozapine: An atypical antipsychotic with a very low incidence of EPS.
  • Quetiapine: Another atypical antipsychotic with a favourable EPS profile.
  • Aripiprazole: A third-generation antipsychotic (also known as a dopamine partial agonist) that has a low risk of EPS and can be considered a good alternative.

Chlorpromazine and loxapine are typical antipsychotics that are more likely to cause EPS. Chlorpromazine, while sometimes used for its sedative properties, still carries a significant risk of EPS. Haloperidol is well-known for its high propensity to induce EPS and is not an appropriate alternative in this scenario.
subject: Psychiatry

question_title:
38.
        An immunocompromised patient receiving total parenteral nutrition through a central venous catheter has had high-grade fever for 1 week. 2D Echo shows vegetations on the mitral valve. Blood cultures are negative for bacterial growth after 72 hours. Empiric antibiotic therapy has not shown improvements in his condition. What is the likely causative organism?
explanation:
Explanation

In this immunocompromised patient with a central venous catheter (CVC), presenting with high-grade fever, mitral valve vegetations, and negative blood cultures after 72 hours, likely suggests a diagnosis of infective endocarditis, with the causative organism being Candida albicans. The absence of bacterial growth and lack of improvement with broad-spectrum antibiotics suggest fungal aetiology, and Candida species are known to cause infections in such scenarios.

For patients with a CVC, common pathogens include skin flora like Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis, as well as Candida species. While Staphylococcus infections typically show up on blood cultures, Candida infections may not always be detected this way, especially in the context of systemic candidiasis. Candida should be suspected when cultures are negative, and symptoms persist despite antibiotic therapy.

Candida albicans is a frequent cause of opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients, including candidal endocarditis. It can lead to systemic infections where traditional cultures might be negative. Candida infections are diagnosed based on clinical presentation, lack of bacterial growth on cultures, and response to antifungal treatment.

Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (Shown in the image below). It appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Candida albicans form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus rarely causes infective endocarditis and is more commonly associated with invasive fungal infections, such as aspergillosis, which primarily affect the lungs but can disseminate to other organs, including the heart.

Option C: Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella species—are known causes of endocarditis, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions. They are often identified in cultures but usually present with a more subacute or chronic course. 

Option D: Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative staphylococcus, is a common skin flora and often a cause of infections related to indwelling devices. It can cause endocarditis, particularly in patients with prosthetic valves or CVCs. However, their infections usually produce positive blood cultures, and the negative cultures here suggest a fungal rather than bacterial cause.
subject: Medicine

question_title:
39.
        An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring the disinfection of wells in a city to reduce the spread of water-borne illnesses. 30 grams of bleaching powder was required to disinfect 2275 liters of well water. When measuring the chlorine demand with the Horrocks apparatus for this well water, which cup would have shown the blue color after adding the indicator?
explanation:
Explanation

Horrocks apparatus used to measure chlorine demand of water. The 3rd cup would have shown a blue color for it to require 30 grams of bleaching powder to disinfect 2275 liters of well water.

Since 2275/455=5, the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is 30/5=6 grams

To calculate the dose of bleaching required to disinfect 455 liters of water, the formula is (n×2), We know the dose required, and we have to calculate 'n' (n represents the position of the cup which was first to show the color).

6=n×2, therefore n=3.

The third cup would have turned blue upon adding the indicator.

Pearl PM1610: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.
subject: Community Medicine

question_title:
40.
        Which of the following statements are true regarding errors of amino acid metabolism?
question_ADD:
1. Hartnup disease - defect in the intestinal and renal transport of tryptophan
  2. Maple syrup urine disease - defective branched chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex
  3. Alkaptonuria - defective homogentisate oxidase 
  4. Albinism - defective tyrosinase
explanation:
Explanation

All of the given statements are true. 

A defect in the intestinal and renal transport of amino acid tryptophan leads to Hartnup disease. The defect would lead to tryptophan deficiency and therefore affect niacin biosynthesis. Therefore symptoms similar to pellagra - dermatitis, diarrhea and dementia (3D's) are seen in Hartnup disease.

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDH). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine, and alloisoleucine. The peculiar burnt sugar odor of urine is characteristic of this disease.

Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of an enzyme homogentisate oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue resulting in ochronosis. Due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogenetic acid, it shows a characteristic blackening of urine on standing for a long time or black stain in diapers. They often present in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Albinism is due to a deficiency of copper-containing enzyme tyrosinase causing a defect in melanin production. The affected child has milky white hair and milky white skin.

question_title:
41.
        Which of the following is not true about the Typbar vaccine?
optionA: A. It is a conjugate vaccine, conjugated to tetanus toxoid
optionB: B.  It is a single IM dose recommended for infants > 6m till < 45 years of age
optionC: C. Effect lasts up to 2 years across all age groups
optionD:
D. Co-administration with MR causes serological interference 
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

Typbar TCV is safe and compatible due to which its co-administration with MCV/MMR does not cause serological interference.

Typbar is a conjugate vaccine for typhoid by Bharat Biotech. 

It contains Vi capsular polysaccharide of salmonella typhi Ty2 which is conjugated with a protein carrier viz tetanus toxoid, providing a foreign peptide protein that increases immunogenicity.  It is not the part of national immunization schedule and is recommended as a single intramuscular dose of 0.5 ml in infants >6 months and adults < equal to 45 years in typhoid endemic areas. It causes 4-fold seroconversion across all age groups. It is the only vaccine available for children < 2 years of age. It has a high avidity, especially IgG mediated which increases the strength of binding between antibody and antigen. This activity persists till 2 years of age. 
A booster dose may be given after 3 years.

question_title:
43.
        Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
optionD: D. Sclerotic type of hypermature cataract
explanation:
Explanation

The given image shows the characteristic appearance of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian hypermature cataract is characterized by the liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile Cataract

Types:

  • Cortical (soft cataract): 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract): 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataract

  • Pigmented nuclear cataracts: Due to the deposition of urochrome pigment
    • Catarata brunescens
    • Catarata nigra
    • Catarata rubra

Pearl PM0875: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.
