question_title:
44.
        A primigravida patient has come for a routine antenatal checkup. Which among the following findings in her would you not consider a physiological change?
question_ADD:
1. Exaggerated splitting of S2
  2. Left axis deviation on ECG
  3. Fourth heart sound
  4. Loud third heart sound (S3)
  5. Grade 2 diastolic murmur
explanation:
Explanation

The findings among the given options that are not considered a part of the physiological changes in pregnancy are the exaggerated splitting of S2, fourth heart sound and grade 2 diastolic murmur.

During pregnancy, the presence of a fourth heart sound(S4) (Statement 3) and a diastolic murmur (Statement 5) is considered a clinical indicator of heart disease during pregnancy.

Physiological changes in the cardiovascular system in pregnancy:

  1. Exaggerated splitting of S1 and increased loudness of both components.
  2. Loud, easily heard third heart sound (S3).
  3. A sys­tolic murmur that intensifies on inspiration or expiration.
  4. Soft diastolic murmur.
  5. Mammary souffle- continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space.
  6. A shift of the cardiac apex laterally.
  7. ECG changes: 
    • Left axis deviation.
    • Q waves in leads 2, 3, and avF.
    • Flat or inverted T waves in lead 3, V1-V3.
  8. Increased cardiac output, heart rate, and ejection fraction.
  9. Decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

Clinical indicators of heart disease during pregnancy:

Symptoms:

  • Progressive dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Chest pain 

Clinical signs:

  1. Cyanosis
  2. Clubbing of fingers
  3. Persistent neck vein distention
  4. Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
  5. Diastolic murmur of any grade
  6. Cardiomegaly
  7. Persistent tachycardia and/or arrhythmia
  8. Persistently split S2
  9. Fourth heart sound (S4)
  10. Features of pulmonary hypertension

Pearl PM1815: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
45.
        A 56-year-old male patient with a history of diabetes mellitus was diagnosed with major depression. He attempted suicide by consuming a bottle of glipizide tablets. What is the antidote of choice for this case?
explanation:
Explanation

The antidote of choice for the above case scenario suggestive of sulfonylurea overdose (glipizide belongs to the sulfonylurea group) which resulted in severe hypoglycemia is octreotide.

Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue. It inhibits the secretion of growth hormone. It binds to somatostatin-2 receptors on pancreatic beta cells and blocks the Ca2+ influx resulting in a decrease in insulin secretion. Hence, it can be used to correct the hypoglycemia caused by sulfonylurea. overdose.

Other uses of octreotide:

  • Acromegaly
  • Esophageal varices
  • Thyrotrope adenomas
  • Carcinoid tumors
  • Adenomas secreting VIP(watery diarrhea)
  • Diagnostic imaging of neuroendocrine tumors
  • Sulfonylurea toxicity

Adverse effects: 

  • Injection site pain
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Gallstones

Other options: 

Option A: Glucagon can rectify hypoglycemia by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. However, it is not routinely administered as it can stimulate insulin release and is not useful in glycogen-depleted patients.

Option C: Intravenous dextrose is not given because when administered it creates a hyperglycemic state thus stimulating insulin release, causing hypoglycemia again.

Option D: Leucovorin (folinic acid) is the antidote of choice for methotrexate overdose.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
46.
        Which of the following statements is incorrect about the tissue shown in the image below?
optionA: A. Extracellular calcium is needed for contraction
optionB: B. Branching of fibers is typically seen
optionC:
C. Gap junctions are not found in intercalated discs
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The above image shows a longitudinal section of the cardiac muscle stained by hematoxylin and eosin. The incorrect statement is that "gap junctions are absent," as they are essential for allowing rapid electrical communication between cardiac cells, which ensures coordinated heart contraction.

On microscopy, cardiac muscle can be identified by:

  1. The junctions between adjoining cardiac myocytes are seen as dark staining transverse lines running across the muscle fiber. These lines are called intercalated discs.
  2. Presence of striations similar to the skeletal muscle.
  3. Presence of single and centrally placed nucleus. A perinuclear halo may be seen surrounding the nucleus.
  4. Cells within one fiber branch and join the cells in adjacent fibers. 

Intercalated discs are unique to cardiac muscle, featuring transverse lines that cross fibers at irregular intervals where myocardial cells connect. These discs contain desmosomes and fascia adherens junctions in their transverse regions, providing strong cell adhesion during contractions. The less common longitudinal regions of intercalated discs contain gap junctions, which allow for rapid electrical communication between cells, ensuring synchronized contractions. Cardiac muscle cells also have a high mitochondrial density, store fatty acids as triglycerides, and may contain glycogen granules and lipofuscin pigment.

Other options 

Option A: Cardiac muscle contraction depends on extracellular calcium and calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum for contraction.

Option B: Cardiac muscle shows branching of muscle fibers.

Option C: Cardiac muscles contain abundant sarcoplasmic reticulum as a source of intracellular calcium.

question_title:
47.
        Name the type of skull fracture.
explanation:
Explanation

The image shows hinge fracture.

Here base of skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge.

Types of hinge fracture:

Type I: Sideway impact on middle cranial fossa known as motorcyclist fracture. The fracture line reaches the opposite side through Sella tursica.
Type II: Posterior impact Fracture line from posterior to anterior cranial fossa.
Type III: Sideway impact on anterior cranial fossa Fracture in anterior cranial fossa.

 

Pearl PM0822: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.
subject: Forensic Medicine

question_title:
48.
         In a patient with lung disease in late stage of  sarcoidosis, which of the following would be most likely?
question_ADD:
DLCO: Diffusing capacity of lung for carbon monoxide

A-a gradient: Alveolar-arterial gradient
optionA: A. Increased DLCO, Increased A-a gradient
optionB:
B. Increased DLCO, Decreased A-a gradient
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionC: C. Decreased DLCO, Decreased A-a gradient
optionD:
D. Decreased DLCO, Increased A-a gradient
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

In patients with late stage of sarcoidosis, lung involvement is due to interstitial lung disease which is characterized by the decreased diffusing capacity of lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) and increased alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient.

The most common cause of granulomatous interstitial lung disease is sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that most commonly involves the lungs. Interstitial lung disease is characterized by decreased DLCO and increased A-a gradient.

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show:

  • Reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC (Restrictive)
  • FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or increased
  • Reduction in DLCO due to a decrease in diffusion capacity
  • Normal PAO2 (Alveolar O2) and decreased PaO2 (arterial), causing an increased alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient. 

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause.

question_title:
49.
        Which of the following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency?
explanation:
Explanation

The Darrow Yannet diagram shown in image 4 depicts adrenal insufficiency. In adrenal insufficiency, there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction.

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Adrenal insufficiency is characterized by aldosterone deficiency which leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid). This results in:

  • The osmolarity of extra-cellular fluid (ECF) decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into the intracellular fluid (ICF). As a result, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction.

The image given below shows Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions:

Diagram 1 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 2 - The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

Diagram 3 - SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate secretion of anti-diuretic hormone) is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Diagram 4 - Adrenal insufficiency is associated with hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Pearl PM0460: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialised compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. It constitutes <1% of TBW (1-2L).
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

question_title:
50.
        A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple episodes of seizure which could not be controlled with multiple drugs. A diagnosis of  Lennox–Gastaut syndrome is made. What is the characteristic electroencephalogram finding will you expect?
optionA: A. 4-5 Hz spike and a slow background in wakefulness
optionB:
B. 1-2 Hz spike and slow wave and polyspike bursts in sleep
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionC: C. 3 Hz spike and slow-wave with a fast background in wakefulness
optionD:
D. Hypsarrhythmia and a slow background in wakefulness
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness is the characteristic electroencephalogram findings in Lennox–Gastaut syndrome.

A child with developmental delay, intractable seizures with an electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike, and polyspike bursts in sleep are suggestive of the diagnosis of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome. It typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. Consists of a triad of

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
  • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

question_title:
52.
        A 6-year-old boy was brought to the orthopedic department with pain and swelling in the right thigh for a few weeks. X-ray of the right femur showed a lesion as shown below.  Biopsy from the lesion showed small blue tumor cells which are PAS-positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation:
Explanation

A clinical scenario of a 6-year-old boy with painful swelling in his thigh and an X-ray showing onion skin periosteal reaction with biopsy demonstrating PAS-positive cells is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma.

Ewing sarcoma is the second most common non-hematologic primary bone malignancy in patients younger than 30 years. They are commonly seen in young patients aged 5 to 25 years and predominantly in males.

They commonly occur in the metaphysis of long bones which extend into diaphysis too. Most of the patients present with pain that is insidious in onset. Fever, swelling, and erythema may also be present. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP.

Radiological examination shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones with onion skin periosteal reaction.

Cytogenetic examination of showing t(11:22)(q24:q12)is the most common translocation diagnostic of Ewing's sarcoma.

Histology shows small blue round tumor cells that are PAS-positive, as tumor cells are rich in glycogen. However, they stain negatively for reticulin.

The image given below shows PAS staining done in Ewing's sarcoma.

Note: Lymphomas are PAS negative and reticulin positive.

Ewing sarcoma is radiosensitive. Large unresectable tumors are treated with radiation while small resectable tumors are more likely to be treated with surgery. Treatment always includes adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. 

Histologic grade doesn't have any prognostic significance since all Ewing sarcoma are considered as high grade.

Poor prognostic factors of Ewing sarcoma :

  • Distant metastases
  • Size of the primary lesion
  • Fever, anemia
  • Elevated WBC count, ESR, and LDH
  • Age between 12- 15 years

Other options:

Option B: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. It has a bimodal age distribution- at adolescence and in the seventh decade. It is typically seen in metaphyseal regions of the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. 

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Option C: Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumor occurring mainly in long bones. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumor. On histology presence of "chicken wire calcification" is pathognomic.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

Option D: Chondrosarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It can present between the 3rd-8th decade of life. They are slow-growing tumors that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone-derived from enchondral ossification. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumors with irregular granular calcifications giving a 'honeycomb' or 'popcorn' appearance. CT and MRI are useful in the diagnosis. Chondrosarcoma is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation. Surgical excision is the only treatment.

The below radiograph shows popcorn calcification in chondrosarcoma.

  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Lymphoma

Radioresistant tumors:

  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Chondrosarcoma
  3. Fibrosarcoma
  4. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

question_title:
53.
        A patient presents with fever associated with rigor and chills for 1 week, with abdominal distension and loss of appetite. On examination, there is marked hepato-splenomegaly. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but rk39 is positive. A sample from which of the following sites is the most sensitive to demonstrate the presence of the causative organism?
explanation:
Explanation

In the given clinical vignette of a patient with fever, rigor, chills, abdominal distension, and marked hepatosplenomegaly, alongside a positive rk39 test, the presentation is highly suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). The most sensitive diagnostic method for detecting the causative organism is splenic aspirate, which has a positive detection rate of up to 98%.

Splenic aspiration is highly effective because it directly samples the site of infection. However, it is not routinely performed due to significant risks, such as haemorrhage, particularly in patients with advanced disease where the spleen is markedly enlarged and soft.

Kala-azar is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sand flies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host. It lowers immunity and causes persistent fever, anaemia, and hepatosplenomegaly, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms, the promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and the amastigote form (as shown below) multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

Diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis includes the rK39 rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test, as recommended by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India. Parasitological confirmation is achieved by demonstrating LD bodies in a buffy coat smear. The aldehyde test of Napier is used for surveillance, while serological tests like rapid dipstick, direct agglutination test, ELISA, and indirect fluorescent antibody test aid in diagnosis. The Leishmanin (Montenegro) test is useful for identifying endemicity and immune response, though it is typically positive 4-6 weeks after cutaneous leishmaniasis onset. The gold standard for diagnosing kala-azar is the microscopic demonstration of amastigotes in bone marrow, generally obtained by aspirating the sternal marrow (as shown below). Other samples may include peripheral blood, splenic aspirate, and enlarged lymph nodes.

Treatment for visceral leishmaniasis typically includes medications such as sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin B. In India, liposomal amphotericin is the first-line treatment, administered as a single intravenous dose of 10 mg/kg. This regimen is preferred due to its efficacy and safety profile, providing a robust option for managing this serious and life-threatening parasitic disease.

Pearl PM1757: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

question_title:
54.
        Which one of the following is a provision under the PPTCT (Prevention of Parent-to-Child Transmission) program for HIV?
optionA: A. Home births with HIV-infected mothers being counseled on safe birthing practices
optionB: B. Lifelong ART administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women with CD4 count of less than 500/mm3
optionC:
C. Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD:
D. Syrup Nevirapine and syrup Zidovudine from birth till 6 weeks for all infants of HIV positive mothers
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

The PPTCT (Prevention of Parent-to-Child Transmission) program includes the crucial provision of plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation (Option C) to determine the risk of HIV transmission from mother to baby. This testing is essential for assessing the level of HIV in the mother's blood, allowing healthcare providers to tailor interventions to reduce transmission risk, such as adjusting antiretroviral therapy (ART) or scheduling a cesarean delivery.

Other options:

Option A: The PPTCT program emphasizes institutional deliveries for HIV-infected mothers to provide better management and immediate medical care, which is not feasible with home births.

Option B: Lifelong ART is administered to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of their CD4 count and clinical stage, ensuring comprehensive care and reducing the risk of transmission.

Option D: The initiation of ARV in babies is differentiated based on the risk level. Low-risk infants receive only Syrup Nevirapine, while high-risk infants receive both Syrup Nevirapine and Syrup Zidovudine, with the duration varying based on feeding practices.

Pearl PM2199: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines
subject: Community Medicine

question_title:
55.
        A tonsillectomy is being performed by a first-year resident. The senior resident warned him to limit his dissection to a certain anatomical limit. What limit is he referring to?
explanation:
Explanation

In this given scenario, the senior resident's warning to limit dissection during a tonsillectomy typically refers to pharyngobasilar fascia to avoid damage to the superior constrictor muscle, which has a rich blood supply. 

The structures forming the tonsillar bed from within outward are 

  1. Pharyngobasilar Fascia
  2. Superior Constrictor
  3. Buccopharyngeal Fascia
  4. Styloglossus
  5. Glossopharyngeal Nerve
  6. Facial Artery

 


Enlarged and infected tonsils often require surgical removal. The operation is called tonsillectomy. 

Absolute indications for tonsillectomy are

  1. Recurrent infections of the throat: 
    • ≥7 episodes in 1 year,
    • ≥5 episodes/year in 2 years,
    • ≥ 3 episodes/year in 3 years, or
    • ≥ 2 weeks of absence from school or work in 1 year
  2. Peritonsillar abscess (1 episode in a child or 2 episodes in adults)
  3. Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures
  4. Hypertrophy of the tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, or interference with speech
  5. Suspicion of malignancy

The relative indications are:

  • Diphtheria carriers who have not responded to antibiotics
  • Streptococcal carriers who may be a source of infection for others
  • Chronic tonsillitis with halitosis unresponsive to medical treatment
  • Patient with valvular heart disease having recurrent streptococcal tonsillitis

It is also indicated as a part of other procedures like palato- pharyngoplasty, glossopharyngeal neurectomy, removal of the styloid process.

Contraindications:

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10g%
  • Presence of acute infection like acute tonsillitis due to increased incidence of bleeding during infection
  • Children under 3 years of age due to poor surgical risk
  • Cleft palate
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease (diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension, asthma
  • During menses
subject: ENT

question_title:
56.
        A 46-year-old man came to your PHC with a history of transient painless genital ulcer. On examination, the inguinal region had painful and fluctuant swellings, as seen in the image below.  What is the best management option?
optionA:
A. Start on black STD kit only and advise follow-up for 21 days
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionB: B. Incision and drainage at your PHC
optionC:
C. Refer to a higher centre for aspiration
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Start on white STD kit only and advise follow-up for 14 days
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) with fluctuation. If an inguinal bubo turns fluctuant, the most appropriate step should be a referral to a higher centre for aspiration.

Lymphogranuloma venerum affects sexually active adults. The organism spreads from the site of the initial lesion to the regional lymph nodes, causing lymphangitis. There is infiltration of polymorphonuclear lymphocytes and plasma cells. The necrotic areas coalesce and enlarge to form a stellate abscess. Patients present with genital ulceration, rectal bleeding, and lymphadenopathy. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3.

There are three stages of the disease: 

  • Primary: the incubation period is 3–30 days. The genital lesions may be painful or painless. The patient usually presents with symptoms of hemorrhagic proctitis. The condition is common among homosexuals.
  • Secondary: It may take days to weeks for the disease to manifest. It is characterised by tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy (groove sign). The lymph nodes coalesce to form painful buboes which rupture and form fistulae and sinus tracts.
  • Tertiary: genito-anorectal syndrome is seen. This occurs years after untreated primary infection.  There is lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This results in genital lymphoedema and inflammation which causes ulceration and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, resulting in esthiomene in women and elephantiasis in men. NACO kit 7 (black) is used for management. It includes a tab. Azithromycin 1 gm (OD - Stat) and tab. Doxycycline 100 mg (BD for 21 days).

For patients who are diagnosed with inguinal bubo syndrome, all partners for the past 3 weeks are treated. Follow up on the 7th, 14th, and 21st days for Inguinal Bubos (IB).

An incision and drainage should never be done for an inguinal bubo, if turns fluctuant, the most appropriate step should be a referral to a higher centre for aspiration.

Pearl PM2024: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

question_title:
57.
        An 8 month old male child presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, and seizures. He has hepatosplenomegaly on examination. His urine has a chlorinated smell, labs reveal 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and severe metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?
optionA:
A. Low protein diet and vitamin C supplementation
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. High protein diet and vitamin C supplementation
optionC:
C. Low protein diet and vitamin B6 supplementation
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionD: D. High protein diet and vitamin B6 supplementation
explanation:
Explanation

This patient has Hawkinsinuria based on clinical features, characteristic “chlorinated/swimming pool odour” and lab results with metabolites present in urine. Treatment consists of a low-protein diet/low-tyrosine diet during infancy. A trial with large doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hr) is also recommended. and breastfeeding is encouraged. 

It is an autosomal dominant trait, caused due to certain missense mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD. (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase) Hawkinsin, a cyclic amino acid that is also excreted in the urine. Clinical features include severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, and hepatomegaly. Mental development is usually normal. Symptomatic infants, asymptomatic affected children and adults excrete hawkinsin, 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid, and its metabolites (4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenyl acetic acids), 4-hydroxycyclohexylacetic acid and 5-oxoproline in their urine. The plasma tyrosine level may also be elevated in symptomatic infants. The management of hawkinsinuria consists of a low-tyrosine diet and vitamin C supplementation. A low-tyrosine diet is necessary to reduce the amount of 4-HPP that is produced. Vitamin C supplementation helps to prevent the oxidation of 4-HPP and HGA.

Other options:

Option A: A high protein diet would worsen the symptoms of hawkinsinuria.

Options C and D: B6 supplementation is neither necessary nor beneficial for hawkinsinuria.

question_title:
58.
        A 27-year-old pregnant woman presents with a five-day history of fever, malaise, and symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. She also reports pain in the costovertebral angle but has no history of similar episodes. Urinalysis reveals the presence of pus casts. All of the following statements about her condition are true except:
optionA:
A. Intratubular aggregates of neutrophils
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionB:
B. Thyroidization of the tubules
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The clinical stem suggests acute pyelonephritis. Thyroidization of tubules is a feature of chronic pyelonephritis not acute.

Points that favor the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis are:

  • systemic symptoms like fever and malaise for the past 5 days
  • increased urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria
  • pain in the costovertebral angle
  • urine routine showing pus casts 

Suppurative inflammation of the kidney caused by a bacterial and viral infection, which can reach the kidney by hematogenous spread or, more commonly, through the ureters in association with vesicoureteral reflux is known as acute pyelonephritis.

Acute pyelonephritis is associated with urinary tract obstruction (congenital or acquired), instrumentation of the urinary tract (catheterization), vesicoureteral reflux, pregnancy, diabetes, preexisting renal lesions, and immunosuppression. Infections are much more frequent in females. However, with increasing age, the incidence in males rises as a result of prostatic hypertrophy.

Histopathological features of acute pyelonephritis are patchy interstitial suppurative inflammation, intratubular aggregates of neutrophils, neutrophilic tubulitis, and tubular injury.

Complications of acute pyelonephritis:

  • Papillary necrosis- is mainly seen in diabetics, sickle cell disease, and urinary tract obstruction. It is usually bilateral. Areas of grey-white to yellow necrosis are seen at the tips or distal two-thirds of the pyramids. The necrotic tissue shows characteristic ischemic coagulative necrosis, with preservation of outlines of tubules
  • Pyonephrosis occurs when the suppurative exudate is unable to drain and fills the renal pelvis, calyces, and ureter with pus. This is seen when there is total or almost complete obstruction of the renal pelvis. 
  • Perinephric abscess is an extension of suppurative inflammation into the perinephric tissue.

Treatment: Uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis is mild, and symptoms disappear within a few days after appropriate antibiotic therapy is initiated.

Chronic pyelonephritis is a disorder in which there is chronic tubulointerstitial inflammation and scarring of the calyces and pelvis. Patients have a silent onset or present with manifestations of acute recurrent pyelonephritis, such as back pain, fever, pyuria, and bacteriuria. The hallmarks features include coarse, discrete, corticomedullary scars overlying dilated, blunted, or deformed calyces, and flattening of the papillae.

The microscopic changes involve predominantly tubules and interstitium. The tubules show atrophy and hypertrophy or dilation. Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). 

Pearl PM2212: Risk Factors of UTI

Risk Factors for Urinary Tract Infection

  • Male infants (UTI is Males>females during infancy alone)

Structural factors - Any anatomical hindrance to drainage

question_title:
59.
        A patient was diagnosed with pseudohemoptysis. He was informed that the color of the sputum is due to a pigment produced by a microorganism. Which of the following pigments is responsible for this?
explanation:
Explanation

Pseudohemoptysis is most commonly caused by Serratia marcescens due to the red pigment called prodigiosin.

Serratia marcescens is a pleomorphic coccobacilli. It may grow in sputum after collection. They may mimic hemoptysis (pseudo hemoptysis) because they produce a non-diffusible red pigment called prodigiosin.

S. marcescens contaminate intravenous fluids, surgical instruments, and antiseptic solutions. Therefore, they are one of the important causes of healthcare-associated infections.

Other options:

Pyocyanin(option A) (bluish-green pigment), pyorubin(option B) (red pigment) and pyomelanin(option C) (brown pigment) are pigments produced by Pseudomonas species.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
60.
        Which of the following is true regarding the enzyme kinetics of the patient in the graph shown below?
optionA: A. There is a decrease in the rate of enzyme synthesis
optionB: B. There is a mutation that decreases the Vmax of the enzyme
optionC:
C. There is a mutation that increases the Km of the enzyme
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. There is a non-competitive antagonist administered
explanation:
Explanation

The curve representing the patient’s enzyme kinetics in the given graph shows that the Km is increased and Vmax remains the same This graph is possible either because of a mutation that increases the Km of the enzyme or if a competitive inhibitor is administered (Option D). Km is the substrate concentration at which velocity is half of its maximum velocity. Vmax is the maximum velocity of a reaction. 

Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to the active site of the enzyme and physically impedes substrate binding. This inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration. More substrate is required to reach half the maximum velocity. Therefore, in competitive inhibition, there is an increase in the Km of the enzyme while the Vmax remains the same (similar to the graph shown). 

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases since non-competitive inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration. However, since it does not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme, the Km remains constant.

Binds via non-covalent interaction

Binds via covalent interactions

No chemical change

Inhibitor binds to the substrate & prevent catalytic activity of enzymes

Can be reversed, as there is no bonding between the inhibitor & substrate

Irreversibility due to strong covalent bonding

question_title:
62.
        A 60-year-old male patient underwent gastric resection surgery for a gastrointestinal malignancy. Following the gastric resection, two Portex tube drains were placed- one in the Morrison's pouch and the other in the region of the gastrojejunostomy. Identify the true statements about the suture material used for securing the drains externally.
question_ADD:
1. It can be used for vascular prosthesis
  2. Increased risk of infection and tissue reaction
  3. Can be used for routine skin closure
  4. Gets absorbed over 1-2 years
  5. Encapsulation in fibrous tissue over 2-3 weeks
explanation:
Explanation

The suture material used to secure abdominal drains is silk. It is black-colored, multifilament, braided, and is derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva.

Silk is unsuitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. There is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction, so they are not used for routine skin closure. It can be used to secure drains externally. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It is shown in the image below:

Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

Pearl PM1242: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

64.
        Which of the following is incorrect regarding the needle shown below and the procedure it is used for?
optionA: A. It is used in obstetric anesthesia

B. It causes rapid onset of anesthesia within 1-2 minutes
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionC: C. It is used along with catheter for continuous infusions for pain management
optionD: D. The blunt tip needle prevents accidental dural puncture
explanation:
Explanation

The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It does not cause rapid onset of anesthesia, instead has a slower onset of action ranging from 10-20 minutes compared to spinal anesthesia which has a relatively faster onset of action.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

It is used in obstetric anesthesia, segmental blocks, and chronic pain management.

question_title:
65.
        Which of the following media can be used for culturing the organism shown in the image below?
explanation:
Explanation

The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, a beaded appearance, and a chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. They are cultured in MacLeod's medium.

Macleod's medium is selective for C. diphtheriae. Potassium tellurite in McLeod's medium or potassium tellurite agar is reduced to metallic tellurium by C. diphtheriae to produce black colonies. Additionally, tellurite (0.04%) inhibits the growth of most other bacteria, acting as a selective agent.

Other options:

Option A: Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is also a differential media. While S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen S. paratyphi. A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production. 

Option B: BCYE agar or buffered charcoal, yeast extract agar is selective for Legionella species. Legionellae are nutritionally fastidious. Their growth is enhanced with iron salts and depends on the supplementation of media L-cysteine. 

Option D: Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria. Plates were incubated at 43°C with 5 % oxygen, 10% carbon dioxide, and 85% hydrogen. Colonies may be observed after overnight incubation.

question_title:
66.
        Which one of the following drugs is a phosphodiesterase 3 inhibitor and is also a calcium sensitizer binding to troponin C used for the treatment of heart failure?
explanation:
Explanation

Levosimendan is an ionotropic drug that acts as a calcium sensitizer. It increases the affinity of troponin C in the myocardium to calcium by binding to the thin filament in troponin C. This binding causes a conformational change, leading to stronger contraction and a positive ionotropic effect for a particular cytosolic calcium without actually increasing calcium levels. Additionally, PDE3 inhibitor action increases c AMP (by preventing its degradation) which causes increased contractility mediated by β1 (c AMP acts as a 2nd messenger for β receptors). 

Increased c AMP levels in vascular smooth muscles cause relaxation and vasodilation. Opening of ATP-sensitive K channels is also a known action of this drug and it is primarily used in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure. 

Adverse reactions include hypotension and arrhythmia owing to its PDE3 action. 

Other options:

Option B: Milrinone is a PDE3/4 inhibitors without calcium-sensitizing action. Milrinone is more PDE3 selective. This drug causes positive ionotropy and vasodilation by increasing c AMP and are hence may be also referred to as being ionodilators. 

Option C: Enoximone is a PDE3/4 inhibitors without calcium-sensitizing action. This drug causes positive ionotropy and vasodilation by increasing c AMP and are hence may be also referred to as being ionodilators. Inamrinone can also cause dilatation of arteries and veins and thus reduce both preload and afterload. 

Option D: Inamrinone is a PDE3/4 inhibitors without calcium-sensitizing action. This drug causes positive ionotropy and vasodilation by increasing c AMP and are hence may be also referred to as being ionodilators. Inamrinone can also cause dilatation of arteries and veins and thus reduce both preload and afterload.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
67.
        A 30-year-old nulliparous woman comes to gynecology OPD with complaints of chronic pelvic pain which increases during menstruation and infertility. Per abdomen shows a tender cystic mass and per speculum examinations are normal. Bimanual examination reveals pelvic tenderness and tender right adnexal mass. The TVS shows the following and the laparoscopy confirms the diagnosis. What is the appropriate management?
question_ADD: TVS - Transvaginal ultrasound
optionA: A. Periodic surveillance and follow up
optionC: C.  Clomiphene citrate followed by intrauterine insemination
optionD: D. Combined oral contraceptives for 1 cycle
explanation:
Explanation

A 30-year-old nulliparous woman with chronic pelvic pain worsening during menstruation, infertility, and a tender right adnexal mass with a TVS showing a homogenous, right ovarian mass with vascularity suggests an endometrioma, also known as a chocolate cyst. The preferred management for symptomatic endometrioma, especially when associated with infertility, is laparoscopic cystectomy.

Endometrioma is a type of endometrial tissue that grows outside the uterus, typically in the ovaries. This estrogen-dependent condition is commonly seen in nulliparous women and may have a familial predisposition. It is associated with abnormalities of the genital outflow tract that lead to retrograde menstruation.

Patients with endometrioma often present with chronic pelvic pain, which worsens during menstruation due to hormonal effects on the lesion and release of prostaglandin F2α. Infertility is related to various ovarian defects, including abnormal folliculogenesis, anovulation, luteal phase defects, luteinized unruptured follicle syndrome, and pelvic adhesions. Clinical examination may reveal a tender cystic mass, red-blue lesions, and powder-burn spots. Bimanual examination often shows a tender, enlarged adnexal mass, potential nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac, and a fixed, retroverted uterus. Elevated CA125 levels may indicate ovarian malignancy, though it is not routinely used due to poor sensitivity. TVS is the primary imaging tool, showing a homogenous, cystic mass with a ground-glass appearance and pericystic flow on Doppler.

The gold standard for diagnosis and treatment is laparoscopy, which can reveal characteristic variable-coloured lesions, including classic powder burns and chocolate cysts. While NSAIDs can manage pain, surgical intervention through laparoscopic cystectomy is recommended for women seeking to improve fertility, as it reduces recurrence and alleviates pain. However, excision of endometrioma may reduce ovarian reserves over time, so early intervention is advisable for those planning to conceive.

Other options:

Option A: Periodic surveillance and ultrasound follow-up are done for endometriomas of <5cm where the female does not desire pregnancy. 

Option C: Although clomiphene citrate followed by intrauterine insemination is the infertility treatment, the chocolate cyst has to be removed first followed by a trial of natural conception. If that fails, artificial methods can be tried. 

Option D: Combined oral contraceptives is not advisable in this patient as she desires pregnancy.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
69.
        Identify the drugs A and B and their respective uses.
optionA:
A. A- norepinephrine- hemorrhagic shock,  B- epinephrine- anaphylactic shock 
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. A- epinephrine- cardiogenic shock,  B- dopamine- hemorrhagic shock
optionC:
C. A- norepinephrine- hemorrhagic shock, B- dopamine- septic shock
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionD: D. A- dopamine- septic shock, B- epinephrine- anaphylactic shock
explanation:
Explanation

Graph A is norepinephrine, which can be used in hemorrhagic shock, graph B is epinephrine, which can be used in anaphylactic shock. 

Graph A is norepinephrine and it predominantly stimulates α and β1 receptors.  
α 1 mediated vasoconstriction increases peripheral vascular resistance 
β 1 stimulation causing an increase in both systolic (green line) and diastolic BP (red line). Although β1 action should also cause an increase in heart rate, a compensatory vagal reflex overpowers it leading to bradycardia. 
 
Norepinephrine is the drug of choice in hypovolemic shock and volume depletion, cardiogenic shock, and neurogenic shock as it restores blood pressure to maintain cerebral circulation. 
 
Graph B is epinephrine. It stimulates α, β1, β2, β3 receptors. 
β1 stimulation causes an increase in heart rate (positive chronotropic) as well as increased force of contraction (positive ionotropy). 

The increase in systolic blood pressure (green line) is greater than the increase in diastolic blood pressure (red line); hence, the pulse pressure decreases (orange line). 
Peripheral vascular resistance decreases as β2 receptors on blood vessels are more sensitive than α receptors. 

Epinephrine is the drug of choice in anaphylactic shock, where it increases blood pressure along with improving bronchospasm, and laryngeal edoema. 
 
The action of dopamine on receptors depends upon the dose administered. At lower infusion rates (0-2 mcg/kg/min) It stimulates D1 receptors, leading to renal vasodilation, increasing GFR, and promoting diuresis at 2-10 mcg/kg/min acts on β1 receptors increasing heart rate, and systolic BP with minimal effect on diastolic BP. D1-mediated vasodilation also decreases peripheral vascular resistance.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
70.
        Identify the incorrect statement concerning the neonatal resuscitation program.
optionA:
A. The 2-finger technique of chest compressions increases blood pressure
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionB: B. Delayed cord clamping is recommended for preterm infants
optionC:
C. After 10 minutes, resuscitation can be terminated if there is no heartbeat
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided if the abdomen is scaphoid
explanation:
Explanation

If adequate resuscitation continues for 20 min without a detectable heart rate, resuscitative efforts can be terminated. Hence, option C is the incorrect statement.

The image given below shows the steps of neonatal resuscitation.

Other options:

Option A: The 2-finger technique of chest compressions is preferred over the thumb technique because it helps achieve high blood pressure, increases coronary perfusion, and results in less fatigue.

Option B: Delayed cord clamping for 1-3 min is especially recommended for preterm infants. Additional benefits for preterm infants include improved haemodynamic stability, decreased need for inotropic support, decreased need for transfusions, and decreased risk of necrotising enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage.

Option D: A scaphoid abdomen or asymmetry in contour or movement of the chest suggests a diaphragmatic hernia, hence bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in these cases.
subject: Paediatrics

question_title:
71.
        Arrange the following organs in the order of appearance of rigor mortis.
question_ADD:
1 - Upper extremities
2 - Fingers
3 - Chest
4 - Legs
5 - Abdomen
explanation:
Explanation

The correct sequence is 3-1-5-4-2. Chest -> Upper extremities-> Abdomen -> Legs -> Fingers.
The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours. The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Left chamber of the heart is affected first.

Other muscles are affected in the given order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

In individual limbs, it usually progresses from above downwards.
subject: Forensic Medicine

question_title:
72.
        A 78-year-old female patient has ECG findings below and a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Which medication would prevent future complications in this patient?
question_ADD:
ECG - Electrocardiogram

BP -  Blood Pressure
explanation:
Explanation

The medication that would prevent future thrombotic complications in this patient with the given ECG showing an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent 'p' waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF) is rivaroxaban.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have AF. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥1. The CHA2DS2-VASc score in this patient is 5. This patient needs anticoagulation with rivaroxaban to prevent future thrombotic complications. 

  • Age ≥ 75 years = 2
  • Diabetes = 1
  • Hypertension = 1
  • Female gender = 1

Total score = 5

For patients with non-valvular AF, oral anticoagulation has been proven to reduce the risk of stroke and other thromboembolic events. The preferred agents are non-Vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs) such as dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban or edoxaban. 

The situations in which warfarin may be considered as an option include:

  • Patients already on warfarin who are comfortable with periodic INR monitoring and SC injections
  • Patients with mechanical heart valves or severe mitral stenosis
  • Patients who are unlikely to comply with the dosing of oral medications
  • Patients with eGFR < 30 mL/min
  • Patients who are on enzyme-inducing epileptic drugs like phenytoin or protease inhibitors for HIV

Other options :

Option A: Aspirin may be used in patients with a score < 2 in patients with AF.

Option B: Amiodarone may be used for rhythm control in patients with AF but is not used to prevent thrombotic complications.

Option D: Rosiglitazone is an anti diabetic drug but is associated with increased risk of cardiac complications like congestive hear failure, MI.

question_title:
73.
        The true statement regarding the trajectory of the growth curve of a neonate is:
optionA:
A. 10% of birth weight is lost in the 1st week of life
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. Regains birth weight in 3 weeks
optionC: C. 10% of birth weight increases in the 1st week
optionD: D. 10% of birth weight is lost in the 1st 2 weeks of life
explanation:
Explanation

The true statement regarding the trajectory of the growth curve of a neonate is that "10% of birth weight is lost in the 1st week of life".

In the first week after birth, newborns typically experience a temporary weight loss of around 10% after vaginal delivery and up to 12% after cesarean section. This initial decrease is primarily due to the elimination of excess fluid and limited early nutritional intake. As feeding progresses, colostrum gives way to higher-fat breast milk, and infants improve their ability to latch and suck effectively. Consequently, mothers become more adept at feeding techniques.

By the second week of life, most infants regain their birth weight or surpass it. Throughout the first month, infants typically gain about 30 grams (approximately 1 ounce) per day. This period marks the fastest phase of postnatal growth. Approximate daily weight gain is that : 0-3 months: 30 g/day; 3-6 months: 20 g/day; 6-9 months: 15 g/day; 9-12 months: 12 g/day. 

Pearl PM2037: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Note : Infant weight approximately Doubles at 4-5 months , Triples by 1year and is 4 times by 2 years of age.

Weight gained with respect to birth weight

Age Weight
5 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

Formulae for calculating the weight in children

Age Formula

Weight =[age (months) + 9]
2
1-6 years Weight = [2×age (years)] + 8
7-12 years
Weight = [7×age (years) - 5]
2

question_title:
74.
        The expression of which of the following biomarkers can differentiate embryonal cell carcinoma from seminoma?
explanation:
Explanation

The expression of cytokeratin can differentiate embryonal cell carcinoma from seminoma.

Embryonal cell carcinomas are known for their local aggressiveness, often spreading into the epididymis or spermatic cord through the tunica albuginea. The neoplastic cells appear epithelial, are large and anaplastic, and feature hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells are commonly observed, and blood and lymphatic vessels are often invaded.

A typical seminoma cell exhibits a round to polyhedral shape with a well-defined cell membrane. Its cytoplasm appears clear or watery and contains a large central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli. Using immunohistochemistry, the tumor cells of seminoma generally show positivity for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin, while they do not express cytokeratin.

Similar to seminoma, embryonal carcinoma stains positively for OCT3/4. However, it differs in being typically positive for cytokeratin and negative for KIT and podoplanin.

Pearl PM2277: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

question_title:
75.
        You would not consider oral bisphosphonates as a management option in treating osteoporosis in all of the following patients except?
optionC:
C. Seizure disorder on phenytoin
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass done 6 months back
explanation:
Explanation

Bisphosphonates are not contraindicated in patients with a seizure disorder or patients taking phenytoin. Phenytoin can cause secondary osteoporosis in patients.

Contraindications for bisphosphonates:

  • Esophageal disorders
  • Severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Inability to remain upright for 30 minutes
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Chronic kidney disease with an eGFR less than 30-35 mL/min
  • Pregnancy and lactation
  • History of osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ)
  • Active upper gastrointestinal disease, including peptic ulcers, active gastritis, or recent gastrointestinal bleeding

Other options:

Option A: Barrett's Esophagus: Oral bisphosphonates can cause esophageal irritation, making them contraindicated in patients with Barrett’s esophagus due to the increased risk of esophagitis or esophageal cancer. Therefore, bisphosphonates are typically avoided in this population.

Option B: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) with eGFR <30 mL/min: Bisphosphonates are generally contraindicated in patients with severe CKD (eGFR <30 mL/min) because they are excreted via kidneys and may cause a worsening renal function.

Option D: Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass: Patients with a history of gastric bypass surgery may have altered absorption of oral medications, including bisphosphonates, due to changes in the gastrointestinal tract. This makes bisphosphonates less effective or potentially irritating to the stomach, so they are generally avoided in these patients.

Patients who are unable to take oral bisphosphonates can be started on IV bisphosphonates.
subject: Orthopaedics

question_title:
76.
        A middle-aged patient with obesity and elevated liver enzymes is diagnosed with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Which of the following is a newly approved drug for the treatment of  NASH with moderate to advanced liver scarring?
explanation:
Explanation

Resmetirom (brand name REZDIFFRA) is indicated for the treatment of adults with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) with moderate to advanced liver fibrosis in conjunction with diet and exercise.

It is a selective thyroid hormone receptor (THR)-beta agonist. It acts primarily in the liver, where THR-beta is the predominant form of thyroid hormone receptor. Activation of THR-beta by resmetirom reduces intrahepatic triglycerides and liver fat content. This selective activation minimizes the effects of THR-alpha, which mediates thyroid hormone actions in the heart and bone.

Common adverse effects include gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and abdominal pain. Hepatotoxicity and gallbladder-related adverse reactions are significant concerns.

Other options:

Option A. Elafibranor is a medication used for the treatment of primary biliary cholangitis. It is a dual PPARα/δ agonist.

Option B. Vamorolone is a synthetic corticosteroid, which is used for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. 

Option C. Obeticholic acid is used to treat primary biliary cholangitis.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
77.
        A 35-year-old man with no comorbidities presents with altered sensorium, severe headache, and 2 episodes of vomiting. Lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure and turbid cerebrospinal fluid, which is sent for analysis. Initial results revealed raised neutrophils. What medications should be started until the final reports are available?
explanation:
Explanation

The clinical features suggest meningitis; given the patient's age and absence of comorbidities, empirical therapy with ceftriaxone and vancomycin should be initiated.

The patient has elevated intracranial pressure with nuchal rigidity, and positive Kernig's (pain on passive extension of the knee when the thigh is flexed on the abdomen) and Brudzinski's (spontaneous flexion of hips and knees on passive flexion of neck) signs. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appears turbid. All these findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The most common organism causing bacterial meningitis in adults is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Other less common causes are Neisseria meningitidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Haemophilus sp., and Enterobacteriaceae, etc.

Patients may have a fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and seizures. Signs of meningeal irritation can be elicited by Kernig's and Brudzinki's signs. 

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) abnormalities in bacterial meningitis
Opening pressure >180 mmH2O
White blood cells 10/μL to 10,000/μL; neutrophils predominate
Red blood cells Absent in nontraumatic tap
CSF/serum glucose <0.4
Protein  >0.45 g/L (>45 mg/dL)
Gram’s stain Positive in >60%
Culture Positive in >80%
PCR Detects bacterial DNA
Latex agglutination May be positive in patients with meningitis due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, Escherichia coli, group B streptococci

As soon as bacterial meningitis is suspected, blood cultures should be immediately obtained and the patient should be started on empirical antibiotics and dexamethasone. 

Choice of empirical antibiotics in various situations is as follows :

  • Preterm infants to infants <1 month - Ampicillin + cefotaxime
  • Infants 1 – 3 months - Ampicillin + cefotaxime or ceftriaxone
  • Immunocompetent children > 3 months and adults <55 years - Cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, or cefepime + vancomycin
  • Adults > 55 years and adults of any age with alcoholism or other debilitating illnesses - Ampicillin + cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, or cefepime +vancomycin
  • Hospital-acquired meningitis, posttraumatic or post neurosurgery meningitis, neutropenic patients, or patients with impaired cell-mediated immunity - Ampicillin + ceftazidime or meropenem + vancomycin

        Identify the arrow-marked structure and the corresponding vertebral level.
optionB:
B. Arch of Aorta - T3
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

The arrow marks the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk. It corresponds to the T5 level.

The image shows a cross section of a cadaver at the T5 vertebral level. This corresponds anteriorly to the level of the sternal angle, and is also the level of division between the superior and inferior mediastinum.

At this level, the other structures visible are:

  • The origin and termination of the arch of aorta. The descending aorta can be identified to the left of the oesophagus. The arch of the aorta (Option D) would be visible at the T3-T4 cross sectional level.
  • The superior vena cava (Option B), just lateral to the origin of the aorta, which can visually differentiated from the aorta based on the wall thickness. At this level, it penetrates the right atrium.
  • The bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk.
  • The left and right main bronchi. The carina (Option A) is not visible as the trachea bifurcates more proximally at the T4 level.

question_title:
79.
        Which of the following is not a contraindication for pancreaticoduodenectomy in a case of pancreatic cancer?
optionB:
B. Peri-pancreatic lymph node involvement
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

Among the following options, peri-pancreatic lymph node involvement is not a contraindication for pancreaticoduodenectomy.

In pancreaticoduodenectomy, the following are generally considered contraindications:

  • Liver Metastases: (option A) The presence of liver metastases is a contraindication because it indicates that cancer has spread beyond the pancreas, making a curative resection unlikely.
  • Peritoneal Seedings: (option C) This indicates widespread cancer within the peritoneal cavity and is a contraindication for resection, as it suggests metastatic disease.
  • Celiac Lymph Node Involvement: (Option D) Involvement of the celiac lymph nodes often signifies metastatic disease, which is generally considered a contraindication for resection.

Peri-pancreatic Lymph Node Involvement is not an absolute contraindication for resection. While it suggests locally advanced disease and might influence the decision-making process, the presence of peri-pancreatic lymph node involvement alone does not preclude resection if the disease is otherwise localized and potentially resectable. 

Findings contraindicating resection:

• Liver metastases (any size)
• Celiac lymph node involvement
• Peritoneal implants
• Hepatic hilar lymph node involvement

Findings not contraindicating resection:

• Invasion at duodenum or distal stomach.
• Involved peri-pancreatic lymph nodes.
• Involved lymph nodes along porta hepatis that can be removed along with the tumor.
• Involvement of superior mesenteric vein

question_title:
80.
        Match the correct neurocutaneous disorder with its respective clinical spectrum.
question_ADD:
Condition Clinical spectrum
1. Neurofibromatosis type 1  A. Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ash-leaf spots
2. Sturge-Weber syndrome B. Cerebellar haemangioblastoma, retinal angiomas
3. Von Hippel Lindau disease C. Iris hamartoma, optic glioma
4. Tuberous Sclerosis D. Port-wine birthmark, glaucoma
explanation:
Explanation

Option B is the correctly matched answer to this question. The following table represents each condition matched to its clinical spectrum.

Condition Clinical spectrum
1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 

C. Iris hamartoma/ Lisch nodules, optic glioma
2. Sturge-Weber syndrome D. Port-wine birthmark, glaucoma
3. Von Hippel Lindau disease B. Cerebellar haemangioblastoma, retinal angiomas
4. Tuberous sclerosis

A. Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ash-leaf spots

Neurocutaneous disorders are conditions that affect ectodermal derivatives, most commonly the skin and the CNS. 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is due to an autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutation in the NF1 gene. Other characteristic features of NF1 include cafe-au-lait macules, inguinal and axillary freckling, and neurofibromas.

The images below show Lisch nodules, cafe-au-lait macules, and axillary freckling respectively.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by vascular malformations limited to segments. It usually results from a mosaic mutation in the GNAQ gene. Leptomeningeal angiomas are a common finding. Presenting complaints in patients range from developmental delay and headaches to seizures, hemiparesis, and stroke-like episodes. Port-wine marks and glaucoma are characteristic.

Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) is an autosomal dominant condition that arises from a mutation affecting the VHL tumor suppressor gene. Characteristic features of VHL include spinal hemangioblastomas, endolymphatic sac tumor, pheochromocytoma, and cystic lesions of the kidneys, pancreas, and liver.

Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) also follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Other features of TSC also include shagreen patches, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal angiomyolipoma, facial angiofibroma, and periungual fibromas which are shown in the images below. 

Pearl PM2489: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.
subject: Paediatrics

question_title:
81.
        A 75-year-old woman presents with multiple, tense, pruritic bullae and blisters. A linear pattern is seen on immunofluorescence and histopathology demonstrates subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. Which of the following is true about this disease?
optionB: B. Blisters formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis
optionC:
C. Nikolsky sign is negative
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Nikolsky sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid.

Immunofluorescent microscopy will show the presence of subepidermal split and linear pattern deposition of IgG antibodies against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230- components of hemidesmosomes. Subepidermal, nonacantholytic bullae are seen which are tense and don't rupture easily. Hence Nikolsky sign i.e exfoliation of skin on slight rubbing is absent.

Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders. It is mostly a disease of the elderly.

Histopathology will show the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils and basal cell layer vacuolization. 

Clinical features include a prodromal phase and a bullous phase.

A prodromal phase with excoriated papules, eczematous or urticarial skin lesions and haemorrhagic crusts may be seen.

The bullous phase is characterised by the:

  • Intense pruritus is almost constantly present.
  • Symmetrically distributed tense bullae and vesicles over the flexural aspects and abdomen of the body.
  • Partly haemorrhagic crusts and erythematous plaques with an annular pattern are seen.
  • Lesions heal without scarring, provided there are no superinfections.
  • The bullae contain clear, sometimes haemorrhagic exudates.
  • Nikolsky's sign is negative.
  • Oral or mucosal lesions and milia formation are rare.

The image given below shows the lesions seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Other options:


Options A, B, and D: Blisters in suprabasal layers of epidermis, anti-desmoglein antibodies, and intraepidermal target antigens are all features of pemphigus vulgaris.
