question_title:
119.
        Match the following:
question_ADD:
Column A Column B
1. Nystagmus A. Organophosphate
2. Miosis B. Aconite
3. Mydriasis C. Phenytoin toxicity
4. Hippus D. Amphetamine
explanation:
Explanation

The correctly matched set is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

 Column A Column B
1. Nystagmus C. Phenytoin Toxicity
2. Miosis A. Organophosphate
3. Mydriasis D. Amphetamine
4. Hippus B. Aconite


Phenytoin, carbamazepine, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, and phencyclidine can cause nystagmus. Acute poisoning from phenytoin often presents with drowsiness, confusion, excitement, delirium, hallucinations, ataxia, vertigo, slurred speech, and visual disturbances, with severe cases potentially leading to irreversible brain damage if not managed promptly. Charcoal haemoperfusion is effective for removing highly protein-bound, lipid-soluble substances with a large volume of distribution, like phenytoin, barbiturates, and salicylates.

Organophosphate compounds are among the commonly used agricultural poisons, metabolized in the liver and detoxified via cytochrome P450. These compounds inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine at nerve endings and causing symptoms such as pinpoint pupils(miosis), respiratory distress, and a characteristic kerosene-like odor from body fluids. Acute poisoning results in overactivity of the nervous system, with irreversible enzyme inactivation occurring within 24 to 36 hours, leading to persistent symptoms and potential paralysis.

Amphetamines increase the synaptic levels of dopamine and norepinephrine by blocking their reuptake and increasing catecholamine release, which can cause toxicity similar to cocaine. Symptoms of acute poisoning vary from mild restlessness, insomnia, and dilated pupils to severe delirium, hyperpyrexia, convulsions, and arrhythmias. In moderate cases, individuals may experience confusion, hypertension, tachycardia, and hallucinations.

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconitum napellus (shown below). Hippus, i.e. alternate dilatation and constriction of pupils, followed by complete dilation, is a characteristic feature. Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves and skeletal and smooth muscles. Symptoms include intestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain, and diarrhea), cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), and neurological (vertigo and restlessness) manifestations.
subject: Forensic Medicine

question_title:
120.
        A 32-year-old G3P2 Rh-negative mother presented at 35 weeks of gestation for follow-up. Her husband is Rh-positive. She did not receive anti-D prophylaxis for her previous two pregnancies. Her current antibody titers are at 1:32. On Doppler velocimetry, the middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity is at 1.7 multiples of median (MoM). What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Explanation

Middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) of >1.5 MoM is suggestive of fetal anemia and the next step in management is to deliver immediately since the patient is at more than 34 weeks of gestation.

The protocol for RH isoimmunisation is as follows:

Other options

Option A: Intrauterine transfusion is usually done when fetal hematocrit is <30%. It is done before 34 weeks of gestation.

Option C: It would be advisable to wait till 37-38 weeks if MCA PSV <1.5 MoM. In this case, fetal hemolysis has already occurred and immediate delivery is required.

Option D: Estimation of fetal hemolysis is done through amniocentesis or MCA PSV. Follow-up of MCA PSV every 2 weeks till 37-38 weeks is done only when MCA PSV <1.5 MoM.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
121.
        A patient with myocardial infarction develops a sudden circulatory collapse. On examination, his BP is 80/70 mm Hg and his pulse rate is 40 beats/minute. Which of the following physiological reflexes is involved in this scenario?
explanation:
Explanation

The circulatory collapse in a patient of MI (myocardial infarction) is due to Bezold-Jarisch Reflex. 

Carotid sinus baroreceptors sense the arterial hypotension and trigger afferent fibres that send autonomic signals resulting in an increase in heart rate and contractility, while pressure receptors in the left ventricular wall send signals that trigger paradoxical bradycardia and decreased contractility. This results in suddenly marked hypotension and the individual feels lightheaded and may lose consciousness for a brief period.

The activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) that causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing is the Bezold Jarisch reflex.

It can be elicited by :

  • Substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine
  • Myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals 
  • Radiocontrast agents for coronary angiography

Other options:

Option A: Tachycardia following acute volume overload is due to the Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option B: Hypertension following a head injury is due to the Cushing Reflex. When the intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Option C: Apnea followed by rapid breathing after iv capsaicin is due to the J Reflex. C fibre-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. This is called the J reflex or pulmonary chemoreflex. A similar response is produced by receptors in the heart (Bezold-Jarisch reflex or the coronary chemoreflex).
subject: Physiology

question_title:
122.
        All of the following cause traumatic asphyxia, except
explanation:
Explanation

Traumatic asphyxia, or Perthes's syndrome, is a medical emergency caused by an intense compression of the thoracic cage, causing back-flow of blood from the right side of the heart into the veins of the neck and the brain.

This may occur during road traffic collisions or following collapse of structures such as mine tunnels, or buildings in earthquakes.

Pressure on the chest that restricts movement may also occur if the individual simply gets into, or is placed into, a position in which the free movement of the chest is restricted. This positional asphyxia occurs most commonly in individuals that are rendered immobile through alcohol or drugs and may be seen following restraint in custodial settings.

It may also be seen in the healthy, for example, attempting to climb through a small window to gain access to a property.
subject: Forensic Medicine

question_title:
123.
         Which of the following statements are true regarding the grading of renal injury in patients with traumatic renal injury?
question_ADD:
1. Microscopic or gross haematuria with normal imaging is grade I.
  2. Laceration of <1 cm parenchymal depth without extravasation of urine is grade II.
  3. Non-expanding peri-renal hematoma confined to the retroperitoneum is grade III.
  4. Avulsion of the renal hilum devascularizing the kidney is grade IV.
  5. A shattered kidney is grade V.
explanation:
Explanation

The statements that are true regarding the grades of renal injury are:

  • Microscopic or gross haematuria with normal imaging is grade 1.
  • Laceration of <1 cm parenchymal depth without extravasation of urine is grade II.
  • A shattered kidney is grade V

A non-expanding peri-renal hematoma confined to the retroperitoneum belongs to grade II. Avulsion of the renal hilum devascularising the kidney belongs to grade V.

question_title:
124.
        Match the antibodies seen in systemic lupus erythematosis with their specific clinical utility.
question_ADD:
1. Anti-Sm a. Best screening test for SLE
2. Anti-histone b. Predisposes to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block 
3. Anti-nuclear c. Predisposes clotting & thrombocytopenia
4. Anti-phospholipid d. Specific for SLE. Simultaneous RNP positivity is also seen.
5. Anti-Ro e. More frequently associated with drug-induced lupus than SLE
explanation:
Explanation

The correctly matched antibodies seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosis with their clinical relevance are given below.

1. Anti-Sm d. Specific for SLE. Simultaneous RNP positivity is also seen
2. Anti-histone e. More frequently associated with drug-induced lupus than SLE
3. Anti-nuclear a. Best screening test for SLE
4. Anti-phospholipid c. Predisposes clotting & thrombocytopenia
5. Anti-Ro b. Predisposes to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block

Systemic lupus erythromatosis (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that causes cell damage due to autoantibodies and immune complexes. It is more commonly seen in females and is associated with autoimmune activation of innate immunity, autoantibodies, and T-cells. Several factors predispose to this disease including:

  • Genetic factors: HLA-DR3, DNAse-1, STAT4, APOL-1
  • Environmental factors: UV light, smoking, crystalline silica, Ebstein Barr Virus infection

Diagnosis of SLE is based on the characteristic clinical features and autoantibodies.

Systemic Lupus International Collaborating clinic criteria (SLICC) for diagnosis of SLE:

Clinical manifestations:

  1. Skin:
    - Acute/ Subacute: photosensitivity, malar rash, maculopapular lesions
    - Chronic: discoid lupus, panniculitis
  2.  Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Renal:
    - Protein/Creatinine >=0.5
    - RBC casts
    - Biopsy
  5. Synovitis >+2 joints
  6. Serositis - pleurisy, pericarditis
  7. Neurologic:
    - Seizures
    - Psychosis
    - Mononeuritis
    - Myelitis
    - Cranial neuropathies
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia or lymphopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia

Immunologic manifestations:

  1. ANA > reference negative value
  2. Anti-dsDNA > reference
  3. Anti-Sm
  4. Antiphospholipid:
    - lupus anticoagulant
    - anticardiolipin
    - anti-beta glycoprotein I
  5. Low serum complements
  6. Direct Coomb's test positive in the absence of hemolytic anemia

The presence of any 4 criteria with at least 1 in each category is diagnosed as SLE with 93% specificity and 92 % sensitivity. A positive renal biopsy is read as systemic lupus even if none of the other features is present.

Pearl PM1922: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

More common in black & asians than white

(In nucleosome & chromatin)		 More frequent in drug induced lupus than in SLE

This is not a useful clinical test

(includes antiglutamate receptor)		 60 Neuronal & lymphocyte surface antigens In some series, a positive test in CSF correlates with active CNS lupus

question_title:
125.
        A 40-year-old woman presents with a sudden loss of vision in both eyes that occurred after a stressful argument with her boss. On examination, her visual acuity is recorded as 6/6 in each eye, and her pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. There are no abnormalities found on ophthalmic examination or in other neurological evaluations. When asked to follow a moving object or identify visual stimuli, she demonstrates inconsistent performance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Explanation

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is conversion disorder /functional neurologic symptom disorder.

Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anaesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Conversion disorder usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented or behavioural therapy is also helpful. Hypnosis and anxiolytics are used in some cases. 

Other options: 

Option B: Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. Some clinical features include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), especially in its ischemic form, usually presents with severe visual loss, marked retinal haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, optic disc oedema, and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), often accompanied by detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic examination. However, this patient has normal visual acuity, normal pupillary reactions, and no detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic or neurological exams, making CRVO an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option D: Eales' disease, common in young Asian males, features recurrent vitreous haemorrhage and retinal neovascularization due to peripheral retinal vein inflammation. It presents with a reddish vitreous mass and can lead to vision loss and complications like retinal detachment. However, it is less likely here due to the patient’s demographics and absence of characteristic findings.

Pearl PM0377: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.
  • Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.
  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability
  • Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

Pearl PM0376: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

Key features of somatic symptom and related disorders

Somatic symptom disorder

Excessive anxiety and preoccupation with ≥1 unexplained symptom

Illness anxiety disorder

(hypochondriasis)

Fear of having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and consistently negative evaluations

Conversion disorder

(functional neurologic symptom disorder)

Neurologic symptom  incompatible with any known neurologic disease, often acute onset associated with stress

Factitious disorder

Intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with a goal to assume the sick role

Malingering

Falsification or exaggeration of symptoms to obtain external incentives (secondary gain)

Pearl PM1937: Classification of somatic symptom disorders: DSM-5 vs ICD-10

DSM-5

(Somatic symptom and related disorders)

 ICD-10

(Somatoform disorders)
Somatic symptom disorder

Somatization disorder

Undifferentiated somatoform disorder

Persistent somatoform pain disorder
Conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder) Dissociative (conversion) disorder
Illness anxiety disorder Hypochondriacal disorder
Factitious disorder  
Somatoform disorder NEC

Somatoform autonomic dysfunction

Other somatoform disorders

Somatoform disorder unspecified

Neurasthenia (neurotic
disorders category)
Psychological factors affecting another medical condition
subject: Psychiatry

question_title:
126.
        A patient on statins was advised to discontinue his medications as he developed statin induced myopathy. When he came for follow up 6 weeks later, his CK levels were normalized. What is the next step in the management of hypercholesterolemia for this patient?
optionA:
A. Restart statin at a lower dose
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Start him on Omega 3 fatty acids
explanation:
Explanation

This patient had statin-induced myopathy and now is presenting for further management of his hypercholesterolemia. The next step in his management would be to restart statins at a lower dose to see if he can tolerate them. 

Statin-induced myopathy presents with muscle pain, tenderness or weakness. The risk of statin-associated myalgia or myopathy is increased by factors such as older age, frailty, renal insufficiency, and the use of drugs that interfere with statin metabolism, including erythromycin and related antibiotics, antifungal agents, immunosuppressive drugs, and fibric acid derivatives, especially gemfibrozil. If muscle symptoms arise, a plasma CK level can be measured to distinguish myopathy from myalgia. CK levels would be higher in myopathy.

Statins are the most commonly used hypolipidemic drugs. Statins act by inhibiting the rate-limiting HMG-CoA reductase enzyme, which in turn inhibits cholesterol synthesis. They decrease low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and triglycerides and increase high-density lipoproteins in plasma.

Examples of statins are lovastatin, Simvastatin, Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin, Pravastatin, and Pitavastatin.

If a patient develops statin-induced myopathy, the next step is to stop medications and observe for normalisation of his CK levels over 4-6 weeks. Once his CK levels are normal, low-dose statins must be attempted first. If that is not tolerated, then a different class of drug can be attempted, for example, ezetimibe, a NPC1L1 inhibitor (Sterol absorption inhibitor). (Option C)

Pravastatin, pitavastatin, and fluvastatin have had lesser associations with muscle toxicity. 

Alternate day dosing can also be tried if patients are not able to handle daily dosing.  

Other options:

Option B: Dietary modification is unlikely to help a patient with hypercholesterolemia that is controlled with a drug as pharmacotherapy is usually attempted after conservative measures fail. 

Option D: Omega 3 fatty acids do not have enough supportive evidence to justify using them over proven efficacious drugs
subject: Medicine

question_title:
127.
        Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody directed against integrin, used in the treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis?
explanation:
Explanation

Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin.

Natalizumab is highly effective and reduces the attack rate of multiple sclerosis thus improving the severity of the disease (both clinical and MRI). Natalizumab is given as an injectable preparation. 

The major concern of natalizumab is the risk of the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is also a life-threatening condition developed from the JC virus infection. The risk of developing PML is higher in patients taking natalizumab associated with JC antibody positive. Therefore, natalizumab is recommended only for JC antibody-negative patients.

Other options:

Option A: Fingolimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate modulator. It reduces the attack rate and improves the disease severity in multiple sclerosis. It is given as oral preparation. The patients on fingolimod are at risk of developing macular edema and disseminated varicella-zoster infection.

Option B: Teriflunomide inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme, dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase present in de novo pyrimidine biosynthesis. It is given as oral preparation. The adverse effect includes Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It has teratogenicity and is considered a category X drug. 

Option C: Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule located on the surface of mature B cells and is a highly effective medication for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis. It is given as an intravenous preparation. It is associated with an increased risk of malignancy like breast cancer and infusion reactions.
subject: Medicine

question_title:
128.
        Identify the instrument given in the image below:
explanation:
Explanation

The image is that of a Bulldog clamp.

The utility of a bulldog clamp is as follows:

  1. To clamp the common hepatic duct to control the flow of bile during pancreaticoduodenectomy. 
  2. Clamping the middle colic artery during left colonic interposition, for oesophageal replacement. 
  3. Clamping of mesenteric vessels during Roux-en-y-replacement.

Other options: 

Option A: DeBakey's forceps are useful for holding vessel walls in vascular surgery. They allow the surgeon to grasp tissues firmly while minimising damage to the tissue held in the jaws of the forceps.

Option B: Payr's crushing clamp is a stout, heavy instrument with a double level in the handle and it crushes the bowel once applied. It is used in gastrectomy.

Option D: Lister’s sinus forceps are used for blunt dissection. It is used during Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi and is also used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.
subject: Surgery

question_title:
129.
        A 6-year-old boy presents with fatigue and yellowish discoloration of the eyes. The peripheral smear examination is given below. What is the underlying pathology involved in the disease associated with this condition?
optionA: A. Mutation of spectrin ankyrin proteins
optionB:
B. Mutation of beta globin chain
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario of anaemia and jaundice with the peripheral smear showing sickle-shaped RBCs is suggestive of sickle cell disease and the pathology involved in the disease associated with this condition is the mutation of the beta-globin chain. 

Sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated haemoglobin (HbS).

Factors that predispose to sickling are - 

Intracellular dehydration increases the mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration(MCHC) which increases the aggregation and polymerization of RBCs during deoxygenation. Conversely, conditions that decrease the MCHC reduce disease severity. This occurs when an individual is homozygous for HbS but also has coexistent α-thalassemia, which reduces Hb synthesis and leads to milder disease.

A decrease in intracellular pH reduces the oxygen affinity of haemoglobin, thereby increasing the levels of deoxygenated HbS at any given oxygen tension and augmenting the tendency for sickling.

In most of the microvascular capillaries, the transit time of RBCs is too short for significant aggregation of deoxygenated HbS to occur. As a result, sickling is confined to microvascular capillaries with slow transit times. Blood flow is sluggish in the normal spleen and bone marrow, which are prominently affected in sickle cell disease.

Note - The presence of HbF decreases sickling as it shows higher oxygen affinity than HbA and thereby reduces the levels of deoxygenated Hb which are prerequisites for sickling. Hydroxyurea, a drug used in sickle cell disease acts by promoting HbF production.

Other options:

Option A: Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant hereditary hemolytic anaemia caused by mutations in red blood cell surface proteins like spectrin and ankyrin.

Option C: Hereditary spherocytosis is likely to have increased osmotic fragility, unlike sickle cell disease which has decreased osmotic fragility.

Option D: In Sickle cell disease, there is increased mechanical fragility like in cases of thalassemia, G6PD deficiency, and malaria. When subjected to mechanical stress, such as shearing forces, trauma, or turbulence, sickle cells have high mechanical fragility because they are more rigid and less deformable than normal red blood cells. This makes them more likely to break apart when subjected to mechanical stress.

Note: Mechanical fragility measures the extent of hemolysis observed when red blood cells are exposed to mechanical stress, often through shear forces.
subject: Pathology

question_title:
130.
        A 7-year-old boy with a recent history of travel to central Africa is brought to the ER with a painful blistering rash that started over the face and progressed to other regions. The rash started almost 5 days before the presentation. He also complained of associated low-grade fever, myalgia, and fatigue. On examination, there is palpable regional and inguinal lymphadenopathy and blisters, as shown in the image. He was accompanied by his mother, who was currently asymptomatic. Ideal management for her would be:
question_ADD: ER - Emergency room
optionB:
B. Isolate for 21 days along with prophylactic antivirals
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionD:
D. Only Monitor for 21 days
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical vignette suggests a case of monkeypox (Mpox) virus and management of this patient's asymptomatic mother would be to monitor her for 21 days.

Management of asymptomatic contacts includes monitoring for 21 days. There is no role for prophylactic antivirals. If at any point in time in 21 days, the patient develops symptoms he should be placed for an empiric 5-day isolation. The natural reservoir is unknown. The incubation period might last from 5 to 21 days. The communicability phase lasts 1-2 days before the rash appears and ends when all scabs fall off or diminish. There is evidence of both human-to-human and animal-to-human transmission. 

While monitoring a patient with monkeypox during this period of 21 days we may come across patients either in one of these two categories:

If a rash occurs The patient needs to be isolated until the rash is examined and tested by a doctor and it is tested negative.
Other signs or symptoms but no rash

The patient needs to be observed for another 5 days for any more new signs or symptoms even if it extends beyond 21 days. 

also, it is to be noted that if a new sign or symptom has been observed during this extended period of 5 days, the patient needs to be further observed for another 5 days. Whereas if there is no sign or symptom observed, monitoring may be stopped and the patient discharged.


Mpox virus belongs to the orthopoxvirus genus of the Poxviridae family which is a double-stranded DNA Virus and enveloped. Mpox has been prevalent in parts of central and western Africa. The clinical features of the disease include fever, myalgia, fatigue, and back pain. It is associated with a painful rash starting on the Face and spreading to the trunk and chest. One of the characteristic differentiating features from chickenpox and smallpox is the presence of lymphadenopathy.

The monkeypox virus has been further classified into two types ie. Clade I and Clade II.

Clade I: Predominantly found in Central and East Africa and is more severe.

Clade II: Endemic to West Africa and is less severe.

Diagnosis is done by RT-PCR of blister fluid or body fluids.

Most cases of mpox present with mild symptoms and there is complete recovery within 2 to 4 weeks. There is no specific treatment for the disease yet, although antivirals such as Tecovirimat have been approved for the treatment of severe Mpox.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
131.
        Structures are marked as 1, 2 ,3 and 4 in CT of the paranasal sinus below. In which of the following given structures does the nasolacrimal duct opens into?
explanation:
Explanation

The structure marked as 1 is the inferior meatus and the nasolacrimal duct opens into it.

The valve of Hasner, which is present at the lower end of the duct prevents reflux from the nose. The inferior turbinate is a separate bone and the inferior meatus lies below it.

Maxillary (Antrum of Highmore), frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses open in the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to basal lamella of middle turbinate.
subject: ENT

question_title:
132.
        Identify the marked structure in the given image.
explanation:
Explanation

The structure marked in the given image of transverse section of basal ganglia is a gray matter structure known as claustrum. It is flanked by external capsule medially and extreme capsule and insular cortex laterally. 

The gray matter structures which can be seen on a transverse section of the cerebrum are:

  • Head of caudate nucleus forms the lateral wall of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle.
  • Thalamus contributes to the floor of the body of the lateral ventricle.
  • Lentiform nucleus is a wedge-shaped mass related medially to the internal capsule, which separates it from the caudate nucleus and the thalamus and laterally to the external capsule. A vertical plate of white matter divides the lentiform nucleus into globus pallidus medially and putamen laterally. 
  • Claustrum separates the external capsule from the extreme capsule and the subcortical white matter of the insular cortex. The function of claustrum is not known.

All the capsules (internal capsule, external capsule and extreme capsule) are white matter bundles while all the nuclei (caudate nucleus, lentiform nucleus, thalamus) are masses of gray matter.
subject: Anatomy

question_title:
133.
        A 72-year-old male patient complains of headaches. His son adds that the patient also has memory disturbances. Further questioning revealed a history of a fall a few months back. The most probable diagnosis among the following is
explanation:
Explanation

An elderly male patient with a history of memory disturbances and headaches following a history of fall point toward chronic subdural hemorrhage (SDH). 

Chronic SDH is commonly seen in elderly patients. It is also a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in them. Cerebral atrophy in the elderly age group results in the stretching of cortical–dural bridging veins, which makes them vulnerable to rupture. The resulting hematoma can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately leading to symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits.

There is usually a history of a recent injury. Even apparently trivial impacts may be responsible for this condition, especially if on antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications.

On head CT scan, chronic SDH appears as a hypodense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion as shown in the image below.

Burr hole evacuation is the preferred treatment in most patients with chronic SDH. Conservative treatment can be considered in small, asymptomatic bleeds.

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion as shown in the image below.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Or GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

All other conditions, given as options present with rapid deterioration of neurological signs and symptoms along with a history of high-energy impact injury. Hence, they are ruled out.

Pearl PM0111: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size
subject: Surgery

question_title:
134.
        A student is studying effects of endplate potential on skeletal muscle using the following graph. All of the following can lead to curve B except?
optionA:
A.  Coupling of neostigmine with acetylcholine esterase
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionB: B. Coupling of carbachol with nicotinic receptor
optionC:
C. Coupling of curarine with nicotinic receptor
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Coupling of diisopropyl fluorophosphate with acetylcholine esterase
explanation:
Explanation

The above graph is a depiction of end plate potential initiating action potential and curve B is normal end plate potential causing muscle action potential. The coupling of curarine drugs with nicotinic receptors causes weak endplate potential (curve A)  by preventing the passage of impulses from the nerve endings to the muscle fiber.

The end plate potential is a local potential caused by a sudden rise in the number of sodium ions in the muscle fiber when voltage-gated acetylcholine channels open causing a positive rise of potential up to 50 to 75 mV.

In the given graph end Point A and Point C denote weak end plate potential which are not able to elicit action potential, whereas point B refers to a strong end plate potential that can cross the threshold to cause action potential.

Curve A is caused by poisoning of the muscle fiber with curare drugs by competing with acetylcholine receptors, hence block of action potential takes place

Curve C is due to the effect of botulinum toxin which inhibits exocytosis of acetylcholine by binding to synaptobrevin.

Other options:

Option A) Coupling of neostigmine with acetylcholine esterase stimulates the neuromuscular junction by inactivating acetylcholinesterase. Hence it is no longer able to hydrolyze acetylcholine and causes action potential.

Option B) Coupling of carbachol with a nicotinic receptor causes stimulation of muscle fiber because carbachol is a sympathomimetic drug that has a similar action to acetylcholine.

Option D) Coupling of diisopropyl fluorophosphate with acetylcholine esterase causes positive action potential as it is also a cholinesterase inhibitor.
subject: Physiology

question_title:
135.
        A patient presents with dysphagia and hoarseness of voice. A 2D echo shows a dilatation in the thoracic aorta. He is diagnosed with thoracic aortic aneurysm. What is the most commonly associated risk factor for the development of this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

Hypertension is the most commonly associated risk factor for the development of a thoracic aortic aneurysm(TAA), which in this patient presents as hoarseness of voice and dysphagia with a finding of dilatation in the thoracic aorta in the above clinical scenario.

TAA is associated with multiple risk factors:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Systemic conditions like vasculitis and Marfan syndrome
  • Tertiary syphilis
  • History of trauma like a motor vehicle collision
  • Male > Female 

Clinical features of TAA:

  • Dysphagia due to compression of the esophagus
  • Hoarseness of voice due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • Dyspnea from compression of the bronchi
  • Chest pain from bone erosion or obstruction of a coronary artery

Other options:
Cigarette smoking and diabetes mellitus are both associated with TAA but hypertension is more closely associated. They are, however, major risk factors for the development of abdominal aortic aneurysms.
subject: Pathology

question_title:
136.
        A 7-year-old girl presents with a sore throat, fever, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy for 3 days. She has a history of frequent sore throats requiring prolonged antibiotics, easy bruising, and bruises of different ages on her arms.  She is fair-skinned and has blonde hair.  Her birth and family history are unremarkable. What is the likely defect?
explanation:
Explanation

This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Chediak Higashi syndrome which is a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes a loss-of-function mutation of the LYST gene encoding for the lysosomal trafficking regulator—a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. 

Patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome may present clinically with persistent skin, respiratory, and gastrointestinal infections, particularly due to Staphylococcus aureus. They may also exhibit partial oculo-cutaneous albinism, and platelet dysfunction leading to increased bleeding time, easy bruising, and excessive bleeding despite normal platelet counts. Neurological dysfunctions such as progressive peripheral neuropathy, nystagmus, and mental retardation are common, and patients may experience an accelerated phase with lymphoma-like illness and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. The latter is a life-threatening condition characterized by prolonged high fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and cytopenia, and it carries a very poor prognosis.

Diagnosis can be done by detecting the presence of peroxidase-positive giant primary granules in neutrophils and other granule-bearing cells on Wright’s stain. Genetic detection may be confirmatory. 

The image below shows a neutrophil in Chediak Higashi Syndrome showing polymorphonuclear leukocytes with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules-

Other options:

Option A: Disorders of T cells include conditions such as Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disorder, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and DiGeorge syndrome

Option B: Disorders of B cells include conditions such as hyper IgM syndrome and IgA deficiency. 

Option C: Disorders of the complement system include angioedema.

Pearl PM0536: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
137.
        Nivolumab and Relatlimab combination can be used in which of these tumours?
optionC: C. Non small cell lung cancer
explanation:
Explanation

Nivolumab and Relatlimab combination can be used in patients with Malignant Melanoma.

Both Nivolumab and Relatlimab are Immune checkpoint inhibitors. A combination of Nivolumab, a PD-1 blocking antibody(programmed death receptor-1), and Relatlimab, a LAG-3 blocking antibody (lymphocyte activation gene-3) is indicated for the treatment of patients with unresectable or metastatic melanoma.

Binding of the PD-1 ligands (PD-L1 and PD-L2) to the PD-1 receptor found on T cells, inhibits T-cell proliferation and cytokine production. Upregulation of PD-1 ligands occurs in Malignant melanoma which leads to inhibition of T-cell immune surveillance of tumours. Similarly, the LAG-3 pathway inhibits T-cell proliferation and cytokine secretion. The drugs which inhibit PD-1 or LAG-3 and other similar interactions between the Tumour and Immune cells are termed Immune checkpoint inhibitors.

The synergistic combination of Nivolumab (anti-PD-1) and Relatlimab (anti-LAG-3) results in increased T-cell activation compared to the activity of either antibody alone, as LAG-3 blockade potentiates the anti-tumour activity of PD-1 blockage, inhibiting tumour growth and promoting tumour regression.

The drug combination is given by intravenous route in adults as well as children more than 12 years of age. Adverse effects upon usage include anaemia, lymphocytopenia, increased AST, increased ALT, and Hyponatremia.

Many other immune checkpoint inhibitors have been approved for the treatment of various tumours. Pembrolizumab which acts by inhibiting PD-1, is approved for the treatment of carcinoma endometrium.

Atezolimumab is also an immune checkpoint inhibitor, acts by inhibiting PDL-1, used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer.

Durvalumab is also a PD-L1 inhibitor and is approved for use in metastatic urothelial cancer.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
138.
        A 65 year old male patient came to the outpatient department with cough with expectoration for the past 2 weeks and hemoptysis for the past 1 week. CT image is taken and is shown below. What is the condition the patient is suffering from?
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario with acute hemoptysis and CT imaging showing a Halo sign is suggestive of invasive aspergillosis.

Aspergillosis is a fungal disease caused by Aspergillus sp. HRCT findings of various types of aspergillosis are:

  • Angioinvasive aspergillosis shows multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation (‘halo sign’) or pleural-based wedge-shaped areas of consolidation.
  • Aspergilloma (saprophytic) shows a mass with soft-tissue attenuation, which is separated from the thoracic wall by airspace called the air crescent sign. Multiple nodules and bilateral involvement may be seen.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA): It is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus species. On HRCT, it manifests as branching tubular opacities that resemble fingers inside a glove. These opacities represent mucus-filled dilated bronchi, often seen in the upper lobes, reflecting the mucus impaction and bronchiectasis characteristic of ABPA.

Other options:

Option A: CT findings in Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) typically include peripheral and bilateral ground-glass opacities, bronchial wall thickening, pulmonary nodules, and pleural effusion. These findings are often associated with clinical features such as asthma and eosinophilia. An image of a CT lung in Churg strauss is shown below


Option C: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) shows patchy subpleural consolidative opacities. A characteristic peribronchiolar/ perilobar opacities with a rim of subpleural sparing called the reverse halo sign is seen.The image given below shows the reversed halo sign:

Option D: Usual interstitial pneumonia pattern is most commonly seen in people with rheumatoid arthritis. The characteristic HRCT findings of UIP are - Bilateral, lower lobe, subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing pattern.

Pearl PM0149: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.
subject: Radiology

question_title:
139.
        A patient diagnosed with stroke was started on anticoagulation 2 days ago by his physician. He now presents to the ER this morning with the following skin changes. On examination, he looked tensed, diaphoretic, BP- 110/70 mm of Hg, PR- 98 BPM, RR - 17 / min. Coagulation studies performed are as follows. What is the cause of the below skin finding?
question_ADD:
Prothrombin Time-  12 seconds (11-15 seconds)

APTT- 31 seconds ( 25-40 seconds)

INR - 2 

Platelet count -2,50,000 cells/mm3

Bleeding time - 3 minutes (1- 8 minutes)
optionA:
A.  Factor V leiden mutation
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

This patient with the skin findings as shown in the image above following consumption of warfarin has developed warfarin-induced skin necrosis. Protein C deficiency is one of the major factor responsible for this.

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that inhibits the vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKORC1), an essential enzyme for activating the vitamin K available in the body. The hepatic synthesis of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as anti-coagulants like protein C and protein S, requires the presence of vitamin K. 

Because protein C has a shorter half-life, the existing protein C depletes before coagulation factors, so hypercoagulation sets in initially. This further leads to skin/tissue necrosis within the first few days of large doses by causing small vessel microthrombosis. 

Heparin “bridging” is when heparin is frequently used when starting warfarin. Heparin activates antithrombin which enables anticoagulation during the initial, transient hypercoagulable state caused by warfarin. Initial heparin therapy reduces the risk of recurrent venous thromboembolism and skin/ tissue necrosis.

Other options:

Option A: Production of mutant factor V (guanine to adenine DNA point mutation ) that is resistant to degradation by activated protein C. Complications include DVT, cerebral vein thrombosis, and recurrent pregnancy loss. Anticoagulants are given in this condition and initiation of warfarin does not cause hypercoagulability.

Option B: Vitamin K deficiency can also cause a similar presentation; however, PT and aPTT will be increased in those patients. This patient had normal coagulation studies.

Option D: Autoantibodies to platelet factor 4 (PF4) combined with heparin cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), which manifests as necrotic skin lesions at heparin injection sites, thrombocytopenia, and arterial or venous thrombosis within 5–10 days of therapy. There has been no exposure to heparin products for this patient.

Pearl PM0609: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban
subject: Medicine

question_title:
141.
        Which of the following statements is not true regarding spina ventosa?
optionA: A. Swelling is an important sign
optionC:
C. Subperiosteal new bone formation is uncommon
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

Subperiosteal reaction is a common feature of spina ventosa, seen in x-ray.

Sclerosis (healing) may also be seen in long standing cases.

Spina ventosa is the name given to tuberculosis of the phalanges of the hand. 

It is a feature of tuberculous dactylitis. This refers to the tuberculosis of short tubular bones, i.e., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.

The infection is lodged in the marrow cavity leading to spindle-shaped expansion or ballooned-out appearance of the bone known as spina ventosa. Periosteal reaction, abscess, and sinus formation are seen and the affected phalanx swells up. 

 

Below is an X-ray image of the spina ventosa showing soft tissue swelling with cortical erosion in the distal part of the proximal phalanx.
subject: Orthopaedics

question_title:
142.
        You are using southern blotting to diagnose sickle cell trait in a patient. The restriction endonuclease binds to the REN site and then the probe attaches to the 1.15kb segment. Which of the following patterns is expected in a patient with a mutation in one gene copy and one normal gene?
explanation:
Explanation

Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA. In this patient with suspected sickle cell trait, the pattern in lane B is likely to be seen on southern blotting. 

In this technique, DNA is extracted from the cells and cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe.

In this patient with a suspected sickle cell trait, there is one normal copy (upper gene) of the gene and one mutated copy of the gene (lower gene).
Now the restriction endonuclease enzyme cuts the normal gene into two parts (1.15Kb segment and 0.2Kb segment). Since the DNA probe binds only to the 1.15Kb segment, it would be identified as a band in the blot. The 0.2Kb segment would get washed away and would not appear as a band in the southern blot.
However, in a mutated gene, there is no site for the restriction endonuclease to bind, leading to the formation of a longer 1.35Kb fragment of DNA. The labeled DNA probe would bind to this segment and a 1.35Kb band would be seen in the southern blot.

Therefore the final blot would have two visible gene bands - one 1.15Kb band (normal gene) and one 1.35Kb band (mutated gene) which is represented by lane B.

Other options: 

Lane A: The band in lane A is from a sickle cell anemia patient with two copies of the mutated gene. This gene results in only the 1.35-kb band because the single mutation damages the endonuclease restriction site.

Lane C: The band in lane C would be seen in an unaffected patient with two copies of the normal gene. The gene results in only the 1.15-kb fragment of DNA cut by the restriction endonuclease enzyme.

Lane D: The bands in lane D cannot be from any patient. The labeled DNA probe does not bind to the 0.2-kb DNA fragment and therefore would not be visualized on the Southern blot.
subject: Biochemistry

question_title:
144.
        A 60-year-old man with a history of diabetes for the past 25 years presented with offensive-smelling discharge and ulceration of the right foot. Which of the following is the most sensitive modality to rule out the involvement of the underlying bone?
explanation:
Explanation

The given scenario is indicative of diabetic foot. MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality to rule out the involvement of underlying bone in this condition.

The etiological agents of diabetic foot infection are:

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Beta-hemolytic streptococci
  • Aerobic gram-negative bacilli.
  • Pseudomonas.
  • Anaerobes.

Fever and systemic symptoms are relatively unusual in diabetic foot infections but, if present, may indicate rapidly advancing infection, bacteremia, or necrotizing fasciitis.  

Plain radiographs may show evidence of osteomyelitis but can be normal (particularly early infection). MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for the diagnosis of bone involvement. The limited disease has a good prognosis, and in the absence of risk factors for resistant organisms (including prior treatment), empirical treatment can be justified.

In extensive or complicated infections, antibiotic therapy should be guided by the results of the culture of deep bone or tissue samples obtained surgically or radiologically. Superficial swabs or cultures from ulcers or sinus tracts are not reliable in determining the organisms responsible for underlying deep-seated infection.

Surgical debridement is required for collections, necrotic areas, or more extensive osteomyelitis. Vascular compromise should be considered a relative contraindication to a surgical approach. In patients with poor peripheral pulses, a full vascular assessment is mandatory. Proximal angioplasty or bypass surgery may improve distal vascularity to a level where infection surgery in the foot may be more successful.

Amputation is not an easy option in diabetic foot disease, and wound healing can be problematic. In general, excision should be adequate to remove all infected material, and excess bone may need to be resected to allow tension-free skin closure. If there is extensive peripheral neuropathy, a below-knee amputation in an area with better sensation may be appropriate.
subject: Surgery

question_title:
145.
        Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the method for antibiotic susceptibility testing shown below?
optionA: A. It is an example of disc diffusion method.
optionB:
B. Minimum inhibitory concentration can be calculated by this method.
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionC: C. The inoculated organism is spread as a lawn culture on a solid medium like Mueller- Hinton Agar.
optionD: D. Zone of  inhibition around each disc shows antibiotic sensitivity.
explanation:
Explanation

The image shown above is Kirby Bauer's disc diffusion method and Minimum inhibitory concentration(MIC) cannot be calculated by this method. 

Kirby Bauer’s disc diffusion method: The inoculated organism is grown as a lawn culture on a specific medium (Cation adjusted Mueller-Hinton Agar) and various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. The zone of complete growth inhibition around each disc is measured. Each measurement is then interpreted to deduce to which antibiotics the organism is resistant or sensitive.

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

  • Diffusion tests: Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method, Stokes disk diffusion method
  • Dilution tests: Broth dilution method, Agar dilution method
  • Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)

Note: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the growth of the microorganism. Kirby–Bauer test cannot be used for calculating MIC.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
146.
        Which of the following conditions is/are not associated with secondary Raynaud phenomenon?
question_ADD:
1. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  2. Scleroderma
  3. Buerger disease
  4. Raynaud's disease
  5. Atherosclerosis
explanation:
Explanation

The option not associated with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon is raynaud’s disease, as it is the primary raynaud's phenomenon, and all others are associated with secondary raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's phenomenon refers to exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles in the extremities, particularly the fingers and toes, but also occasionally the nose, earlobes, or lips. Raynaud's phenomenon can be a primary entity or secondary to other disorders.

Mechanism of raynaud's phenomenon - Restricted blood flow induces paroxysmal pallor, and even cyanosis in severe cases. The involved digits classically show red, white, and blue color changes from the most proximal to the most distal regions. This correlates with proximal vasodilation, central vasoconstriction, and more distal cyanosis.

Raynaud's disease (primary raynaud's phenomenon) is however diagnosed when all the secondary causes of raynaud's phenomenon have been ruled out. It accounts for more than 50% of cases and is more prevalent in women, affecting them about five times more frequently than men. Symptoms typically begin between the ages of 20 and 40 years, with the fingers being more commonly affected than the toes.

The difference between primary and secondary raynaud's phenomenon is given below.

Primary Raynaud

Secondary Raynaud

Caused by exaggerated central and local vasomotor responses to cold or emotion.

Has a predilection for young women.

Results from vascular insufficiency due to arterial disease.

Raynaud disease

Systemic lupus erythematosus

Scleroderma

Buerger's disease

Atherosclerosis

Symmetrically affects the extremities

Asymmetric involvement of the extremities

The severity and extent of involvement typically remain static over time

Progressively worsens in extent and severity over time
subject: Pathology

question_title:
147.
        A 30-year-old P3L3 lady complained of bright red bleeding per vagina 15 days after the vaginal delivery of her 3rd baby. Which among the following options could be the likely cause of this bleeding?
explanation:
Explanation

The clinical vignette with bright red vaginal bleeding on the 15th day of postpartum is secondary postpartum hemorrhage, which can be caused by a placental polyp.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurring between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery is called secondary or late PPH.

Causes of secondary PPH include:

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

It is treated with oxytocin, methyler­gonovine, or a prostaglandin analog if the patient is stable and sonography reveals an empty uterine cavity. Antimicrobials are given if a uterine infection is suspected. Gentle suction curettage can be done if large clots are seen in the uter­ine cavity on sonography, or if bleeding persists after medical management.

Other options: 

Option A: Multiparity can lead to inadequate retraction and frequently adherent placenta and cause primary PPH.

Option B: Perineal lacerations and an atonic uterus are causes of primary PPH. 

Option C: Atonic uterus is one of the causes of primary PPH.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
148.
        Which of the following factors do not contribute to skin colour?
explanation:
Explanation

The number of melanocytes does not contribute to the pigmentation of the skin. There is very little inter-racial variation in the number of melanocytes.

Variation in skin pigmentation is explained by:

  • Differences in melanocyte structure and function
  • Melanogenic activity i.e the amount of melanin produced
  • Size and number of melanosomes
  • Type of melanin deposited onto melanosomes
  • Donation of mature melanosomes to adjacent keratinocytes

Pearl PM1889: Colour of Skin and Fitzpatrick Classification of Skin types

  • The color of the skin is a property of the pigment melanin synthesized by melanocytes.
  • Melanocytes are dendritic cells derived from neural crest cells and are present in the stratum basale of the epidermis.
  • Each melanocyte synthesizes melanin and packs it in cell organelles to form melanosomes. These melanosomes are transferred through dendritic processes to 36 keratinocytes forming the epidermal melanin unit.
  • The main function of melanin is to impart uniform color to the skin. It also protects cells from UV light.
  • Color of skin depends on the following:
    • Amount of melanin inside melanocytes
    • Number and size of melanosomes
    • Degree of transfer of melanin into keratinocytes
  • It does NOT depend on the number of melanocytes. This is because all individuals contain the same number of melanocytes /cm2 of skin area.

Different shades of skin color in humans is due to 2 factors:

  • Difference in number, size, and distribution of melanosomes.
  • Difference in proportion of eumelanin and pheomelanin. 
Eumelanin Pheomelanin
True melanin False melanin
Brown or black pigment Yellow-red pigment
Present in dark-skinned individuals Present in fair-skinned individuals

The different shades have been classified in the Fitzpatrick classification of skin type scale. It is based on tan ability and burn ability of the skin.

Type 1 Type 6
Excess pheomelanin Excess eumelanin
Always burns Never burns
Never tans Always tans
Maximum malignant Potential Least malignant potential
subject: Dermatology

question_title:
149.
        A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised of brachytherapy. Choose the false statement regarding this treatment modality.
optionA: A. Intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to squared distance
optionB:
B. Tandems are placed in the vagina
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionC: C. Point B is 2 cm above and 5 cm lateral  to the external os
optionD:
D. Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

The false statement about this treatment modality is that the tandems are placed in the vagina. The tandems are placed in the uterine cavity whereas the ovoids and colpostats are placed in the vaginal vault.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. It can be either a low-dose or high-dose rate system. High-dose brachytherapy is safe and effective.

Dosage is calculated with respect to the amount of radiation received at two arbitrary points A and B (image below).

  Point A Point B
Location 2cm above and 2cm lateral to the external os 2cm above and 5cm lateral to the external os
Structure present crossing of the ureter and uterine artery Obturator lymph node
Dose of radiation 7000-8000 cGy 6000 cGy (2000 cGy by brachytherapy + 4000 cGy by external beam radiotherapy)

 

Different techniques of brachytherapy:

 Techniques Device  No. of application Duration
Stockholm 

Intrauterine tandem

One vaginal plaque

 Three 24 hours each weekly
Paris

Intrauterine tandem

Three vaginal ovoids

 One 120 hours
Manchester

Intrauterine tandem

Two vaginal ovoids

 TWo 72 hours each weekly

Radiation dose in surrounding normal tissue is less due to inverse square law (Inverse square law - the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to squared distance from the source of radiation). This method is unsuitable for large tumours and has potential risks of radiation exposure to medical staff.

Note: After loading technique by remote control is the recent development of brachytherapy. It protects the staff from radiation exposure.
