question_title:
150.
        A 30-year-old male patient presents to the Suraksha clinic with lesions on his genitals, as shown in the image below. Which of the following STI treatment kits would you recommend for this patient?
explanation:
Explanation

The image shows a cluster of vesicles over the penis which points toward the diagnosis of genital herpes infection. It is treated with kit 5 or the red kit, which contains acyclovir 400 mg to be taken orally TID for 7 days. No partner treatment is required.

Genital herpes is more commonly caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) 2. The patients present with painful vesicular-ulcerative lesions. In men, it occurs mainly on the penis or urethra. In women, the cervix, vagina, vulva, and perineum can be involved. The primary infection causes serious symptoms accompanied by fever and malaise, followed by recurrent episodes. A cesarean section is performed in a case of active genital herpes at the time of labor in order to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes. The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is in the face, the cheeks, the chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead.

The Tzanck smear technique is a rapid and inexpensive diagnostic method. Scrapings (preferably from the base of vesicles) are obtained from the lesions and stained with a  1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, known as Tzanck cells, are seen. Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles in Giemsa-stained smears.

The following image shows histology of HSV inclusion bodies.

Pearl PM2024: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Pearl PM0008: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

Pearl PM2456: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:
subject: Dermatology

question_title:
151.
        Which among the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown in the image?
optionA:
A. Used for delivery in a platypelloid pelvis
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionB: B. Most commonly used for rotational delivery
optionC: C. Most commonly used forceps in outlet delivery
optionD:
D. It is used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The image shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of breech.

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

It maybe applied electively or when the Mauriceau manoeuvre cannot be accomplished easily.

Pearl PM1839: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

Pearl PM0040: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
152.
        A 21-year-old young man presents with a neck mass. Past history is significant for surgical removal of a pheochromocytoma 6 months ago. On examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following should the patient be screened for?
explanation:
Explanation

This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome. This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. 

The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrine organs. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).

MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizes more frequently in MEN2B syndrome.

Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.

Pearl PM1137: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon
subject: Pathology

question_title:
153.
        What is the punishment for a doctor on the first offence for sex determination under the PCPNDT Act?
question_ADD: PCPNDT- Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques
explanation:
Explanation

Under the PCPNDT Act, a doctor convicted of a first offence for sex determination can be punished with imprisonment for up to three years or a fine of up to ten thousand rupees. If convicted again, the punishment increases to imprisonment for up to five years and a fine of up to fifty thousand rupees.

Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques Act, 1994 is an act of the Parliament of India enacted to stop female foeticides and arrest the declining sex ratio in India.

It aimed at preventing gender-based sex selection and ensuring ethical practices in pre-conception and prenatal diagnostic procedures. The Act is designed to regulate the use of diagnostic techniques and to curb practices that lead to sex-selective abortions. 

Key Objectives:

  • Prohibit Sex Selection: The Act prohibits the use of pre-conception and prenatal diagnostic techniques for determining the sex of the fetus with the intent of aborting female fetuses. This is to prevent female feticide and promote gender equality.
  • Regulate Diagnostic Techniques: It regulates the use of technologies such as ultrasound and amniocentesis, ensuring they are used only for legitimate medical purposes and not for sex determination.

Registration and Regulation:

  • Genetic Clinics and Laboratories: Facilities providing prenatal diagnostic services, including genetic clinics, laboratories, and ultrasound centres, must be registered with the appropriate authority.
  • Equipment and Personnel: The Act mandates specific qualifications for personnel performing diagnostic procedures and requires proper registration and record maintenance.

Consent Requirement: Before performing any pre-natal diagnostic procedures, practitioners must obtain written informed consent from the patient, explaining all potential risks and the nature of the procedure.

Documentation: Clinics must maintain detailed records of all procedures, including patient details and the nature of the diagnostic tests performed.

Penalties: Violations of the Act, such as illegal sex determination or failure to maintain proper records, can result in imprisonment, fines, and professional sanctions. Violations of the PCPNDT Act are classified as cognizable offences.
subject: Forensic Medicine

question_title:
154.
        A 43-year-old lady comes with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, and itching over her arms and legs. On examination, icterus and mild hepatomegaly are seen. Liver function tests show deranged values with elevated serum IgG levels. The patient also tests negative for viral hepatitis markers. Which of the following characteristic histopathological features suggests the diagnosis?
optionB: B. Bile duct injury and granulomas
explanation:
Explanation

The clinical features along with increased serum IgG levels and absence of viral hepatitis markers indicates autoimmune hepatitis (AIH).  The characteristic histopathological picture seen in AIH is cluster of plasma cells and lymphocytes at the interface between the portal tract and liver lobule is known as interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:

  • Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
  • Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.
  • Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

 

Below is a histopathological image of AIH.

 

The simplified scoring system for the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis includes four variables. They are:

  1. Autoantibodies
  2. Elevated serum IgG level
  3. Typical compatible histologic features
  4. Absence of viral hepatitis markers

A small number of drugs such as minocycline, nitrofurantoin, and α-methyldopa can trigger the formation of autoantibodies and hepatocellular injury that mimics autoimmune hepatitis.

Other options:

Option A: Ground glass hepatocytes are characteristically found in Hepatitis B and are a diagnostic hallmark.

Option B: Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option C: Councilman bodies are seen in acute viral hepatitis. They are apoptotic hepatocytes that are deeply eosinophilic stained.

Pearl PM2264: Types of autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)

  Type I AIH Type II AlH
Characteristic antibodies Anti-SMA (F-actin), ANA, pANCA, anti-SLA/LP, anti-AMA antibodies Anti-LKM1, anti-liver cytosol 1
Age of onset Bimodal, peaks at 10–20 years and 45–70 years 2–14 years
Gender distribution 78% female 89% female
lgG increase Pronounced Moderate
lgA decrease Absent Occasional
Association with HLA haplotypes B8, DR3, DR4 B14, DR3

Type III autoimmune hepatitis does not appear to represent a distinct category but, instead, is part of the spectrum of type I autoimmune hepatitis

  • ANA: Anti-nuclear antibodies
  • anti-SMA: Anti–smooth muscle actin antibodies
  • anti-SLA/LP: Anti–soluble liver antigen/liver–pancreas antigen
  • AMA: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies
  • anti-LKM: Liver–kidney microsomal antibodies
  • pANCA: Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

Pearl PM2257: Acute Hepatitis vs. Chronic Hepatitis

Histological features of acute hepatitis Histological features of chronic hepatitis
Ballooning degeneration Ductular reaction
Apoptosis of hepatocytes - Councilman bodies  Bridging fibrosis 
Confluent necrosis Bridging necrosis
Spotty necrosis or lobular hepatitis  Interface hepatitis 
Bridging necrosis in severe acute hepatitis Dense, mononuclear portal infiltration 
Portal inflammation is absent  Chronic viral hepatitis
  Ground glass hepatocytes 
  Lymphoid aggregates or fully formed lymphoid follicles
  Fatty change of scattered hepatocytes
subject: Pathology

question_title:
155.
        Choose the false statement regarding the following instrument which is used for visual field charting.
optionA:
A. It can evaluate both peripheral as well as central fields
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionB: B. 24-2 pattern is most commonly used to assess glaucoma
optionC: C. It is an automated test
optionD:
D. It uses kinetic method of perimetry
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The given image shows a Humphrey visual field analyzer. It is an automated test that uses the static method of perimetry i.e. the location of a stimulus remains fixed, with intensity increased until it is seen by the subject (threshold is reached) or decreased until it is no longer detected.

It can evaluate both peripheral as well as the central field. (option A)

It is most commonly used in interpreting visual field defects in glaucoma, and other neurological lesions.

Central visual fields are most commonly tested.

  1. Central 24-2 test
    • Most commonly used to assess glaucoma (Option B)
    • 54 points are examined in the central 24 degrees.
    • '24’ denotes the extent in degrees to which the field is tested on the temporal side (to 30° on the nasal side). The number after the hyphen (2) describes the pattern of the points tested.
  2. Central 30-2 test
    • Most comprehensive form of visual field assessment of the central 30 degrees.
    • It consists of 76 points 6 degrees apart on either side of the vertical and horizontal axes, such that the inner most points are three degrees from the fixation point.
  3. Central 10-2 test.
    • Assess 68 points 2 degrees apart in the central 10 degree are examined.
    • Especially used to monitor advanced glaucoma.
  4. Macular grid test 
    • Assess the central 5 degrees.
    • Examines 10 points spaced on a 29 degree square grid centred on the point of fixation.

Perimetry: Visual field charting

Classification:

  • Manual: Confrontation, Listers, Campimetry, Goldmann perimeter
  • Automated: Octopus, Field Master, Humphrey Field Analyzer
  • Static: Friedman, Automated
  • Kinetic: Confrontation, Listers, Scotometry, Goldmann

The best type is automated perimetry.

The image given below shows Lister's perimeter.

 

The image below shows the confrontation method for testing the visual field.

 

The image given below shows Goldmann perimeter.

 

The following image depicts the printout of the results obtained from the Humphrey field analyser.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_title:
156.
        A patient presented with features suggestive of acute interstitial nephritis. A microscopy of his urinary casts is shown below. These casts are most likely those of _____.
optionD:
D. White blood cell casts
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

In the given scenario, the patient is having features of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). So, the casts shown are most likely those of white blood cell casts.

AIN usually occurs as an allergic response to certain medications. The most common offending agents are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. It can also occur with proton pump inhibitors, sulfonamide derivatives and sulfasalazine. 

Individuals with AIN are usually asymptomatic and are incidentally found to have elevated creatinine.  However, in some instances, they can develop fever and rash. In severe cases, renal failure with proteinuria can occur. 

Laboratory studies may show peripheral eosinophilia and urinary eosinophilia. The urinalysis usually shows pyuria and occasionally eosinophiluria. But the most characteristic cell types are activated T lymphocytes and plasma cells, along with a few white blood cell casts. 

Other options: 

Option A: Broad casts are seen in chronic renal failure.

Option B: Hyaline casts may be seen normally and are non-specific.

Option D: Red blood cell casts are seen in acute glomerulonephritis.

Pearl PM1885: Urinary Casts and Their Significance
subject: Medicine

question_title:
157.
        Increased thickness of layer C leads to.
explanation:
Explanation

The layer marked as C is stratum spinosum. Increased thickness of stratum spinosum is called acanthosis.

Histopathological terminologies used for skin conditions:

  1. Hyperkeratosis: increased thickness of stratum corneum (layer A).
  2. Hypergranulosis: increased thickness of stratum granulosum (layer B).
  3. Parakeratosis: retention of the nucleus in the stratum corneum. 
  4. Acanthosis: increased thickness of stratum spinosum (layer C).

Hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis are seen in psoriasis.

Spongiosis is seen in acute eczema.

Acantholysis which refers to the separation of keratinocytes is seen in vesico-bullous disorders.
subject: Dermatology

question_title:
158.
        A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric OPD with a history of diarrhoea for 1 day. The mid-arm circumference of the child is 10 cm. Which of the following is not present in the rehydration solution advised for this child?
explanation:
Explanation

A 2-year-old child with a mid-arm circumference of 10 cm (<11.5cm) is having severe acute malnutrition and the rehydration solution used for inpatient management of diarrhoea in a child with SAM is ReSoMal. ReSoMal contains 3 minerals magnesium, zinc, and copper. 

The composition of ReSoMal and ORS are as follows:

Component (mmol/l) Standard ORS ReSoMal
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 125
Sodium 75 45
Potassium 20 40
Chloride 65 70
Citrate 10 7
Magnesium - 3
Zinc - 0.3
Copper - 0.045
Osmolality 245 300

Compared to the standard ORS, ReSoMal contains less sodium to prevent complications related to fluid overload and overhydration. Glucose, potassium, and chloride are more than the ORS. Zinc helps in GI re-epithelialization and prevents recurrence. Magnesium is important for nerve, and muscle function and is an important cofactor for many enzymes. Copper plays a role in immunity and iron metabolism. ReSoMal is however contraindicated in cholera or profuse watery diarrhoea.

question_title:
159.
        A pressure tracing curve is shown below. Which process is typically implicated in development of the patient's condition?
explanation:
Explanation

The pressure tracing in the given image shows a large pressure gradient between the aorta and the left ventricle in systole and is suggestive of valvular aortic stenosis. The most likely pathology in aortic stenosis is dystrophic calcification of the semilunar valves. 

The images below show a normal pressure gradient between the aorta and the left ventricle and the arrows in the 2nd image demonstrates a large pressure gradient between the aorta and the left ventricle:


When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e. the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis. Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option B: Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia, or in conditions associated with an abnormality of calcium metabolism.

Option C: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels with deposition of fibrinoid material such as various vasculitis syndromes.

Option D: Libman Sacks Endocarditis is a fibrinous endocarditis typically seen in association with systemic lupus erythematosus and is associated with aortic regurgitation, not aortic stenosis. It is an example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction.

Pearl PM2357: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure
subject: Pathology

question_title:
160.
        Lymphatic drainage of prostate is into
optionA:
A. Internal iliac lymph nodes
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD:
D. Superficial inguinal lymph nodes
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
explanation:
Explanation

Lymphatic vessels from the prostate drain mainly in the internal iliac, sacral, and obturator lymph nodes.

Important to note is that lymphatic drainage of the prostate is highly variable. Many of the lymph vessels from the prostate anastomoses with their counterparts of several neighboring organs, for example the urinary bladder and rectum. This can have important clinical implications, especially in cases of prostate cancer.

Pearl PM2214: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING
Para - aortic lymph nodes Ovaries /Testis
External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e
subject: Anatomy

question_title:
161.
        A patient diagnosed with a parathyroid adenoma was posted for a parathyroidectomy. Her preoperative parathormone was 150 pg/mL. Her parathormone levels fell by 33% at 10 minutes post-excision. What should the surgeon do next?
question_ADD:
Parathormone - (PTH)

Normal Range of PTH - 10-65 pg/mL
optionA: A. Check the level of PTH again.
optionB:
B. Measure the serum calcium levels. 
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionC:
C. Convert to bilateral neck exploration. 
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

In this clinical scenario, PTH's value has fallen by 33% and as the fall is less than 50% of the maximum preoperative PTH level, as per the Miami criteria, bilateral neck exploration should be done to identify multi-gland disease.

The Miami criteria were developed to ensure the adequacy of resection in parathyroid surgery. It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to the normal range and less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed through an incision less than 3 cm. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure no other hyperactive gland remains by performing an intraoperative PTH assay which is interpreted based on the Miami criteria.

However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration. At times during bilateral neck exploration, all four glands are removed and a forearm autotransplant of parathyroid tissue in the brachioradialis muscle is done.
subject: Surgery

question_title:
162.
        The virulence factors of Candida albicans include:
question_ADD:
1. Polysaccharide capsule
  2. Phospholipase
  3. Phenol oxidase
  4. Secreted aspartyl proteinase
explanation:
Explanation

The virulence factors of Candida albicans include Phospholipase (PLB1) and secreted aspartyl proteinases (SAP). 

Virulence factors of candida species:

  • Agglutinin-like sequence (ALS) surface glycoproteins bind to the host cell membrane receptors and mediate attachment to the epithelial and endothelial cells.
  • Secreted aspartyl proteinases (SAPs) degrade host cell membranes and destroy immunoglobulins.
  • Phospholipase (PLB1) is secreted by the yeasts and pseudohyphae.
  • Fungal biofilm, protected by the extracellular matrix material prevents the penetration of the host’s immune response and antifungal drugs.

Other options : 

The polysaccharide capsule and laccase (phenol oxidase) are the virulence factors of Cryptococcus neoformans.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

Pearl PM2347: Types of capsules in microorganisms

Capsule  Organsim
Polysaccharide capsule 

 Streptococcus pneumonia

 Klebsiella pneumonia

 Hemophilius influenza

 Neiserria meningitidis

 Salmonella typhi

 Cryptococcus neoformans

 Bordetella pertussis

Clostridium perfringens
Hyaluronic acid capsule  Streptococcus pyogenes
Polypeptide (Poly-D -Glutamate) Capsule  Bacillus anthracis
F1 Protein Capsule  Yersinia pestis
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
163.
        A 50-year-old P4L4 patient presented with complaints of involuntary passage of urine on coughing. Which of the following procedures for this condition, is carried out using a vaginal approach?
explanation:
Explanation

The procedure among the following options that use a vaginal approach and is suitable for the clinical scenario suggestive of stress urinary incontinence is Kelly's repair.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) occurs when increased abdominal pressure causes urine leakage because bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure without any detrusor muscle contraction. It is characterized by small amounts of involuntary urine leakage during physical activities or stress, without a detrusor contraction.

The various surgical procedures for GSI are as follows:

  • Vaginal approach
    • Kelly's repair
    • Pacey's repair
  • Abdominal approach
    • Burch colposuspension
    • Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation 
  • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension 
    • Pereyra operation
  • Slings 
    • Tension-free vaginal taping (TVT) - retro-pubic approach
    • Transobturator taping (TOT) - approach via the obturator foramen
  • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
  • Periurethral collagen injection
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
164.
        A 23-year-old sexually active man presents with fever, malaise, and severe pain in his right knee. Joint aspirate is cloudy and reveals multiple neutrophils but no organisms on gram stain. What is the likely cause of his disease?
explanation:
Explanation

This clinical scenario of a sexually active patient with joint pain and fever with a joint aspirate showing neutrophils and no organisms should raise concerns for supportive arthritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea. 

Neisseria gonorrhoea is commonly implicated in sexually active young adults and joint aspirates are usually sterile(no organism seen on gram stain) in only up to 30% of patients. Thus diagnosis should be made on clinical suspicion. Disseminated gonococcal infection causes gonococcal arthritis. It comprises localized septic arthritis and arthritis-dermatitis syndrome. Other manifestations like endocarditis, pericarditis, osteomyelitis, and meningitis are extremely rare.

Joint or tendon pain is the most common accompanying feature. Tenosynovitis often affects the hands and fingers. One-third of the patients may proceed to suppurative arthritis, most commonly of the knee. Migratory polyarthralgia affects the knees, elbows, wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and ankle joints.

Lab diagnosis involves the collection of vaginal or urethral discharge which is then subjected to Gram stain, revealing gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

The image below shows gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhoea.

Other options: 

Option A and D: Gardnerella vaginalis and Ureaplasma urealyticum are common sexually transmitted organisms however, they are unlikely to cause septic arthritis in the individuals.

Option C: Treponema species are not associated with the development of septic arthritis. 

Pearl PM2456: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Pearl PM2024: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
165.
        Which of the following features is least likely to be associated with vitiligo?
optionA: A. It is commonly affects the extensor areas of skin
optionB:
B. It is associated with pseudo-koebner phenomenon
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionC: C. It shows milky-white fluorescence under wood's lamp
optionD: D. It is commonly associated with pernicious anemia
explanation:
Explanation

It is associated with pseudo-koebner phenomenon is the incorrect statement. Vitiligo is associated with koebner phenomenon.

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions. It is commonly seen in immune-mediated conditions like vitiligo and lichen planus.

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon refers to the appearance of lesions in previously unaffected skin following trauma, but unlike the true Koebner phenomenon, it involves the spread of an infectious agent rather than an inherent disease response to trauma. For example. HPV, mechanical trauma

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of skin. It is classified as

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. Non-segmental can either be focal vitiligo or undetermined/unclassified vitiligo.

Clinical features:

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. (Option A) These are the areas of repeated friction. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Vitiligo universalis, which is complete vitiligo, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, hyperpigmentation, as well as areas of normal skin may be seen rarely.

Several autoimmune conditions can be associated with vitiligo. They are:

  • Thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism)
  • Pernicious anemia (Option D)
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes
  • Hypoparathyroidism

Examination:

Under the Wood's lamp examination the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white or milky-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated. (Option C)

Treatment:

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and the use of sunscreen. The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus have also shown to be successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, and selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatment. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Faint yellow

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Pearl PM1956: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Pearl PM1911: Algorithm for the differential diagnosis of Hypomelanosis

question_title:
166.
        A 55-year-old man is started on hydrochlorothiazide for the treatment of hypertension. Which of the following complications is he least likely to develop?
explanation:
Explanation
Thiazide diuretics are associated with hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.
 
Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide:
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Rashes
  • Headache
  • Gastrointestinal upset
  • Dizziness
  • Erectile dysfunction

Pearl PM0486: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Diuretics Sodium Potassium Calcium
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors ↑ ↑↑ No change
Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

question_title:
167.
        A 8-year-old male child is brought with complaints of restricted joint movement and difficulty to walk due to progressive limb contracture . On examination, the child had coarse facial features, macrocephaly, hepatosplenomegaly,  umbilical hernia and cloudy cornea. However his IQ was normal. Which of the following recombinant enzymes is useful in treating this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

A child presenting with contractures, coarse facial features, visceromegaly, cloudy cornea with normal IQ points to the diagnosis of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome. Naglazyme a.k.a Galsulfase is used in the treatment of this condition.

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type VI is caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase B enzyme. Preservation of intelligence is the feature of this syndrome. . It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, disproportionate short stature, umbilical hernia, marked corneal clouding, frequent respiratory illness or otitis media, cardiac defects, contractures and Carpal tunnel syndrome.  

Rapidly progressive Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome is associated with an onset of symptoms before three years of age. Affected individuals may develop walking problems (impaired mobility) by the age of 10 and experience delayed or absence of puberty. 

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
MPS with no corneal clouding: Hunter’s disease and Sanfilippo syndrome
MPS with XLR inheritance: Hunter’s disease
MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease
Skeletal deformity associated with all MPS: Dysostosis multiplex
MPS with no leucocyte inclusions: Morquio’s disease

Other options:

Option A: Aldurazyme a.k.a Laronidase in the treatment of Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is associated with mental retardation, which is not seen in this patient.

Option C:  Elaprase a.k.a Idursulfase is used in the treatment of this Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II. Corneal clouding is not a feature of Hunter's disease.

Option D: Myozyme a.k.a alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase is used in the treatment of Pompe's disease. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding. Where as in this child there is no hypotonia, instead has contractures of limbs.
