question_title:
168.
        A chronic alcoholic patient presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. He had similar episodes in the past along with steatorrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. Which of the following radiological tests is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
question_ADD:
ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography

CT - Computed Tomography
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis and ERCP is the gold standard investigation for this condition.

Pancreatic calcifications can be seen on abdominal X-rays.

Endoscopic ultrasound showing the presence of four or more of the following features is highly suggestive of chronic pancreatitis:

  • Presence of stones
  • Visible side branches
  • Cysts
  • Lobularity
  • An irregular main pancreatic duct
  • Hyperechoic foci and strands
  • Dilatation of the main pancreatic duct
  • Hyperechoic margins of the main pancreatic duct  

An abdominal CT scan is the initial modality of choice for diagnosing chronic pancreatitis. CT or MRI scan will show the outline of the gland, the main area of damage, and the possibilities for surgical correction.

The investigation of choice for chronic pancreatitis is MRCP with secretin stimulation. ERCP is the gold-standard investigation. ERCP is the best way to get detailed information about the ducts and the overall shape of the gland.

Pearl PM1641: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus
subject: Surgery

question_title:
169.
        A 38-year-old mountaineer who has been missing for 12 hours is brought in a semi-conscious state. His heart rate is 26 beats per minute and BP is 70/40 mmHg. Despite initial therapy with rewarming and iv atropine, his heart rate remains critically low, and he continues to exhibit cold, clammy skin, and rapid, shallow breathing. The attending physician decides to initiate an adrenaline infusion. What is the recommended dosage range for adrenaline infusion in this situation?
question_ADD: IV- Intravenous
explanation:
Explanation

The recommended infusion rate of intravenous adrenaline for symptomatic bradycardia after initial treatment with atropine is 2-10 mcg/min or 0.002-0.01 mg/min.

Atropine 0.5 mg IV every 3 to 5 minutes to a maximum total dose of 3 mg is the initial line of management for symptomatic bradycardia but if its ineffective, then adrenaline / dopamine infusion should be started. 

Pearl PM0190: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG 

If the bradyarrhythmia is persisent causing hemodynamic instability, then the management is as depicted by the flowchart (based on the AHA guidelines) below:
subject: Anaesthesia

question_title:
170.
        A 52 year old woman, known case of SLE, on chronic glucocorticoid therapy, presented to the emergency with acute appendicitis and underwent an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy without any complications. Post-operatively the patient becomes hypotensive with BP <90/60 mm Hg despite multiple intravenous fluid boluses. Which of the following is the best immediate step in management?
question_ADD:
SLE - systemic lupus erythematosus

RLQ - Right lower quadrant
optionD: D. CT scan of the abdomen
explanation:
Explanation

The patient is experiencing sudden onset refractory hypotension after surgery, which is highly suggestive of acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal crisis). In adrenal crisis, the hypotension is often resistant to fluid resuscitation alone. Therefore, the best immediate management step is administering intravenous hydrocortisone in addition to aggressive volume repletion.

An adrenal crisis may occur when individuals with chronic adrenal insufficiency (AI) encounter acute stressors like illness or surgery. This patient's medical history includes systemic lupus erythematosus, often requiring prednisone treatment during flares. Long-term glucocorticoid use can lead to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and subsequent secondary AI. Due to the impaired ability of their pituitary gland to increase ACTH secretion during times of stress, these patients face a heightened risk of experiencing an adrenal crisis.

Adrenal crisis primarily presents with hypotension and shock because cortisol plays an important role in maintaining vascular tone. Hypoglycemia may also be present.

Option (A, B, D) CT scan of the abdomen might aid in diagnosing postoperative hemorrhage causing shock, dobutamine infusion is used to treat cardiogenic shock, and intramuscular epinephrine is used in the treatment of anaphylactic shock. However, this patient's history of chronic glucocorticoid use makes adrenal crisis due to secondary Al more likely.
subject: Medicine

question_title:
171.
        In the case of a patient diagnosed with pneumonia on antibiotics who returns with worsening right lower chest pain on inspiration and a fever of 102°F. Given pleural fluid analysis showing frank pus with a pH of 5.0, what is the most appropriate next step in managing this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

In a patient presenting with worsening right lower chest pain, a fever of 102°F, and pleural fluid analysis revealing frank pus with a pH of 5.0, the most appropriate next step is tube thoracostomy (chest tube drainage). This clinical scenario suggests empyema, a severe form of parapneumonic effusion characterized by the accumulation of pus in the pleural space following bacterial infection.

Parapneumonic effusion is pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia, lung abscess, or bronchiectasis. Empyema typically occurs as a complication of pneumonia, marked by a significantly low pleural fluid pH (<7.2), the presence of pus, and often negative or slow-growing bacterial cultures. It indicates an advanced stage of infection where simple antibiotic therapy alone is inadequate. Tube thoracostomy is essential for draining the pus, relieving symptoms, and promoting recovery.

Parapneumonic pleural effusions are categorized as follows:

  • Uncomplicated parapneumonic effusions are exudative and neutrophilic, with negative gram stain and culture, glucose level > 60 mg/dL, and pH > 7.20.
  • Complicated parapneumonic effusions result from bacterial invasion, characterized by decreased glucose levels and pH < 7.20. Despite negative cultures, rapid bacterial clearance or low bacterial counts may be present, necessitating drainage for resolution.
  • Empyema thoracis involves frank pus or evidence of bacterial infection in the pleural fluid via gram stain or positive culture.

Investigations commonly done include: 

  • Chest X-ray: 
    • Loculations or encystments indicate a complicated parapneumonic effusion
    • Intrapleural air-fluid level indicates the presence of bronchopulmonary fistula
    • Parenchymal infiltrations in the lung lobes indicate an underlying pneumonia

Chest X-ray depicting empyema thoracis on the right side is given below.

  • Ultrasound: Shows echogenic pleural fluid with septations and helps in characterizing the effusion
  • Pleural fluid analysis:
    • Exudative neutrophilic effusion 
    • Low pH <7.2, low glucose <60 mg/dL, high LDH >1000 IU/L in complicated parapneumonic effusion
  • CECT: Split pleura sign seen in empyema (given in the image below)

Other options:

Option B: Surgical decortication is considered for more chronic cases with fibrous encasement of the lung, typically after initial drainage has failed. 

Option C: Thoracocentesis may provide temporary relief or be useful for diagnostic purposes but is not a definitive treatment for empyema. 

Option D: High-dose parenteral antibiotics are critical in managing the underlying infection but are not sufficient without drainage. Therefore, immediate tube thoracostomy is crucial to manage the empyema effectively and prevent further complications.
subject: Medicine

question_title:
172.
        Which of the following is at the transpyloric plane?
optionA:
A. Origin of celiac trunk
                
                  
                  
                    
Incorrect
optionC:
C. Origin of portal vein
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionD: D. Lower limit of spinal cord in neonates
explanation:
Explanation

Origin of portal vein occurs at the transpyloric plane (L1).

Other options:

Uncinate process of pancreas is at L2 level.

Celiac trunk is at T12 vertebral level.

Lower limit of spinal cord in neonates is at upper border of L3.

Pearl PM0592: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.
subject: Anatomy

question_title:
173.
        From the following image, identify the structure that marks the boundary between the embryological basal plate and alar plate.
explanation:
Explanation

The structure marked as 3 is the sulcus limitans which is a longitudinal groove that marks the boundary between the basal and alar plates.

Embryologically, the continuous addition of neuroblasts to the mantle layer of the neural tube produces thickenings ventrally and dorsally - producing the basal and alar plates respectively. 

Basal Plate  Alar plate 
Ventral thickening Dorsal thickenings
Give rise to motor nuclei - general visceral efferent nuclei, special visceral efferent of CN IX, X, and XII; and somatic efferent of XII

Give rise to sensory nuclei  CN V, VII, VIII, IX, X, inferior  olivary nucleus, and  mesencephalic nucleus of  CN V
Forms the motor part of the spinal cord (ventral horns)

Forms the sensory part of the spinal cord (dorsal horns). 

The rhombic lip develops into  the cerebellum and its nuclei. 

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

  • Ridges:
    • Transverse fibers: Striae medullares
    • Striae medullaris divides rhomboid fossa into 2 parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary
  • Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:
    • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
    • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
    • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
    • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)
  • Upper and lower ends of sulcus:
    • Bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
    • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
    • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea
subject: Anatomy

question_title:
174.
        A 17-year-old boy who is a long-distance cyclist presents with complaints of knee pain over the past month. He does not recall falling or experiencing any injury. A skyline view of his knees shows a bipartite patella. Which is the most appropriate management in this case?
optionB:
B. NSAIDs and activity restriction
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The most appropriate management in this case is NSAIDs and activity restriction. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can help alleviate pain and inflammation, while rest and modification of activities can reduce stress on the knee.

A bipartite patella (two-part patella) is a patella with an unfused accessory ossification centre, typically at the superolateral aspect. It usually is asymptomatic and is noted incidentally, however pain, when present, can be caused by overuse (such as in a cyclist or climber).

The X-ray below shows the bipartite patella: 

There are three types of bipartite patella

  1. Type I (5%) occurs at the inferior pole
  2. Type II (20%) occurs along the entire lateral border of the patella
  3. Type III (75%) the most common type, occurs as an elliptical area in the superolateral portion of the patella.           

Depending on the number of fragments they may be classified as bipartite, tripartite or multipartite.

For diagnosis, a conventional skyline view is followed by a skyline view with the patient in a squatting weight-bearing position to assess if the pain is caused by a nonunion at the bipartite site. If the gap is higher in the squatting weight-bearing posture than in the standard skyline view, the test result is considered positive.

MRI is not required to diagnose the condition.

Treatment:

If pain occurs with a bipartite patella, limiting and restricting activity, correcting the activity that is causing an overuse syndrome, and prescribing nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents can result in improvement in 3 weeks. 

Other options:

Option A: Above Knee Cast: This is generally not appropriate for a bipartite patella, as it does not address the underlying issue and is not effective in managing the condition.

Option C and D: Surgical treatment with the Ogata technique is rarely necessary. Surgery may be considered only if the patient has persistent symptoms that do not improve with conservative treatment. This is not the first-line approach and is reserved for cases where conservative measures fail.
subject: Orthopaedics

question_title:
175.
        While monitoring the saturation of a patient using a pulse oximeter, an intern records readings of SpO2 between 80% to 85% even with a flow of 100% oxygen. Which of the following conditions will lead to these pulse oximetry readings irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2)?
explanation:
Explanation

In a patient with methemoglobinemia, the pulse oximetry reading will be 80% to 85% irrespective of arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2). 

Carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin absorb light at one or both of the wavelengths used by the pulse oximeter. Therefore, the presence of these Hb species in the blood leads to errors in SpO2 readings. In a patient with methemoglobinemia, the SpO2 will be 80% to 85%, irrespective of the SaO2, and a patient with carbon monoxide poisoning will have a falsely elevated SpO2 level.

Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin. The pulse oximeter probe consists of a light emitter and a photodetector. Transmission pulse oximetry involves placing the emitter and detector on opposite sides of the tissue that is being measured, which is usually the finger.

Potential reasons for artifacts in measurement with a pulse oximeter are given in the table below:

Falsely increased O2 saturation value

  • Carboxy-hemoglobinemia
  • Intra-aortic balloon pump
  • Severe hyper-bilirubinemia

Falsely decreased O2 saturation value

  • Anemia
  • Hypotension (blood pressure- BP<80 mm Hg)
  • Application of nail paint and henna
  • Venous pulsations 

SpO2 estimates the SaO2 of circulating hemoglobin but does not provide information about tissue oxygenation, ventilation, or acid-base status.

Conditions that show inaccuracies in pulse oximeter readings include:

  • Variant hemoglobin species- carboxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin
  • Motion artifacts - SpO2 is decreased compared to SaO2.
  • Venous pulsation
  • The presence of intravascular dyes- methylene blue decreases SpO2 to 65%
  • Presence of nail polish- black, purple, and dark blue show lower SpO2.
subject: Anaesthesia

question_title:
176.
        The illustration given below is used for which female genital pathology?
explanation:
Explanation

The given image shows POP-Q (pelvic organ prolapse quantification) system which was described by the Interna­tional Continence Society for the prolapse of pelvic organs and has the following features:

  • The hymen is taken as a fixed point 
  • Six reference points are measured, using a scaled spatula:
    • Two on the anterior vaginal wall 
    • Two on the apical vagina
    • Two on the posterior vaginal wall 
  • Three measurements: The genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length.
  • The points above the hymen are described as minus and points below as plus.

Staging of POP Q:

Stage Description
Stage 0 No descent of pelvic organs.
Stage 1 The leading edge of the prolapse is >1 cm above the level of the hymen.
Stage 2 The leading edge of the prolapse is <1cm proximal or distal to the hymen.
Stage 3 The leading point of prolapse is >1cm below the hymen but protrudes no further than 2 cm less than the total length of the vagina.
Stage 4 Complete eversion of vagina

 

 

Option D: Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor, in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
177.
        A 68-year-old male presents with pain in his right upper abdominal quadrant. Examination shows a vesicular rash along the 7th rib border that does not cross the midline. Which of the following would have prevented this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

The given stem describing unilateral, grouped vesicles in a single dermatome associated with pain is highly suggestive of reactivated herpes zoster(shingles). This could have been prevented by receiving two doses of the recombinant zoster vaccine. 

This condition arises from the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which lies dormant in the dorsal root ganglia after a prior infection with chickenpox (varicella). Zoster is a self‐limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

The most effective preventive measure for shingles is the recombinant zoster vaccine. This vaccine is recommended for all individuals aged 50 and older, as well as for those with compromised immune systems who are not severely immunocompromised. It is designed to boost the immune response in older adults who are at increased risk of shingles due to age-related immune decline.

The recombinant zoster vaccine is administered as a two-dose series, with the second dose given 2-6 months after the first. Common side effects include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site, along with mild fever and fatigue. These side effects are typically brief and resolve without intervention. This vaccine is more potent than the varicella vaccine given to children, making it suitable for older adults who may not respond as well to the varicella vaccine.

Other options: 

Option B: The pneumococcal conjugate vaccine prevents infections caused by Streptococcus pneumonia. 

Option C: The oka varicella vaccine is intended for children, but is not as effective for preventing shingles in adults. hile the varicella vaccine, intended for children, is not as effective for preventing shingles in adults. The meningococcal vaccine targets Neisseria meningitidis infections and is generally given to adolescents and young adults.

Option D: Meningococcal vaccine is used for the prevention of meningococcal pneumonia caused by Neisseria meningitidis. It is given to students when they are 11-13 years old.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
178.
        The following graph shows a certain pattern of occurrence of disease. Which of the following cancers is not associated with this distribution?
explanation:
Explanation

The above graph shows a bimodal distribution curve of disease. Out of the given options, chondrosarcoma is the only one not known to exhibit a bimodal distribution. 

Chondrosarcoma is the second most common malignant matrix-producing bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It predominantly affects individuals in their 40s or older, with men being twice as likely to be affected. 

Bimodality refers to the occurrence two separate peaks in the age incidence curve of a disease.

Example: Hodgkin's lymphoma shows a bimodal curve with peaks at 15–20 years and 70–80 years.

Examples of Cancers that exhibit bimodality:

  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Breast cancer
  • Cervical cancer
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
subject: Pathology

question_title:
179.
        FFA in a patient with macular ischemia would demonstrate:
question_ADD: FFA - Fundus Fluorescein Angiography
optionA:
A. Enlarged foveal avascular zone 
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. Stars in the sky appearance
explanation:
Explanation

The FFA would show an enlarged foveal avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow) in patients with macular ischemia. 

Interpreting fluorescein angiography images in a case of diabetic retinopathy:

  • Punctate (pinpoint) areas of hyperfluorescence - microaneurysms
  • Abnormal branching or dilatation of blood vessels - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) or retinal neovascularization
  • Fluorescein leakage - retinal neovascularization. Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc and leakage in other regions suggests proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • Patchy non-perfused retinal capillaries (seen as filling defects in capillaries) - ischemia from nonperfused retinal capillaries
  • Increase in the size of the foveal avascular zone - macular ischemia 

 The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the disc region and elsewhere.

The image below depicts the inkblot pattern in FFA. This is characteristically seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Fundus fluorescein angiography helps in confirming the diagnosis of CSR.

The image below shows the following charectaristic appearances:

  • Image A - Cystoid macular edema - Petaloid appearance
  • Image B - Central serous retinopathy - Smoke stack pattern
  • Image C - Drusen - Stars in the sky appearance
  • Image D - Macular Ischemia - enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non perfused areas.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_title:
180.
        A 40 year old patient with complaints of unilateral progressive hearing loss, tinnitus and mild balance problems over the past 8 months is diagnosed to have acoustic neuroma. Which among the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
optionA: A. A flat curve on tympanogram
optionB: B. A SISI Score of 80% is seen
optionD:
D. Speech audiogram shows roll over curve
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

Acoustic neuroma is a retro-cochlear disease and the speech audiogram of this patient will show a rollover curve.

Speech audiogram can be used to differentiate retro-cochlear lesions from cochlear lesions. Roll over phenomenon is the fall in curve rather than maintenance of plateau as seen in the cochlear lesions.

Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, neurilemmoma, or eighth nerve tumor, comprises 80% of all tumors located in the cerebellopontine angle. It is a benign, slow-growing tumor that encapsulates the VIIIth cranial nerve. Bilateral tumors can occur in patients with neurofibromatosis. Speech audiometry typically reveals disproportionately poor speech discrimination compared to the loss of pure tone hearing. A common observation is the "roll-over" phenomenon, where discrimination scores decrease when loudness exceeds a certain threshold.

Different tests to differentiate between cochlear lesions from retro-cochlear lesions : 

Test Type Normal Hearing Cochlear Lesions Retrocochlear Lesions
Pure Tone Audiometry Normal Sensorineural hearing loss Sensorineural hearing loss
Recruitment phenomenon Negative  Present Negative
Roll over phenomenon Negative Negative Present
SISI score 0-15% Above 70% 0-20%
Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) Interval between wave I and V is normal Interval between wave I and V is normal Delayed or absent wave V

Note: A flat curve in the tympanogram indicates fluid in the middle ear.
subject: ENT

question_title:
181.
        A surgeon performing a modified radical mastectomy decides to remove the pectoralis minor and level III lymph nodes but preserve the pectoralis major. Identify the procedure.
optionB:
B. Patey’s modified radical mastectomy
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

The given procedure where pectoralis minor and level III lymph nodes are removed but pectoralis major was preserved is Patey's modified radical mastectomy. 

Patey's modified radical mastectomy is a total mastectomy. It includes removal of the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes up to level III along with the removal of pectoralis minor muscle, but pectoralis major is preserved.

Other options:

Option A: Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy is a modification of Patey's procedure in which pectoralis minor is incised and not removed following which the level III nodes are approached. 

Option C: Halsted radical mastectomy involves excision of the breast tissue, skin, and nipple-areolar complex, dissection of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles. 

Option D: In, Auchincloss modified radical mastectomy, pectoralis minor is left intact and level III nodes are not removed. 

Pearl PM0880: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.
subject: Surgery

question_title:
182.
        A 40-year-old female patient is brought with complaints of acute and bilateral impairment of vision. She also has features of transverse myelitis and intractable hiccups. Antibodies against AQP-4 were detected. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
question_ADD:
AQP-4 - Aquaporin-4

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody
optionA: A. Autoimmune encephalitis with associated myelitis
optionB: B. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus with CNS involvement
explanation:
Explanation

The clinical features are consistent with a diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

NMO, otherwise known as Devic’s disease, is an autoimmune, inflammatory demyelinating disorder that is predominantly seen in middle-aged women. It is associated with specific IgG antibodies against AQP-4.

There are recurrent attacks of bilateral optic neuritis as well as severe transverse myelitis. NMO is also characterized by brain lesions such as:

  • area postrema in the lower medulla causing area postrema syndrome (intractable hiccups and vomiting)
  • cerebral hemispheres causing focal symptoms, seizures, and encephalopathy
  • hypothalamus causing endocrinopathies

It is a recurrent disease and acute attacks are treated with glucocorticoids. Steroid-resistant patients are given empirical plasma exchange. Prophylactic empirical regimens are recommended and include mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, and a combination of steroids and azathioprine. The newer monoclonal antibodies used in prophylaxis include:

  • eculizumab
  • inebilizumab
  • satralizumab 

Other options: 

Option A: Autoimmune encephalitis can present with a range of neurological symptoms and sometimes associated myelitis. However, autoimmune encephalitis is generally associated with anti-NMDA receptor antibodies and not AQP-4 antibodies.
 
Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including visual impairment and transverse myelitis. However, SLE is not typically associated with AQP-4 antibodies.
 
Option D: Sjögren’s syndrome causes lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands and is characterized by keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes), xerostomia, and profound B-cell hyperactivity. Anti-SSA/Ro60 autoantibodies are seen in this condition.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_title:
183.
        Which of the following factors may lead to a false-positive result during a dexamethasone suppression test?
question_ADD:
1. Phenobarbitone
  2. Pregnancy
  3. Phenytoin
  4. Rifampin
  5. OCPs
explanation:
Explanation

All the factors mentioned here lead to a false-positive result during a dexamethasone suppression test.

Dexamethasone suppression test is a diagnostic tool used primarily to screen for ACTH-independent hypercortisolism (also known as Cushing’s syndrome) caused by an adrenal nodule. 

It can give a false positive result with:

  • Antiseizure drugs: Drugs such as phenytoin, phenobarbital, and primidone can induce liver enzymes that increase cortisol metabolism, potentially affecting test results
  • Rifampin: also induces liver enzymes, affecting cortisol metabolism and test results.
  • Estrogen, during pregnancy or as oral contraceptives or HRT

In an overnight dexamethasone suppression test, Dexamethasone 1 mg is given orally at 11 pm and serum is collected for cortisol determination at 8 am the next morning; a cortisol level less than 1.8 mcg/dL, is a negative result and excludes Cushing syndrome.

Pearl PM1550: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Pearl PM1549: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome
subject: Medicine

question_title:
184.
        In the given image, the value of the ratio y/x is pathognomic if it is above:
question_ADD: y - thickness of the mucous gland layer
explanation:
Explanation

The given image depicts the Reid index. It is the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer (y) to the thickness of the wall between the cartilage and the epithelium (x). It is normally 0.4 and is increased in chronic bronchitis. The increase is in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years.

The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between emphysema and chronic bronchitis:
 

Predominant Bronchitis

Predominant Emphysema

Age (year)

40-45

50-75

Dyspnea

Mild; late

Severe; early

Cough

Copious sputum

Scanty sputum

Infections

Common

Occasional

Respiratory insufficiency

Repeated

Terminal

Cor pulmonale

Common

Rare

Airway resistance

Increased

Normal or slightly increased

Elastic recoil

Normal

Low

Chest radiograph

Prominent vessels; large heart

Hyperinflation; normal heart

Appearance

Blue bloater

Pink puffer
subject: Pathology

question_title:
185.
        A patient presents to the psychiatric OPD with a history of a sudden fall after his friend threw a plastic snake on him as a prank. He gives a history of similar episodes in the past, having vivid hallucinations and being in a dream-like state when he goes to sleep. The drug of choice for the given condition can also be used in which of the following conditions?
explanation:
Explanation

A history of sudden falls indicating loss of muscle tone following intense emotions like surprise, shock and vivid hallucinations and a dream-like state while going to sleep (hypnogogic hallucinations) is suggestive of narcolepsy. The drug of choice for narcolepsy is modafinil. It is also indicated for ADHD.

Modafinil is a mild stimulant and weak dopamine transporter inhibitor that prevents reuptake of extracellular dopamine, thereby increasing dopamine levels in the synapse and enhancing dopaminergic transmission. Other than narcolepsy, the stimulant action can be used for the treatment of ADHD. It can also be used as an off-label drug for cocaine, alcohol, amphetamine, and methamphetamine withdrawal. 

Narcolepsy is a disorder of sleep architecture characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness. The sleep attacks of narcolepsy represent episodes of irresistible sleepiness, leading to perhaps 10 to 20 minutes of sleep, after which the patient feels refreshed, at least briefly. The patients often experience symptoms related to the intrusion of REM sleep characteristics into wakefulness.

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (sleep onset REM).

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. The CNS stimulants used for treatment are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine.

Other options:

Option A: Drugs used for insomnia can be inducing agents like ramelteon and Z drugs and maintenance agents like dual orexin receptor antagonists (DORA). 

Option C: SSRIs, SNRIs, TCA, and atypical drugs like bupropion, and mirtazapine are used for the treatment of depression. 

Option D: Typical and atypical antipsychotics are used for the treatment of schizophrenia.
subject: Psychiatry

question_title:
186.
        A recently weaned child presents with perioral vesicular plaques sparing the upper lip and diarrhea. What is he likely to be deficient in?
explanation:
Explanation

This is the classical presentation of zinc deficiency leading to acrodermatitis enteropathica (Transient neonatal zinc deficiency) with diarrhea, alopecia, and a perioral and acral cutaneous eruption.  

The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, resulting in a ‘U' or ‘horseshoe‐shaped’ appearance. Risk factors include weaning from the breast, anorexia nervosa, alcoholism, vegetarianism, and inadequately supplemented total parenteral nutrition. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial(perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

The deficiency of copper leads to Menkes kinky hair syndrome.

Deficiency of selenium leads to Keshan disease and Kashin–Beck disease.
subject: Dermatology

question_title:
187.
        Assertion: The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and the early part of the distal tubule are called diluting segment.
Reason: The diluting segment reabsorbs sodium and is impermeable to water.
optionA:
A. Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
optionC: C. Assertion is true and reason is false
optionD: D. Assertion is false and reason is true
explanation:
Explanation

Here, both the assertion and the reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.

Sodium is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb of the loop of henle by secondary active transport facilitated by Na–K–2Cl cotransporter. Also, the thick ascending limb and early part of the distal tubule are impermeable to water. As a result, the fluid that enters the early part of the distal tubule is hypotonic.

Due to these reasons, the thick ascending limb and the early part of the distal tubule are called the diluting segment.

The image which shows the structure of the nephron and the tubular function is given below:
subject: Physiology

question_title:
188.
        A 1-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with bluish discoloration of the skin and rapid breathing. His mother reveals a history of congenital heart disease in the baby and adds that this episode was provoked by an incessant cry. Which of the following is least likely to be used for managing this child?
explanation:
Explanation

The least likely drug to be used for managing this child is intravenous nitroglycerin. The given scenario is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/ cyanotic spell. The administration of intravenous nitroglycerin is of no use and can worsen the condition, as it decreases peripheral resistance.

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic spells may also be referred to as tet spells/ blue spells/ hypoxic spells. Though commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot, they can be associated with other forms of pulmonary stenosis with ventricular septal defect as well. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking agitation.

They are characterized by:

  • Period of uncontrolled crying/ panic/ irritability
  • Rapid and deep breathing
  • Increased cyanosis
  • Limpness and lethargy
  • Reduced murmur intensity (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across the right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options for this child include the following:

  • Calm the child and minimize the stimuli
  • Place in the knee-chest position
  • Administer oxygen
  • Subcutaneous morphine (not in excess of 0.2mg/kg)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate - for correction of the ongoing metabolic acidosis
  • IV phenylephrine - as it increases the systemic vascular resistance
  • IV propranolol - as it reduces the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF
  • If the spell is resistant to all the above-said measures, then intubation and sedation of the child are required to break the spell

Pearl PM1213: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Persistent Truncus arteriosus

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

Tetrology of Fallot

Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication

Ebstein anomaly

Eisenmenger's syndrome

VSD with pulmonic stenosis

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation
subject: Paediatrics

question_title:
189.
        A 22-year-old P1L1 one day post normal vaginal delivery is having bleeding PV. Her vitals are normal. You reassure her that expulsion of the remaining placental tissue and blood is a normal physiological process. However, she insists on getting investigated, so you send the discharge for microscopy. Which of the following will not be predominantly seen in the discharge's workup?
explanation:
Explanation

The normal physiological discharge described here is lochia rubra and it predominantly does not contain leucocytes.  

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge resulting from the sloughing of decidual tissue in the early puerperal period. 

Name Colour Timings after delivery Contents
Lochia Rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, Vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia Serosa Yellowish/pink After 3 to 4 days WBCs, cervical mucus, micro-organisms
Lochia Alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterin crystals and fat cells 

The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL and may persist for about 3 weeks.

Foul-smelling lochia may be a symptom of post-partum endometritis.  Copious or absent lochia may also indicate infection or lochiometra. The persistence of lochia rubra beyond the normal limit may signify subinvolution or retained bits of the conceptus. Prolonged discharge of lochia alba for more than 3 weeks may signify a local genital lesion.
subject: Obstetrics & Gynaecology

question_title:
190.
        Match the following leukodystrophies with their corresponding abnormalities.
question_ADD:
Column A Column B
1. Lysosomal arylsulfatase A deficiency a. Alexander disease
2. GFAP gene mutations b. Adrenoleukodystrophy
3. Translation initiation factor eIF2B mutations c. Metachromatic leukodystrophy
4. ABCD1 peroxisomal transporter d. Vanishing white matter leukoencephalopathy
  e. Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease


GFAP: Glial fibrillary acidic protein

ABCD1: ATP binding cassette subfamily D
explanation:
Explanation

The correctly matched set is 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b (option C).

Lysosomal arylsulfatase A deficiency Metachromatic leukodystrophy
GFAP gene mutations Alexander disease
Translation initiation factor eIF2B mutations Vanishing white matter leukoencephalopathy
ABCD1 peroxisomal transporter Adrenoleukodystrophy


Leukodystrophies are a group of genetic disorders caused by mutations affecting the creation, maintenance, or repair of myelin. 

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A.

Mutations in intermediate filament proteins such as GFAP cause Alexander disease

A mutation in genes for various subunits of translation initiation factor eIF2B results in vanishing white matter leukoencephalopathy.

Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease associated with mutations in a member of the ATP-binding cassette transporter family of proteins (ABCD1), which is involved in the transport of molecules into the peroxisome.

Mutations in genes that encode proteins required for myelin formation result in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination. Proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) located at Xq22 is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system.
subject: Pathology

question_title:
191.
        Choose the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure in the given image of the head.
optionA:
A. It arises from the posteromedial aspect of the external carotid artery.
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionB: B. It supplies the palatine tonsils.
optionC: C. It contributes to the supply of the nasal septum.
optionD: D. It give off branches in the cervical region.
explanation:
Explanation

The structure marked in the given image, emerging on the edge of the mandible at the anteroinferior border of the masseter muscle is the facial artery. 

The facial artery is an anterior branch (option A) of the external carotid artery, given off in the neck region, just above the greater cornua of the hyoid bone. The artery is very sinuous throughout its course. This is so that the artery is able to adapt to the movements of the neck and the face during daily activities. It gives of four branches in the neck and four on the face.

Its 4 branches in the neck region are (option D):

  • Ascending palatine artery supplies the soft palate and the eustachain tube. 
  • Tonsillar artery is the main arterial supply to the palatine tonsils (option B)
  • Submental artery is the largest cervical branch of facial artery. It supplies the overlying skin and muscles in the submental region. 
  • Glandular branches supply the submandibular salivary gland. 

Its 4 named branches on the face are:

  • Premasseteric artery is small and inconstant. When present, it goes upwards along the anterior border of masseter and supplies the surrounding area.
  • Inferior labial artery arises near the angle of the mouth. It runs between the orbicularis oris muscle and the mucous membrane. It supplies the glands, mucous membrane and the muscles.
  • Superior labial artery is larger and more tortuous than the inferior labial artery. It pursues a similar course along the superior labial margin, between the mucous membrane and orbicularis oris, anastomoses with its contralateral fellow, and supplies the upper lip. It gives off a septal branch that ramifies anteroinferiorly in the nasal septum. (option C)
  • Lateral nasal artery is given off by the side of the nose, supplies the dorsum and ala of the nose, and anastomoses with its contralateral fellow. 

The part of the artery distal to its terminal branch is called the angular artery.
subject: Anatomy

question_title:
192.
        A 5-month-old boy was recently diagnosed with bronchiolitis. The doctor explains to the mother that it is caused by a virus which is the most common cause of the disease in infants. Which of the following statements are true regarding the management of this condition?
question_ADD:
1. The treatment depends mostly on supportive care
  2. The drug approved for the treatment of the condition is ribavirin
  3. The drug can be given in both oral and aerosol forms
  4. The preferred mode of administration is inhalational for 3–6 days
  5. Immunoglobulins can be used for prophylaxis
explanation:
Explanation

The most common cause of bronchiolitis in infants is respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and all the statements given are true except the statement that "the drug can be given in both oral and aerosol forms". 

The mainstay of treatment for bronchiolitis in infants is supportive care. Ribavirin is the approved treatment of the lower respiratory tract infection caused by RSV, especially in infants who are at risk of severe disease. Oral ribavirin is not useful, so it is administered as an aerosol for 3–6 days. 

Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody against the RSV F glycoprotein that is used for the prevention of RSV lower respiratory tract disease in children at high risk of RSV disease.
subject: Microbiology

question_title:
193.
        Given below is a graph charting the hormone levels in a normal pregnancy. Which of the following hormones is represented by curve 1?
question_ADD:
(hCG - human chorionic gonadotropin)

(hCS - human chorionic somatomammotropin)
explanation:
Explanation

In the given graph of hormone levels in a normal pregnancy, the hormone represented by curve 1 is human chorionic gonadotropin. 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted in pregnancy. It is a glycoprotein similar in structure to LH, FSH and TSH. It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta. hCG maintains the corpus luteum for secretion of estrogen and progesterone till 13 to 17 weeks after conception and thus has a role to play in maintaining early pregnancy. 

hCG can be detected in the blood by radio-immunoassay as soon as 8 to 9 days after ovulation. Its level peaks at 10 to 12 weeks of pregnancy and then falls by the 16th to 20th week. It remains at this low level for the rest of the pregnancy. 

hCG can also be detected as early as 14 days after conception in urine, which is more commonly used as a sample for pregnancy diagnosis. However, hCG is not specific for the diagnosis of pregnancy, as hCG is also detected in gastrointestinal tumors in both males and females. 

Curve 2 represents estrogen (option C), and curve 3 represents progesterone (option D). In pregnancy, both hormones are secreted in large quantities by the placenta. Estrogen levels rise steadily throughout pregnancy. However, from the seventh month onwards, progesterone secretion remains constant. Thus, the estrogen-to-progesterone ratio increases towards the end of pregnancy, as depicted by curve 2 crossing curve 3 towards the latter half of pregnancy.  

Human chorionic somatomammotropin (hCS) (option B) is a protein hormone secreted from the placenta during the 5th week of pregnancy. Its levels rise throughout pregnancy. hCS causes decreased insulin sensitivity in the pregnant woman and acts similarly to growth hormone.
subject: Physiology

question_title:
194.
        A 60-year-old male presents with a history of vivid dreams and physical movements during sleep, as reported by his spouse. He has injured himself and his bed partner during these episodes. Polysomnography reveals prominent muscle activity during REM sleep without associated atonia. Which of the following conditions is associated with his symptoms?
question_ADD: Rapid Eye Movement- REM
optionA:
A. REM Sleep Behavior Disorder
                
                  
                    
Correct
explanation:
Explanation

Among the following conditions, the one that is associated with his symptoms is rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder (RBD).  

RBD involves a disruption in normal REM sleep paralysis, allowing patients to act out their dreams physically. During REM sleep, the brain usually inhibits motor neurons to prevent movement. However, in RBD, this paralysis is incomplete or intermittent, leading to behaviors that correlate with dream content. Unlike sleepwalking, where individuals may perform activities calmly and with some awareness of their surroundings, RBD patients are more likely to aggressively act out their dreams, potentially causing harm to themselves or others. This can result in injuries ranging from minor cuts to severe fractures. 

Diagnostic confirmation of RBD involves polysomnography that reveals RBD without atonia (loss of muscle tone). Management of RBD typically begins with melatonin, commonly prescribed at doses up to 20 mg daily. Melatonin aims to regulate sleep-wake cycles and mitigate symptoms of RBD. However, if melatonin proves ineffective or intolerable, alternative medications such as clonazepam, gabapentin, or codeine may be considered cautiously. These options require careful monitoring due to potential adverse effects such as worsened cognition or increased risk of falls.

Other Options:

B. Sleep-related epilepsy: typically presents with seizures that occur at any stage of sleep and is less specifically associated with muscle activity during REM sleep.

C. Sleepwalking: occurs during non-REM (NREM) sleep and is not characterized by vivid dreams or REM sleep-related muscle activity

D. Nightmares: They typically do not involve physical movements or muscle activity during REM sleep
subject: Psychiatry

question_title:
195.
        Which of the following drugs used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension cannot be given orally?
explanation:
Explanation

Epoprostenol is a drug used in pulmonary hypertension which cannot be taken orally. It is given as IV infusion. 

Epoprostenol is a synthetic prostacyclin and hence causes vasodilation in both systemic and pulmonary vasculature. It is rapidly degraded by digestive enzymes and the liver due to which it has a short half-life (3-5 mins). It is, therefore, given as a continuous IV infusion. 

It is used in advanced stages of pulmonary artery hypertension. 

Side effects are extended pharmacological actions of prostacyclins such as flushing, dizziness, systemic hypotension, and diarrhoea. All other drugs above can be administered orally. 
All patients with pulmonary artery hypertension should undergo certain lifestyle modifications like reducing heavy physical exercise. Normally during physical exercise blood flow to the lungs increases, but in PAH it is impaired due to vascular remodeling as a result of increased pressure.
subject: Pharmacology

question_title:
196.
        Assertion: Cardiac hypertrophy shows increased gene expression of atrial natriuretic factor.
Reason: Hypertrophy leads to the switch of contractile proteins from adult to fetal forms.
optionA: A. Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
optionB:
B. Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
                
                  
                    
Correct
optionC: C. The assertion is true, but the reason is false statement
optionD: D. The assertion is false, but the reason is true statement
explanation:
Explanation

The assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

Hypertrophy refers to the enlargement of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the affected organ. Cells that do not divide, such as myocardial fibers, increase the mass of their tissue through hypertrophy. Cardiac hypertrophy shows increased gene expression of atrial natriuretic factor, a peptide hormone. This hormone facilitates salt secretion by the kidneys, reducing blood volume and lowering blood pressure, thereby alleviating hemodynamic stress.

Cardiac hypertrophy occurs due to an increase in the production of cellular proteins. It also involves a change in gene expression where adult-type contractile proteins are swapped for fetal isoforms of the same proteins. For instance, the α isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the β isoform, which contracts more slowly and with greater energy efficiency. Additionally, hypertrophic myocardial cells exhibit changes in proteins governed by genes responsive to cellular stress.

Hence, both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
subject: Pathology

question_title:
197.
        A 24-year-old man comes to the OPD with decreased vision. He also gave a history of tremors and dysarthria for 2 months now. After a thorough examination, the physician suspects Wilson's disease. Which is the most sensitive and accurate test for diagnosing this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

The most sensitive and accurate test in diagnosing Wilson's disease is measuring the hepatic copper content.

The diagnosis of Wilson's disease is based on the following:

  • Increased 24-hour urinary excretion of copper (the most specific screening test)
  • Increase in hepatic copper content (the most sensitive and accurate test)
  • A decrease in serum ceruloplasmin
  • Kayser–Fleischer rings 
  • Genetic testing for mutations in the ATP7B gene
 
Serum copper levels are of no diagnostic use since they may be low, normal, or elevated depending on the stage of the disease.
subject: Pathology

question_title:
198.
        A teenager was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of mental retardation and delayed growth and sexual development. Ultrasonography revealed thyroid atrophy. Which of the following nutrient deficiency is most likely to be associated with this condition?
explanation:
Explanation

Selenium deficiency is most likely to be associated with mental retardation and, delayed growth and sexual development in this patient.

The clinical presentation of the child is indicative of a myxedematous type of endemic cretinism, which can be caused by a deficiency of selenium and iodine.

Endemic cretinism includes two overlapping syndromes: a neurologic type and a myxedematous type.

Persons with myxedematous syndrome are intellectually challenged, deaf, and they have delayed growth and sexual development, myxedema, and thyroid atrophy. Delayed skeletal maturation is present, which may extend into the 3rd decade or later.

Selenium deficiency has been implicated in the myxedematous syndrome; it decreases the synthesis of thyroid hormones by impaired functioning of selenoproteins like iodothyronine deiodinases, which are responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3. This decreased production of thyroid hormones leads to the stimulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis due to the lack of negative feedback control, thereby, increasing TSH production. TSH stimulates the iodothyronine deiodinases to convert T4 to T3, with consequent production of hydrogen peroxide, which accumulates itself in the thyroid tissue causing thyrocyte damage with subsequent fibrosis. Therefore, serum T4 levels are low and TSH levels are markedly elevated. It also contributes to antioxidant defense in the thyroid. Ultrasonographic examination shows thyroid atrophy.

Other causes of the myxedematous type of endemic cretinism include foods like linseed, sorghum, sweet potato, cabbage, cauliflower, turnips, soy and millet, which are all goitrogenic; thiocyanates and Yersinia.

Deficiency of selenium can also give rise to depressed mood and hostile behaviour; it is implicated in Keshan disease, which is congestive cardiomyopathy along with heart failure, ECG abnormalities, cardiac enlargement and cardiogenic shock, seen in children and women of child-bearing age and in Kashin-Beck disease, which is characterised by bone, cartilage and joint deformity. Additionally, selenium along with vitamin E is essential for normal functioning glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that protects cell membranes and lipid-containing organelles from peroxidative damage.

Other options:

Option B: Chromium deficiency leads to impaired glucose tolerance.

Option C: Fluoride deficiency leads to an increased susceptibility to dental caries.

Option D: Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

Pearl PM0124: Differences between the two types of endemic cretinism

Neurological type Myxedematous type
Goiter  No goiter (USG shows thyroid atrophy)
Euthyroid  Permanent hypothyroidism
Intellectual disability, deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity, and rigidity Intellectual disability, Deaf, coarse facial features, and myxedema.
Normal pubertal development and adult stature Delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development, severe short stature
subject: Biochemistry

question_title:
199.
        Penile scrapings from an immunocompromised patient show multinucleate giant cells with Lipschultz bodies. If he develops encephalitis, which of the following lobes is most commonly involved?
explanation:
Explanation

Lipschultz bodies are intranuclear inclusion bodies seen in the multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells) in case of herpes simplex infection (HSV-1 & HSV-2). Tzanck preparation (Wright & Giemsa staining) of the tissue scrapings reveals these findings. Herpes simplex can cause encephalitis and temporal lobe is most commonly involved.

MRI showing prominent swelling, increase T2 signal involving the left temporal lobe and insular cortex.

Herpes simplex usually spreads by sexual contact or vertical transmission from the pregnant mother to the fetus. Clinical manifestations range from oral-cutaneous lesions to disseminated disease-causing encephalitis, pneumonitis, and hepatitis.

Safe sexual practice and the use of antivirals like acyclovir remain the mainstay of treatment.

Pearl PM0144: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies
Psittacosis, Chlamydia psittacci  Levinthal-Cole-Lille bodies (LCL bodies)
Trachoma, Chlamydia trachomatis Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies
Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules

 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies
Disease/Virus Inclusion bodies
Rabies Negri bodies
Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus
Cowdry type A Lipschutz inclusions Herpes Virus
Torres bodies Yellow fever
Cowdry type B Basophilic inclusions Adenovirus

  • Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies 
Disease/Virus  Inclusion bodies

Cytomegalovirus Owl-eye inclusions (basophilic, predominantly intra-nuclear, small granular intracytoplasmic inclusions are found)

 

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections

subject: Microbiology

question_title:
200.
        A 40-year old male patient was referred to you with the features of testicular and renal tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you identified the presence of parathyroid and pituitary adenoma and hence advised him to undergo chromosomal studies. The gene mutation responsible for this condition is located on ___________
explanation:
Explanation

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of MEN 4 syndrome which is caused by germline mutations in the CDKN1B gene, located on chromosome 12.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is characterized by the occurrence of tumors involving two or more endocrine glands within a single patient.

MEN 4 comprises:

  • Reproductive organ tumors such as testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical cancer
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

Note :

  • MEN 1 is caused by a germline mutation in the MEN1 gene (menin protein),  tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 11.
  • MEN 2(both 2A and 2B) is caused by a germline mutation in the RET proto-oncogene, located on chromosome 10.

Pearl PM1138: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

Pearl PM1137: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon
subject: Surgery
